I was never certain how this AYCE pizza thing worked but now I know:  it works very well.  Almost from the moment one is seated, servers appear with hot from the oven pizzas, tell you what they are, and wave their little spatula around, enticing you to agree to a slice.  Even if you pass on it another pizza will be proffered momentarily, all different and no duds unless you count that one covered with hot peppers which was too much even for this heat-a-holic.  

What I particularly liked about this AYCE pizza thing were the slim slices.  Were they offering the large slices you get when you order a single piece elsewhere you might not get to sample much or feel like you got your money's worth; these slim slices allow you to try many slices and many toppings.  Win-win.  

This isn't fancy pizza. I doubt that people who scout out top pizzas will come here and decide that Goat Hill's are tops, but they're satisfying; I liked 'em.  And I really liked how the pizzas kept being offered, even when I'd started refusing most which walked by.  They might not tell you about the salad bar with its old-school iceberg lettuce but it's there, in the back room, and makes a perfect pizza accompaniment.  

A mellow glass of house red wine ($4) was even better when ordered as a half carafe ($8.50).  It came to almost 4 glasses.

Goat Hill's Monday night well-priced AYCE is perfect for those times when you're actually hungry and a bit thirsty too.  

*  Monday night AYCE runs from 4 - 10 p.m.
*  AYCE for kids ages 5 - 12 costs only $6.95.
author: Tracey A.

description:
Is it Monday yet?! This place makes me look forward to Mondays with their all you can eat! 
When you're seated, you're given a paper plate and immediately the servers come by with their pizzas. It's like dim sum style where they walk around and come by your table and ask you if you want a slice. There are a lot of varieties and I can go through the whole meal without repeating a slice with the same toppings. There is usually a good number of people so the pizzas are always piping hot with a crispy crust. Delicious! The slices are tiny but the servers keep your plate full so you get to try many kinds and no waste. There is a mediocre salad bar in the back but I ain't here for the salad. Love this place and so grateful it's in the neighborhood.
author: Melissa C.

description:
I've heard so many good things about this place, I think I had set my expectations too high. Don't get me wrong, this pizza is good, but it's not one of the most amazing pizzas I've ever had. There was something missing and I can't put my finger on it. I came here late on a Saturday night as we were the only people in the restaurant (I guess pizza is more of a to-go kind of food). We ordered a medium half veggie and half hilda's favorite. My favorite of the two was the veggie - the vegetables were fresh and there were so many of them piled on the pizza. A medium was a good size for 2, we had 2 slices leftover which was enough for one person's lunch the next day! This pizza was good, but nothing exceptional and unfortunately this location is kind of out of the way for me so I don't know when I'll be back. 

I can imagine that this restaurant is good for larger parties because they do have a lot of space in the back!
author: Malika R.

description:
This place used to be a lot better.

Over the years the quality had gone down and the prices have gone up. This is mostly reflected in the pizza, but even the usually delicious minestrone soup taste gross tonight, and was all one color and texture. The qualities that usually makes their version of minestrone good (the variety of vegetables and thinner broth) were completely absent. It was just slop :(

The pizza is decent, if you like thin and sourdough crust.
author: Reena R.

description:
I'm not sure why but I prefer this location to the one I live next to in SOMA. I know they won't deliver to me so I'll have to get in my car and drive all but maybe 2 miles but I'll do it every time. 

I'm a big fan of their special Hilda pizza but living with a carnivore sometimes we have to compromise with killing Hilda with meats. Either way, they are always friendly, have great service and for some odd reason, always taste better than the made while you wait GH down the street. 

They also have all you can eat on Monday night's where they walk by your table with different types of funky pizzas. How they come up with them, who knows? But it's a great twist on an all-you-can-eat and gets you out of the box trying new things.
author: Leina K.

description: Happened to find myself in the city down the road a bit & drove up the hill, spotting this place randomly. Glad I did, my 2 year old & I caught a yummy late lunch of spinach & cheese ravioli & meatballs. We both approve! And loved the garlic bread :) I'll keep this place the next time I'm in the area, everyone around us seemed to be devouring their pizzas happily. We'll have to try those next.
author: Erika R.

description:
People working there really are incompetent; I placed an order at 7 pm for 830. After talking with 3 different people I was able to place an order. Guess what happened 1 hour after the order was in? Someone else called me saying that the order could not be delivered!!!! 1 hour after! We were starving and it was really unappreciated! Really awful experience after 12 hour work day.
Also I used a coupon and it was redeemed without getting any pizza!
REALLY SADLY BAD EXPERIENCE!
author: Lorenzo X.

description:
New Years Eve, Me and the Girl-Pal are staying in an AirBnB 5 minutes from downtown Potrero Hill in San Francisco.  We ordered the Hilda's Favorite.  It was perfectly delectable, just the right amount of pesto sauce, not over-powering with the goat cheese. 

I will definitely be coming back to GHP on future visits to the City.
author: Drew P.

description:
Goat Hill's claim to fame is its sourdough crust, so your opinion on the pizza largely depends on your love for that.

I personally like the stuff they have here -- it's kind of chewy but it is by no means tough. I do like their large cuts of bread, but the pizza itself could stand to have some fresher veggies.
author: Casey S.

description:
Why do I love Yelp parties?  Answer:  Finding places that I normally wouldn't try.  
Remembering a great YEE here, a light bulb lit above my head.  I thought of Goat Hill's pizza and thought of Wilhelm's recommendation of their lasagna.  I phoned in my takeout order and picked it up about 30 minutes later.  The food was ready and here's what I had:   

1) Pepperoni, Sausage, & Mushroom Pizza, large (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gVikx9Ad2aAVv0BXnJJPKw#Yr-Bm0W6QTS5DDqdcsBhkg) - Perfectly cooked as the toppings were just right flavor wise.  The sour dough crust is a great change from the current trendy thin crusts throughout the city.  $23.65

2) Meat Lasagna, full order (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/gVikx9Ad2aAVv0BXnJJPKw?select=CJHsXUaIj_5TvPUxYxHJYw#CJHsXUaIj_5TvPUxYxHJYw) - Served with two garlic bread slices, there is no lack of sauce in their rendition.  Two lasagna squares are filling, but not the best I've tried.  $12.95

I must say that I was a bit surprised that my bill was a tad over $40.00.  No, I didn't eat ALL this food, saving half of the pizza for my dad's midnight snack.  I actually ate half of the lasagna and two slices of the pizza for my lunch... carb alert!
This relatively old school pizzeria definitely buck the trend of NYC/thin crust pies and, sometimes, it's just to have something just a little different from everyone else.
author: Mike C.

description: Being a New Yorker, Goat Hill Pizza is the closest in taste and quality in SF. I frequent the West Portal location more than the other 2 spots and I'd say this is ok. Definitely old school neighborhood vibe, which I like, but I wish the staff and service was more welcoming. Overall an okay experience and if you're in that part of town then definitely stick to GHP.
author: M J.

description:
I order goat hill all the time!  A solid, reliable pizza place.  

The interior is cute and seems targeted at familys.  Children's drawings are on the walls (also in the bathroom).  They also were giving out slices on halloween to kids, thought that was cute!

Pricing is fair.

The pizza itself is pretty good.  I'd say a solid top 30% pizza, but not quite a top 15%. Really enjoy it (hence why I get it all the time), but I would actually prefer Long Bridge Pizza nearby in Dogpatch.  Not really too much to say about the pizza...it's a normal, good pizza.
author: Casey P.

description: Not entirely the pizza place's fault, but the driver decided to text us 90 minutes after we ordered our pizza saying he was going to be another 30 minutes because his car was broken. It would have been another 45 minutes to get a new pizza baked and delivered. They canceled the order for us and were apologetic, but we're still hungry and have no pizza.
author: Dale B.

description:
Great pizza. Try the Goat hill one and it is great. Molten goat cheese fills you up fast but again thats a personal taste.

Will definitely go there when we are in the area.
author: Ram S.

description: Terrible service. Let me order, pay them and then 40 minutes later said they were cancelling it. They didn't know they were closing early when they took my order? Won't be back!
author: Kristi E.

description:
This is the place that finally convinced me that San Francisco cannot make a decent thin-crust pizza. 

Pizza here is equivalent to Domino's in quality, but costs more than twice as much.

We've ordered it a few times -- either delivery or to go. For ~$32, you can get one large pie with two meat toppings.

The crust is supposedly Sourdough, but is bland and chewy. The rest of the ingredients are similarly mediocre.

Either go to one of the fantastic SF deep dish joints (Little Star, Ragazza) and get a killer pizza for this price, or call Domino's if you're pinching pennies. Just don't waste your money here.
author: Andrea F.

description:
These guys are serious about customer service!! That and their pizza is delicious.

I placed an order through caviar for a company luncheon, which caviar screwed up by changing the delivery time 2 hours after we needed it there. I called goat hill the morning of delivery, as it was my first time using caviars delivery service. The manager was quick to remedy the situation by getting her chefs to make 15 pizzas out for delivery before the restaurant opened. The pizza was a hit and the service can't be beat, I would order again but this time directly through goat hill if they do that.
author: Ruth M.

description:
TGIF! The little one wanted cheese pizza for dinner so here we came! It was pretty busy, filled with families just like us, little ones running around, we fit right in.

I ordered a medium cheese with light sauce and a chef's salad. My son eats like a bird so he only had one piece, however, he enjoyed every bite. He was more interested in drawing on his place mat and hanging it on the wall. The salad was good, too much for me to finish, had enough left over to take both the salad and pizza to go. 

I have to say the service was awesome! Our waitress came by and checked on us several times. My son kept asking her to hang his drawing on the wall, even while he had food on top it :-/ Also, when the check came, she asked if ok to give the candy mints. 

This is a great place for families, if only we lived closer I'd order delivery too!
author: Kristine R.

description:
I made a Friday night reservation on Thursday night at their Potrero Hill location. Parking was easy to find there and the restaurant is pretty casual too. 

Loved their pizza. 

Highly recommend Hilda's Favorite. 

I don't recommend Vegetarian Combination. It could use some more sauce.
author: Hiral P.

description:
Very consistent in putting out great food. The house Italian dressing is the ONLY way to do. Pizza is always cooked to perfection. Spaghetti and meatballs looked amazing! 

Check in for complimentary cheesy garlic bread - score!
author: T N.

description: Someone asked me why I don't just order from caviar. This pizza is already about $35 for a M why would I continue to support businesses that don't even want our business by paying an extra $10 to have it delivered. No fucking thanks.
author: Nika C.

description: Fresh decent pizza. For some reason I like the smaller location on Portal Ave but this is pretty nice as well. This location has a great local vibe and is good for small parties. Yes, go here for the crust if nothing else.
author: Michael H.

description: Good food in a relaxed and fun atmosphere.  They treat you like family.  Home cooking and good Italian recipes.  Monday night all you can eat pizza is perfect if you city me in a big group.
author: Suren S.

description: I love it here! I always come on the weekends for lunch. The staff are always so courteous and attentive. They are so kind to take my order ahead of time via phone so that after sitting I need only wait a short time. Their pizza is always perfect, I love their unique crust. Also the chicken wings and ranch sauce are always a wonderful addition. It's a wonderful restaurant and has great atmosphere.
author: Frank L.

description:
Goat Hill offers a full menu of delicious pizza choices on a crispy sourdough crust. Come in during the late afternoon and you'll avoid the crowd. Also, your pizza will come out hot and fresh within minutes!

TIP: Can't choose between the different pizza offerings?! You can request to get two in one pie. 
Sharing with a friend? Upgrade to a larger size for a couple dollars more, and do a split of two different choices. I recommend Hilda's Favorite and Mediterranean.
author: Edwina L.

description:
Goat Hill reminds me of the kind of pizza place I went to growing up - Formica(-like) tables, wooden chairs and no-nonsense pizza (even if Goat Hill does have sourdough crust). 

It's a great place to go with kids because they have normal kid-type pizzas (just pineapple! Plain cheese pizza!) and garlic bread - classic French bread slathered in butter and garlic. Portions are hearty which is another reason why it's a good place for families. 

Super kid friendly - they bring out crayons for the kids to draw and even post the artwork around the restaurant.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Happened to visit here on a Monday.  Turns out that's kind of a big deal.  It's all you can eat pizza and salad bar for $13.  They have a variety of pizzas that they'll keep walking around and shoveling on your plate, should you so agree, and the little salad bar helps you to feel a little bit better.  

Neither are so overly spectacular that you'd really want to pay that much for all you can eat, but they both have enough flavor that you don't feel like you're completely losing out on the deal.  I did have to eat way more than anticipated, however, to justify the cost.  At least the good flavors helped!
author: Jes G.

description: Honestly, I love goat hill pizza. This is my only bad experience and I'd give a higher rating but nobody is willing to contact me. I ordered an x large pie and got what looked like 2 leftover pizzas smashed together. I'd definitely recommend eating here, but I can't say the customer service is on par with similar restaurants.
author: Devin H.

description:
Really great pizza. You get what you actually order! No fuss, no muss! 

Fresh garlic on pizza is the best.
author: Juan H.

description: We love Goat Hill Pizza. Many great pies here...especially the "porky pie" - in which they roast huge bulbs of garlic on your pizza, add bacon etc. Their salads are delicious as is their garlic bread & spaghetti & meatballs. Great for kids/families/groups. On street parking. Delish!
author: Amanda M.

description:
Mind you, I'm no vegan, but our order on this hot day today confirmed this place has good food. We got a Californian pizza (naturally with artichokes hearts, tomatoes and garlic), but also with anchovies and jalapeños applied. Anchovies count as seafood of some sort, and each add-on ingredient enhanced the flavor!

Also ordered their Caprese salad with mozzarella and tomatoes. Decided that one cold item would better compliment as a side dish on a hot day than something like hot wings, despite my carnivorous tendencies. With temperatures outdoors literally reaching 90° F or higher, anything cooler was preferable. Window seat with blowing air was also nice.
author: Garett T.

description:
Good pizza. The Portuguese pizza was good. But the cheese pizza with pepperoni and anchovies just rocks! Tasty and satisfying. Flavors just blend together nicely. 

Didn't care for the hot wings as they were too fatty. The salad was okay as well. But the pizza is the highlight of our meal. 

Damn good pizza.
author: Marck N.

description: The pricing on the menu doesn't seem to fit what you actually get charged. On the menu it said small pizza 15.95, then when the receipt arrived it said "small pizza 19.95"! It wasn't very tasty either - most of the flavour came from an overdose of garlic (this was the 'Californian'). And to top it off, a few days later I noticed I'd been charged twice!! I phoned them and after forwarding me through a few managers, they gave me a refund but no apology or anything. Terrible business; avoid.
author: Mel M.

description:
Great local pizza place. I live across the street, so I come here all the time. Things to order:

- Hawaiian Pizza (sounds weird, but the ham they use is legit)
- Pizza by the slice (you can order any toppings you want)
- Meatball sandwich 
- Anything with roasted garlic
author: Cory D.

description: Great place to bring kids, if you have them. Pizza is one of the best in the city.
author: Miguel D.

description:
I've been here a few times for lunch and I do have to say it does taste pretty good!

The pizza is on spot and the prices are one of the best around. I also support businesses that support others.

Thanks guys!
author: Ian A.

description:
i so wish the pizza were better here, but its just not. there is something lacking, and its hard to pinpoint what - the crust is crispy but not in a good way, and there's an essential flavor missing, not just once but each time i've had it.     

what was amazing was their curried mushroom soup -not your typical cream of mushroom as it featured coconut milk and madras curry powder. wow! what a delicious twist. we'll definitely be back to try all things not pizza, but the pizza, man oh man, how i wish it were better.
author: Archana P.

description:
You don't really think about the sourdough crust even though that's what makes it special, because it didn't particularly scream "SOURDOUGH" to me.

My friend and I got the porky pie which if you love garlic like I do is heaven. I don't know why no one's put garlic and bacon together with a white sauce but it is a revelation and I'm pretty sure there'll be a new religion dedicated to its greatness soon.

I think for sure what's best is the box and the logo which is this goat face throwing some 'tude yet looking oddly smug and self-aware at the same time. Something to aspire to. That goat is hbic.
author: Rosy H.

description: Ordered an XL half Hawaiian half chicken on sourdough crust online for pickup. Was ready in 30 min. I don't even like sourdough bread but my boyfriend has been wanting to try Goat Hill so I had an open mind. I'm really surprised how much I loved this crust, it's crispy and delicious with ranch. Yes it's more expensive than Little Ceasers or Dominos but same price point as DNA Lounge or Escape from NY. Highly recommend Goat Hill and will be ordering again!
author: Amanda L.

description:
This is a nice sit-down place, not too fancy but comfortable and cozy. 

The Caprese was fresh and the waitresses were attentive. The Porky Pie is very good. We were tempted by the It's Its in the freezer but decided not to indulge since we had a medium pie between the three of us and were quite full.
author: Rebecca M.

description: I'm visiting from New York, where we have some of the best pizza in the world. My wife and I ordered a medium pie to be delivered to a local brewery on a Wednesday night. The pizza was damn good! We got a plain cheese pie and a porky pie (this one is really good). The only negative is the price point. 22$ for a medium pie is a little steep. I can get an extra large pie at regular sports for 6$ LESS that this. Other than the price, it's good pizza.
author: Alexander Z.

description:
Great suggestion by my daughter. Goat Hill is one of the better pie joints I've been too. Not Chicago or NY style per-say, but excellent nonetheless. And surprisingly, the plain cheese was exceptional. 

If I was in the area, I would definitely come back. 

p.s. The Anchor Steam was on point.
author: Daniel W.

description:
I really don't understand the hype about this place - at least from the culinary perspective.  They have a neighborhood night on Mon with all-you-can-eat pizza and salad, but the food was average. 

I like they have a wine list and the service was very attentive to all the details of the order.
author: Marianna K.

description:
Pizza and I have a long standing relationship.  It's one of those comfort foods that really can be made with anything and it'll always work itself out (for the most part). Pizza draws me back to my childhood where I, like many countless others dined on Totino's or Red Baron during primary school, graduated to Little Ceasers and the other's during high school, and then to the more customized and refined of sorts into college and graduate schools.

I must admit that the goat cheese, pesto, and tomato pizza at this Goat Hill Pizza location knocked my socks off!  I love different cheeses, and the creaminess, saltiness, silkiness, and bite of that pizza was pure foodgasm.  It was an experience similar to when your mouth is overcome with water when you initially bite into something sour, or when you crave a certain food and your mouth all of a sudden floods.

The other pizzas here were just as great.  I had a meat combination pizza, a standard slice of cheese, and a roasted garlic w/ bacon slice that for any pork fat lover like myself, I could've hidden in a dark corner and just savored for all of eternity.  

Chasing them down with a pair of pitchers filled with Stella Artois and then transferred to my ice cold frosted mug was just heaven.  It has been a long time since I've had an opportunity to just sit down and appreciate a good slice of pie; this certainly made me check this box off!

The restaurant itself is riddled with local art that can be purchased if you wish.  Reviews are plastered everywhere from adults to small children, even in the bathroom for you to conveniently read if you so choose.

The use of non-modern engineering upgrades add to the charm and character this location has.  And you know what they say, "If it aint broke, don't fix it".  

FOOD: Spectacular

DRINKS: Even better.

BATHROOMS: Clean! and spacious

LOCATION: Parking can be a mess depending on time of day but doable. And plenty of public transportation to get you around the hilly neighborhood.
AMBIANCE: Definitely dressed to the local flavor.

EXPERIENCE: I'LL BE BACK!
author: Myke Y.

description:
My sister's family insisted on taking me out for a late bday dinner and we selected Little Star on Divisidero because it's been called the best pie in the city. Unfortunately it was closed for a private party so we immediately made a beeline for Goat Hill Pizza instead. Turns out it was their all-you-can-eat night so we were excited to try as many different flavors as possible.

Their AYCE deal is served sort of like at a Brazilian churrascuria and I ate about 12 slices of pizza, all of which were different. My favorites were definitely the anchovy and olive, the sausage, and the meat lovers. What can I say, I love meat! They also had a salad bar which was nice, but the best part was the dressings which served double duty as dipping sauces for my 'za! We also scored a pitcher of Anchor Steam to wash it all down.

I love the food here, ever since being introduced to it by a Yelp Elite event. I had no idea they had the AYCE deal on Mondays, but it's freakin' awesome and I can't wait to come back! I left stuffed and happy, and anxious to return soon. I'd definitely recommend it!

Food: 8/10

Service: 9/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 8/10
author: Joe M.

description: There's not much I can say except that the food was incredibly delicious!! I had the meatball sub and minestrone soup. Tasted as good as I hoped, and aside from my own cooking, was as close as I could get to the flavors of east/coast Italian! I'm definitely looking forward to returning.
author: Jay G.

description: Pizza was okay. Not great. The crust was thin and the pizza oily. They charge their own tip so don't bother to leave any.
author: Yurani B.

description: Best  South of the Market! Order anything, can't go wrong! But do talk to staff, they are knowledgeable and helpful
author: Ilias B.

description:
FOOD -

Got the cheesy bread! Free with a check in. DELICIOUS! The cheese is so gooey and warm. I loved it. Tasted even better because it was free.

We ordered two large thin crust pizzas. One was half combo and half chicken florentine and the other was half hilda's and half Greek Gourmet. I really really liked the chicken florentine, but I just wish the chicken were cut up a bit smaller so it's easier to eat. The chicken went everywhere! lol. 

I think my only beef with the pizza is that the crust isn't crispy enough so the toppings make it all soggy and it's hard to hold it to eat. I had to whip out my knife and fork on several occasions. 

Other than that, everything tasted yummy. 

SERVICE - 

Waitress was tentative and pizzas came out fast. Just wonderful.
author: Anthea W.

description:
Yum! Very good. We ordered half black olive, mushroom, jalapeño and the other half with all that plus sausage. The sausage was hard to find. We are confused as to if that's how it normally is or if they gave use half the amount of sausage on the entire pizza?

Loved the sourdough-cornmeal crust. We should have remembered to get extra sauce for dipping the crust.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Goathill generally gets a five-star rating.  It's a local favorite.  The spaghetti dinner is consistently v. good.  Unfortunately, the Sunday crew ripped us off on June 26, 2016.  When you eat in, the serving size is generous - a genuine meal.  When you take-out, the containers are usually packed, though the serving size isn't quite as generous.  Today's take-out was half-packed - a rip off.  

The problem is, as hard as some of us work, and as good a job as we do at our work, it is aggravating to pay good money for subpar performance.  Whether it's the quality or size of a meal, or the service in a restaurant, or any other purchasing experience, there is a reasonable level of satisfaction that needs to be met.  Sorry Goathill:  you lose a star for today's performance.
author: Ted R.

description:
I thought the pizza pan had it out for me. 

Turns out it was my brother taking too many slices off one side, sending the pie careening from the table rack onto my lap with a generous helping of Apple cider. 

The Goat Hill folks replaced the spilt slices and spilt drink for no charge, even without punishment meted on my bro. 

Now I love goats.
author: Zeno H.

description: I had lost count after eating more than 15 slices of pizza on a Monday night. I've never ate that much pizza in one seating in my entire life. Yes the slices is thin but if you joined them together I believe I may have eaten a whole medium size pie! Just $11.95/pp for the Monday night buffet, what a steal! Came at around 6 and was seated within 5 mins. Sat there for an hour and within that hour they had more than 15 different kinds of pizza! The servers came around fast. The one Mexican server with the heavy accent is very friendly and funny, making jokes. The only thing I wasn't really liking were the topping selection. Each pizza had 2-3 toppings if you don't include the cheese. So they were pretty boring. But if you want AYCE pizza this is the place. They also have a free salad bar but some of the lettuce looked wilted.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
I love this place! It's great for kids & groups & the servers that have been here forever like Jose & Miguel are sweethearts:-)

I first found out about Goat Hill because of their Monday All-U-Can-Eat Nights, which are fun & so much easier than trying to agree on toppings with friends who have different ideas about what should go on a pizza. I personally love the salad bar that's included on Monday nights & end up eating more salad than pizza often, which makes for a pretty guilt free pizza dinner. 

I also actually worked here for a while a few years ago & it always feels like family when I come back in. (& from an ethical practice of supporting businesses that treat their employees well standpoint, I can tell u that the owners at goat hill really do care about their employees & take care of them well. )
author: Tracy M.

description:
"The pizza is not BaaaaahhD."  At least I think that's what sound goats make.  I'm not real good with the animal noises, but I know what sound I make when I bang my toe against a piece of furniture in the house; I'll give you a hint, it rhymes with "BUCK"!

Actually Goat Hill has excellent pizza.  I came here with my family, and the first thing I noticed, they use sourdough crust.  Nobody likes sourdough more than me. NOBODY.  To me that's one of the first things I think of in my beloved city besides Dungeness Crab And mission burritos.  

So Goat Hill has the right idea to me.  Pizza authentic to the Sucka Free, specializing in the thin but not too thin sourdough crust.  The dough has a different texture.  Different from any other pizzerias.  A nice change of pace.  No need to try and be like Delfina or Tony's.  Goat Hill got it going on.  And they have all-you-can-eat mondays!?!?  Look out all you two slice eaters!  Big Daddy is gonna come Monday and put a hurt'n on some sourdough pizza.  

Along with the pizza, I had the ravioli entree, some of the salad my sister ordered, and tiramisu.  All were good, but to me, it's all about the pizza.  Potrero Hill has a contender in the pizza making art.
author: Michael L.

description:
Don't bother ordering on their terrible website - the site does not work.  I tried setting up two different profiles and neither worked.  Mind you, I manage an internet startup, so I know my way around.

Called the Potero store and was put on hold for an eternity, then they hung up on me.

Called the SOMA store, was put on hold mid-order and they hung up on me.

Bye-bye Goat Hill.  Hello North Beach Pizza.
author: Scooby S.

description:
Best pizza in town the ingredients are always fresh and the sourdough crust is fantastic  and the Italian sausage sandwich is good and so is the meatball sandwich
Monday night dinner is the best deal in town
author: Stan H.

description: The waitress over heard me complain about under cooked onions.... It was crazy because the manager Jason rushed over! Honestly, the pizza was crazy good! One rouge onion wouldn't have changed it. But the attentiveness of the kitchen assured me of the stellar quality of the vintage pizzeria I was in!
author: David G.

description: For take out goat hill is really fast, the sour dough crust isn't my favorite in the world, but it's solid well put together pizza.   They have some online ordering thing, but it's typically a lot easier to just call them.
author: Michael E.

description:
The best and my new favorite pizza. The crust is thin and nicely crunchy.

The Mediterranean Pizza - 5 stars! Spinach, feta cheese, garlic, and red onions makes a surprisingly divine pizza. The feta cheese brings a different texture.

The Californian - 4.5 stars! It's just a compilation of the following simple toppings: Artichoke, freshly diced tomatos, and garlic. Great combo.

Oh, and nothing like the vegetarian pizza with additional sausage for a complete pizza feast. I'd probably go for the Special Combo instead next time.

Three large specialty pizzas from Goat Hill don't come cheap at $75 but so worth it. Their slice proportions/cuts are a bit inconsistent. You may eat a big slice only to find a slice half that size beside it. Delivery for any amount under $100 worth is an extra $3.50.
author: Samantha L.

description: Love goat hill pizza. They are our family go to spot for great food, kid friendly dining. The staff and service is wonderful.
author: Cathy L.

description:
My bf and I had passed by Goat Hill a few times, and never had a chance to stop in until now. It was actually perfect.  We called in our order, on our way up from the Peninsula, and our pizza was ready, just as we pulled up.  We ordered a large combination pizza, to go.  The pizza was still fresh and hot when we got it.  The sourdough crust was tasty and crisp, and wasn't too sourdoughy (if you know what I mean).  The center of the pie was filled with toppings, to the point where when we each grabbed a slice, on some occasions, the toppings fell off, or we almost lost the inner part of the slice to the box.

My bf and I must have each inhaled 3 slices in a matter of minutes, not only because we were hungry, but because it was good.  It was the perfect way to start our Friday, evening.

At first, we weren't sure if a large would be the right size, but it ended up being perfect.  We were full and still had a few slices left over.
author: Audrey C.

description:
Pizza, price, taste, portion, and store hours, location and customer loyalty program are all solid. 

Pasta is ok but given a high profit margin on pasta there could be an improvement in taste to justify cost or a price reduction to match the current product which is average.
author: Fanshu B.

description:
FINALLY had some fieldwork in the neighborhood and was able to try this place out. I've seen a lot of friends use Goat Hill Pizza as their fundraiser spot, so I've been dying to try it out. Anyways, here's my breakdown of the Porky Pie.

Crust - So good. Crisp crust, nice and chewy center. And if I read the sign correctly, they feature a sourdough crust. That's awesome.

Toppings (bacon, roasted garlic, red onions and garlic creme sauce) - I knew this was going to be a heavy hitter, but WOW... I almost passed out after eating this. Obviously anything with bacon is awesome, but I was impressed with the amount of roasted garlic that this pizza had. Not a roasted garlic spread, but whole cloves. My only wish was that they put some acid (maybe quick pickle the red onions) to cut through the garlic, cream and bacon goodness.
author: Mark L.

description:
Today we had their pizza of the day, which was artichoke, bacon, green onion on sourdough crust.

We enjoyed it a lot.  The service was great. Really prompt.

We walked here after seeing Empty Nesters at the theater Thick House around the corner.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
I finally made Goat Hill Pizza after hearing about it from a friend. I didn't know what to try on my first visit so I ordered the special, asparagus, ham, and artichoke pizza, the crust was thin and the pizza was very good except for the pickled taste of the artichoke that I didn't like.

They have all you can eat pizza and salad on Monday nights, I plan to return so I pick my favorite. It's in a nice and quiet neighborhood.
author: Milly H.

description: Nice service and delicious pizza, even if it's overnight!
author: Tes Y.

description: Tiny pizza place in the middle of Portrero, but it makes some killer pies. The service is awesome and the staff is a lot of fun
author: Tauasa T.

description:
This happened, and I think it's a measure of outstanding service. I am seriously grateful for these folks.

I had worked 12 hours in the hospital, teaching nursing students clinically, and it had been a VERY tough day, involving sending a patient to Hospice, a code, and a  long decompression/discussion afterwards with some heavy-hearted, dedicated students. I was exhausted, both emotionally and physically. I was looking for comfort food, and had always heard that Goat Hill was amazing. 

At 10:01pm, I arrived at Goat Hill Pizza, hoping that there would be *something* - *anything* to eat. They close at 10:00.
Me, thinking: "Crap, I'm tired and they might've just closed." I step in. 
"We're closed." 
Me: "I'm so burnt. Do you have just a slice I can buy?" 
Rachel, who I think is a supervisor, has discussion with a coworker who says, "I don't think we do." Rachel reaches into her two personal pizzas has saved for later and says, "You're a nurse? You need to eat. Long days. And thanks." 
She gave me two slices. My jaw dropped. 
She refused my money. I was floored. 

That simple act of kindness nearly made me cry. I can't even tell you how much it touched me in that moment- I had just gone through an incredibly hellish day, and to have someone *do* that...wow. That speaks volumes to me about the character of the people working there. 

And yes, that pizza was delicious. Apparently, they have gluten-free and dairy free options as well. I cannot wait to return.

Thanks Rachel. Thanks to all of you.
That was incredible. You created a very loyal customer who will be returning as much as possible, and be assured I've told all of my friends about your awesomeness. 

I'm gonna pay that forward like you wouldn't believe.
author: Nicole L.

description: I've been here a few times now and I've never really been excited about the pizza. The atmosphere is lacking. Service has been mediocre. There are much more interesting dining options in the area.
author: Sarah S.

description: Yummy pizza, felt like I was back in NJ with the decor, style and ambiance. There are a lot of flies/insects when we were there
author: Ron M.

description:
Good lunch specials, 2 slices & a salad for less than $10. Good service, nice location, and very friendly staff. Pasta & lasagna dishes are pretty good.

The pizza however is sadly mediocre at best. I form that opinion about the pizza after 4 or 5 visits trying different pies each time. The crust is hard & rather flavorless. The sauce is flavorless & toppings aren't at all impressive. I'd honestly prefer Domino's pizza over Goat Hill's.
author: David C.

description:
Our family of 5 has been dining at Goat Hill Pizza for the past 12 years.  So many happy memories.  The food is always the same, fresh and yummy.  

Our favorite pizza is the Hawaiian, the salads are fresh and the staff friendly.  We like the small neighborhood feel, easy access and the beautiful views before and after dinner.  

The local investments in our children's schools speak to the commitment to our city.  Thank you goat hill!
author: Ken M.

description:
I'd been looking to try this place for a while and I don't think it disappointed. You can get a medium split between two flavors which is totally sufficient for two people and if you're not that hungry, you might even get the joy of cold pizza after.

We tried the bacon garlic one and the goat cheese pesto one both being quite good. The goat cheese isn't super pungent so don't worry if you're not generally in to it. The bacon half was real garlicky and the bulbs of roast garlic mixed in really stepped up the pizza's bad breath good taste game.
author: Misha T.

description:
Decent pizza- nothing to write home about but it's good if you want delivery, 45 min in SF is amazing. Pepperoni and sausage is my favorite. Crust isn't super crispy as I like but it's a good flavor- not just doughy bread like other places. 

They also offer gluten free crusts!

If you live in the SOMA area it's better than any other choice.
author: Kristen M.

description: It's a solid and acceptable pizza. No particular reason to drive there for it but if youre on the street and you have a hankering for pizza, it's acceptable pizza - home style crust with solid amount of ingredients but it's certainly not great, not a great value or anything great. It's a fine neighborhood pizza but definitely not going out of the way.
author: Joe B.

description:
Being pescatarian isn't the best especially when you love meat and so do your friends. However, I decided that for a month, I was going to eat nothing but vegetables and fish. That was quite hard when my friend had decided that we were going to go to Goat Hill pizza and order the Porky Pie (which has bacon, sadly bacon is not a vegetable or fish). Instead, we ordered a pizza with half of it that was pescatarian approved - Mediterranean. That was delicious with the spinach and the feta. 

We sat next to the piano and there was actually a person playing the piano - super cool. I wasn't paying too much attention, but I didn't recognize the songs. It's nice to have live music playing though whilst eating pizza. 

After the month was over, there was another instance where I could try the Porky Pie and it is definitely amazing. Bacon on pizza is like god's food. Try it guys. Sourdough crust makes it San Francisco.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Yummay! The pizza is GREAT! If you're craving some quality pizza & have some $ to spend...GO!

The décor is hilarious though, it has a very cute, low effort, family theme thing going on with random paintings of mixed quality done by children or that look like they are done by children. *MAKE SURE* TO CHECK OUT "SANDMAN DREAM" right in the left corner of the back room...you won't regret it...;)
author: Zhenya S.

description: This is by far one of my favorite pizza places.  If you are a Hawaiian pizza lover and you love garlic get the porky pie with added pineapple.  You are in for a treat!
author: April S.

description:
Came in for the Monday night neighbourhood all you can eat, which costs $12.99 per person. They bring around 10-15 different pizzas around per hour and you take a slice if you want to try that pizza. You can also go to the unlimited salad bar if you want. 

It's great. The pizza is tasty and relatively inventive in some cases. The bases are not too heavy and the crusts are nice and puffy. 

The staff are pleasant, nice, pretty friendly and polite. 

I'd definitely recommend Monday nights to anyone.
author: Emma R.

description: Good sourdough pizza around the neighborhood. Make sure to check in and get free bread.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
So many reviews for Goat Hill, so little time to read them . . . sigh . . .

What more can be added?  This:  A consultant just flew out to my job this week, she's from the Midwest.  And the thought came to me, and I told it to her:  It's Monday night, and if you want to see the real San Francisco, don't go to Fisherman's Wharf, go to Goat Hill.  And I described the pizza, the all-you-can-eat, the scene.  She didn't go, she had to take a nap.

But the more I thought about that exchange, the more I realized that Goat Hill's Family Night is an authentic San Francisco experience.  You park on the street and traverse a hill, and 18th Street can be steep.  You walk into a narrow old building crowded with locals.  The skyscrapers of the Financial District offer a great view if the sun's up, or shine their beautiful lights if it's nighttime.   The pizza?  They do bring around old standbys like pepperoni and ham & pineapple, but also "only in California" combos like spinach & feta cheese and barbecued chicken & sun-dried tomatoes.  I once took my sister-in-law and my wife's BFF, and they loved the experience.  Unfortunately, we parked *down* 18th Street . . . they don't have hills this steep in Southeast Texas . . .

Now, about the pizza:  Small but delicious.  Perfect for the discriminating taste-tester.  Creative combos.  But sometimes it backfires on them:  one waitress was begging people to take this unappetizing `za that was requested, and he was the only one who ate it!  Might have been liver & onions or something.  I set my record here - 20 slices in one sitting - but a long-time waitress told me that the most she saw was 30.  Oh maaaaan . . .

Of all the restaurants in The City, Goat Hill is our favorite, and Monday night is our time to go.  It'll become one of your favorites too.
author: Ron L.

description: Pretty darn delish sourdough pizza! The Hawaiian slice was delicious because it balanced out the tangy crust. Plain cheese slice was pretty good and pepperoni slice was too salty. 3.50-4.00 for a specialty slice. Next time, I would order a full Hawaiian pie to go.
author: Jules W.

description:
Really great pizza! Been coming here at least 15 years and their pizza is still great. Mondays are slammed but it's all you can eat!! Love this local restraunt, beautiful views of the city from the back dining area. Plus they give you crayons and placemats while you wait for the pizza! Great place for a date.

And Ben w's review is not even relevant to the food. That douche probably never ate here.
author: J B.

description: Great local food on the hill. Fresh ingredients. Definitely an institution of Potrero Hill!
author: Kirk D.

description: Service was great. But the spaghetti meatballs very dry. Ordered some pizza plenty of sourdough but it lacked the toppings. Highlight of the dinner was the lasagna. It seemed to be freshly made and extra cheesy.
author: Sergio T.

description: Ordered simple takeout of 3 items. Pizza, salad bowl with garlic bread, and spaghetti with meatballs tonight. Picked it up quickly but realized spaghetti and meatballs wasn't there so went back in. Mean lady said it wasn't ready so husband waited for 20 minutes and noticed she left her shift. Asked the guy and he said it was there the whole time!  No apology or complimentary item. And guess what?  Got home and missing garlic bread. They lost our business.
author: Becca D.

description:
BEST pizza and service SF has to offer!!!  Love this place.  Fresh ingredients, nice, friendly and gorgeous staff.  Awesome deals on wine by the glass - that actually taste yummy.  GIANT salads with the works.  Pizza is legit, nice thick crust, fresh meat, yummy cheese.  Great little "hill" location in Portrero Hill.  This place hits the spot on so many levels.  Go GOAT HILL PIZZA!!! 

Ohh you can color while you wait for your food too.
author: Jana S.

description:
Solid pizza choice in Potrero. My roommie and I had a lazy Saturday watching Breaking Amish and were in the mood for some 'za. Goat Hill was recommended by multiple good-eaters, and we decided to try it out. 

We got half Hawaiian and half pepperoni. Fresh ingredients, sourdough crust. We also got the hot wings with blue cheese dressing (per our request) and happened to have some Crystal hot sauce in the house so we lathered them up and they were off the hook. I should have asked for them to be well-done, and advise that you do the same. They weren't under cooked or anything, just would have been much better with a little crisp. 

The dude I ordered with was very friendly and we had a nice delivery lady. Though our food choices were very basic, Goat Hill did not let me down which will bring me back for more.
author: Crystal C.

description: Sourdough Pizza Crust is the Best!!! A friend saw this place on the food channel of places to eat while in San Francisco and let me tell you, this place will not dissapoint. Great Location up in the Hills very nice area.   Looks like a house from the outside.  They sell beer and wine, Pasta, salads and Pizza!!! Pizza was the best i've had in a very long time.  I had the Porky Pie, A Ham Pizza and a Pepporrini.  Plenty of space for a large family!  So far one of my top 3 pizza places that i've tried!
author: Rick M.

description:
Double Date Dinner Rules:

1)  There is a list of prohibited conversation topics at dinner. 
2)  Video games are at the top of this list.
3)  The women are allowed to slap their respective men if they venture into nerd territory.

With these rules established, our dinner at Goat Hill Pizza was very pleasant!

This homey restaurant is very neighborhood-y and kid friendly as evidenced by the colorful drawings that decorated the walls and the cutouts of the goats that helped us decide between an "X-Laaarge" and "Laaarge."  (Of course we went X-Laaarge.)  While deciding, we drank the vino that my galpal and her hubby had thoughtfully brought (corkage $8). 

Since we were at Goat Hill Pizza, it made sense to get Goat Cheese on our pizza.  "Hilda's Favorite" (goat cheese, pesto, and tomatoes) is now Amy's Favorite too though I wished the pesto was more garlicky.  On the other half of our pizza, we went "Chicken Florentine" (grilled chicken, spinach, and mushrooms).  I'm not a fan of chicken as a pizza topping but everyone else yummed it up. 

BF loves sourdough so he was loving the crisp, chewy crust.  Galpal's pizza pet peeve is not enough sauce and she was not peeved.  Galpal's hubby loved that our pizza, plus some garlic bread, and a half order of spaghetti and meatballs only cost the four of us around $50.

We'll definitely be baaack! 

(All-you-can-eat-pizza on Monday nights?  Yes please!)
author: Amy C.

description:
Excellent pizza and service! I love the sourdough crust, and the mozzarella + tomato and basil is an excellent starter. The fun artwork / placemat drawings of goats are really neat to look at, too -- they cover the walls in the dining area and restrooms. 

The view from the window tables in the back of the restaurant is lovely; it's fun to watch the fog or the sunset.
author: Katie M.

description:
A neighborhood gem all the way. And you can place a delivery order online wha wha?!

This is the place where you can bring the whole family and grab a pitcher and pizza after a baseball game.  Or, sidle up to one of the pews in front of the T.V. to watch a game. The staff has always, always been very welcoming and the walls usually have a pretty nice rotation of local artists young and old alike. :)

Pretty bummed they did away with their punch card reward program. It was always such a nice feeling to walk in with a stack of single-punched cards and walk out with a FREE X-Large pie, just signed up for the new program, so we'll see how that compares.

....been coming here regularly for 6 years now and they have yet to disappoint.
author: CeeLo L.

description:
Once again, great pizza and was worth the walk up a huge SanFrancisco hill.

I was dreaming of this, and it satisfied completely!
author: Jim N.

description:
If you own a large pizza chain in San Francisco (home to possibly the largest gaggle of code monkeys on the planet) and you can't get your website to work you really aren't playing the game at even a 1st grade level. Also - your "e-commerce" site is hosted by GoDaddy... because everyone loves helping businesses that partner with the worst website on the entire internet. NO SOUP FOR YOU

Also - you're pizza is pretty meh.
author: Ben W.

description:
Since moving here, this has been my number one pizza place. Maybe that's because it's a few blocks away or maybe it's because of the thick sourdough crust. Whatever the reason, the time to go is Monday night when it's AYCE pizza. Not only is there a salad bar included, but the chefs throw together all sorts of combinations that are off the menu. My tip: Don't eat all the crust so you can save room for maximum variety. Corkage is also only $5.

After rejecting the servers who "just have" pepperoni, you start to feel bad and hope they don't take it personally that they got saddled with a boring pie. Don't feel bad though: the employees are generally thick skinned and can handle your pizza put downs. There's one employee in particular that always has a smile on his face and a song in his heart. He makes it all worthwhile.

This place is consistent and has the right blend of ingredients to cheese ratio. It's refreshing to have a few places that have gone against the Neapolitan style (which I do love too) so you can actually hold a piece in one hand. It can get a bit pricey when ordering a full pizza, but the taste is great and well worth checking out.
author: Brandon K.

description: I am a NY'er and Italian American so pizza is a tough subject for me. But this place rocks. Yummy pizza with a sourdough crust. Makes me feel like I have adapted west and am finding my groove. Try it, you'll love it too.
author: The Style R.

description:
I normally like Goat hill a lot but tonight they were incredibly rude regarding delivery and hung up on me while I was trying to talk to them on the phone.  AS IN MID SENTENCE.  I am surprised as I have been calling them for the past two years ordering pizza for my entire class and other groups.   I think there is no excuse for rude behavior like that.  What pizza delivery restaurant stops delivering at 10 pm anyway? 

Are they aware this is San Francisco? I'll bet they get about 40 calls a night after 10.  If anyone in this neighborhood delivers later I hope they take all goat hill's business. 

There is no reason to be rude to people who have given you so much support

Goodbye goat hill from my whole department.
author: Dave T.

description:
My date was starving and we had half an hour to kill before the Andrew Jackson Jihad show started at Bottom of the Hill. He looked up close-by places on Yelp and because I am a lazy fuck, we drove to Goat Hill Pizza and found parking right next to it. Yipee. 

It took forever to get seated. We got the Mediterranean pizza. The crust is awesome. I l love thin crust pizza! The pizza tasted absolutely horrible after the show though but I was never a fan of cold pizza. I can't believe they have all you can eat pizza on Mondays! That is a pretty good deal considering their pizzas are slightlyyy pricey to begin with. 

I don't know if they have a regular desert menu but they had one of those commercial freezers you would find in a 7-11 full of ice cream that I noticed as soon as I entered. I couldn't leave without getting a Drumstick omnomnom.
author: Tiffany V.

description: Dropped by because of the sign... Great price for pizza slices... After we ordered.. They reheated it right away and tasted great.... Didn't realize that they made it with sour dough bread... Yum
author: Sandra S.

description:
Goat Hill is my favorite pizza parlor in San Francisco. The food here is nothing short of freakin spectacular: classic pizza piled high with fresh ingredients, baked to perfection. If you want to get a killer slice in SF, Goat Hill is it.

Pro tip: Neighborhood Night is on Mondays, with rodizio-style all-you-can-eat slices and salad bar--you get to try each type of pizza on the menu, plus some combinations the kitchen throws in for funsies.
author: Sabrina V.

description:
This review is solely for their weekly Monday Neighborhood Night AYCE pizza. I swear the price has gone up a bit over the past couple of years, but for about $13-14 you can eat as much of their soft but crunch sourdough pizzas and salad bar as you'd like. The servers come out with different pizza types, tell you what it's got, and you can choose to accept or refuse a slice. This cycle repeats, and repeats, and repeats, depending on how much pizza you can eat. This cycle, or time it takes for the servers to cone around to your table, can sometimes take a long time (especially if you're with a large group).

All in all, damn good pizza with their signature sourdough crust, and totally worth it for the Monday nights.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I recently went for the All You Can Eat Pizza on Mondays.

Not disappointed.

Plently of variety of hot and delicious pizzas, not to mention a salad bar too.  Also, they take requests of pizza choices you would like.

A good place to get you Pizza fix.

Good for a group of people too.
author: Daniel P.

description: Really great sourdough crust pizza!! The place is pretty small & the inside is nothin fancy, but the pizza is worth it.
author: Rick M.

description: We four people went there on a Friday night when travelling to SF. This place was very crowded, but we didn't have to wait in line. We ordered chicken wings and salad for starters and an extra large pizza. Chicken wings were a little spicy and very tasty. As for the pizza, the extra large size was so filling that we took four pieces home. The meat lover's was good, but Californian was not delicious at all.
author: Liz J.

description:
I walk in on a busy - ish Friday night.
Hostess/ Waitress: "Do you have a reservation"
Me: "No"
Hostess/ Waitress "how many in your party?"
Me: "8"
Hostess / Waitress "ha, good luck!" and walks away....

That was probably one of the RUDEST conversations I've had with a hostess ever at a restaurant. She just walked away after practically laughing in my face. The only reason I am not giving this place 1 star is that the next waiter was much more kind and was able to find us a table within 10 minutes, which meant this place wasn't THAT crowded as the first person has made it.  The second guy was nice and made sure we were taken care of. Service otherwise was pretty slow, we had to ask a couple times for our check, water, etc. The waiter looked disinterested and looked annoyed when taking our orders.  Our "free" yelp check in garlic bread never came. Pizza came in about 20 minutes which is standard. 

Food: 3/5
Combination: ($27.95 for XL) - think everything pizza
Dough - crunchy and gooey
Sauce - Not enough
Toppings: Salty!
Overall, as a comparison, Costco does a better job on the "combo" for less than half the price. 

Porky Pie: bacon, lots of garlic and onions. Dracula's worst nightmare and a good reason to not go around kissing people.  It's a sauceless pizza. It felt that it was good, but it's hard to eat more than one slice since the flavors were so strong.

I might consider coming here again, but after the experience with the service I'm disappointed. The food was ok, but the slow aloof service coupled with the rude hostess really doesn't make this place worth coming to again.
author: Christine B.

description: The best pizza in the Bay Area and beyond.  Went here yesterday and a number of times In the past years ago.  It's consistently good!  They now are gluten free conscious and there gf pizza is amazing too.  They also surprisingly had a bigger size gf pizza which most places seem to just do small or mini gf pizza. Yum
author: Paloma M.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza also sells soups, sammies, salads and the like. forget about  everything else except for the pizza. the gotcha is the sourdough crust that is so addicting, especially for sourdough lovers like me.

eats:
 pizza of the day (m,17.25) feta cheese, sausage, red onions
-all ingredients fresh
-liquified cheese on top, taste totally different when cooled
-crusty sourdough with soft middle

crumbs:
-prep time 15 minutes
-small place, expect a wait at peak times.
-definitely an unique pizza, easily could become a fav.
author: Victor G.

description: Keep moving. Nothing to see here. This is just another mediocre place stuffed into a city that used to lack a quality slice but now has several good options. Why would you want to pay for overpriced, wannabe artisanal pizza when you can do better. These crust-heavy imitation gourmand slices aren't terrible, they just aren't good. Especially not for the price.
author: Casey C.

description: good pizza. I need to go back to see if its great. Like any other place in the city its small so get useto it. I like that there is someone always there to serve you and your questions. I am looking forward to going back to see if I could try their all you could eat pizza on mondays. I didnt have the patience this last monday. And since I dont eat meat I really have to be patient. They do have pizza for me but, I do have to wait.
author: Ray R.

description:
Excellent pizza, friendly service!  We went in at 9:15 on Sunday night - just 45 minutes before close - and they were pleasant, patient, and food was as good as one would expect any time during the day.  

It's on the expensive side, but it was completely memorable and delicious!
author: Jeff P.

description: Great pizza restaurant in the heart of Potrero Hill with a lovely view of the city from the window seats.  I went here on a Sunday and we got a Hawaiian pizza and lunch special (soup and salad).  Very casual atmosphere and great food.  I'm looking forward to trying this for little gem for dinner.
author: Tanichka B.

description:
Another skeptical suggestion by my girlfriend on a Monday night... "Goat Hill Pizza" she said. My preemptive notions were by far surpassed. Great service and unusually pleasing combinations in the toppings department.    The smaller guy with the pony tail was an absolute riot, thank you for the pleasant experience my friend."Fantastic!" I loudly screamed at him. 

Without a doubt I will be back. Well done Goat Hill, well done.

If i had to recommend a slice itd be the jalapeno bacon apple sausage. Nouveau yet  a classic.
author: DeVince C.

description: Ordered half mediterranian and half hilda's and couldnt decide which half I liked better, they were both delicious.  If you like thin crust pizza with lots of flavor, order here. Delivery took about 45-1hr but it was worth the wait.
author: Natalie S.

description:
I've been to GHP a few times for the all you can eat Monday and have had a different experience each time. There can be a long wait if you get there late and there's a better variety early on so shoot for early evening. Salad bar is uninspired but to be expected at a family style pizza joint. The pizza itself is good, close enough to great. But the selling point for me is the variety and inventiveness. It seems they give the cooks a lot of creative control over the types of pizzas so I always leave there having tried 10 or so types that I really enjoyed. I also invariably end up eating far more than $10.95 worth of food.

   I give them a few points for service as well. They generally aim to get everyone enough pizza, which can be tough when the place is packed and you only have but so many slices on a pan. Got there near the end once and was mistakenly told there would be a lot more pizzas coming out. A pair walked in 5 minutes later and a different host instructed them to not pay for unlimited because they wouldn't get their money's worth. When I confronted her she apologized and offered to have the chef make personalized pizzas at the end to ensure I got a sufficient amount. Can't lose with that kind of customer service. I'll definitely go again.
author: Donnie M.

description: Where do I start?!! This is the worst restaurant in the entire Bay Area. The pizza is horrible. The service is awful! If I could give any less stars I would. I was so disappointed when I came here. The reviews looked pretty good so we were really excited to try it out. We sat at a table for about 10-15 minutes before we were ever served our water. Then we ordered a couple pizzas and it took 1 hour yes 1 hour to finally get our pizza! When we were there 2 different people came in for take out that had had their orders completely screwed up. Then we we finally got out food no one came to ask how it was. We had to grab our own to go boxes and the bill for two pizzas was like $70. Keep in mind there were only like 3 tables in the whole place during this time... Will never ever go back and I hope you don't waste your time either.
author: Mallory R.

description:
They don't accept credit cards. Boooooo.

I mean, there is the word "pizza" in the name, and I chose a sandwich. This is only because my co-worker who pretty much only eats pizza and burgers, said that the sandwiches are awesome there.

We went for lunch and I ordered the sandwich lunch which includes a choice of soup or salad for $8.95 (the online menu lists it as $8.50).
I chose the Hot Italian over the Meatball because of a previous Yelp review. 2 of our friends ordered the meatball sandwiches that had 3 humongous meatballs; it looked delicious!

My Hot Italian was delicious, although, I wish that I ordered cheese with it, and I wish that it was bigger than delivered.

The restaurant seemed clean. Parking was okay, only because we got lucky. Let's see how the pizza tastes next time before I update this review. Sourdough crust sounds really good.
author: Rosie M.

description: I prefer thin crust pizza, but for a thicker crust it was really good pizza.  The toppings were fun and creative.  I forget the name of the we ordered, but the goat cheese was awesome.  We had a party of 10.  They were accommodating and pretty quick to produce our order.  3 extra large and 2 salads fed all 10 of us.
author: Justin C.

description: Great concept with the thin crust sourdough. Have been a regular for couple years now. Very kid friendly and they have a huge seating area in the back which gives a nice intimate touch. I've had couple instances where orders were mixed up, deliveries were missing items etc. but for the most part the staff were courteous and accommodating. Will continue to go back!
author: Rajiv R.

description:
I'll admit, I've only gone on Mondays for the all you can eat pizza and salad bar. This review is in no way reflective of anything that happens here between Tuesday and Sunday.

With that said, let's talk about Mondays at Goat Hill:

1) It's not your typical AYCE pizza joint. Instead of a buffet line, the servers consistently stop by your table to drop off small slices. Think of it as dim sum for pizza. It works really well because they have a lot of different pies.

2) It gets very crowded so either come early or come late. I usually have a drink or two at Thee Parkside before trudging up the hill for a late night feast. I think they stop seating at 9PM, but I could be wrong.

3) Total cost for unlimited pizza and salad is $10.95. Not bad, and they have reasonably priced pitchers of good brew. One more thing to note: If you go on Monday, you can only do AYCE. They won't let you order from the normal menu, so don't bring friends with small stomachs.

Aside from Anchor Brewing, this is possibly the only reason to climb Potrero Hill (I used to live there so I can say this). So, in the rare case that you didn't have a gluttonous enough weekend, stop in on a Monday night and feed your face.
author: Nick K.

description:
My go to for pizza delivery... hands down the best!

The salads and meatballs are also the best I've had!!!

Everything is just so fresh, hearty, and delicious...
author: Nolan M.

description: I have been to serveral art openings at Goat Hill Pizza and their pizzas are all terrific. I like the art in the back room and the fact that they support artists.
author: Marty H.

description: Glorified domino's. Not sure how or why this got 4 stars. It's fine for what it is but considering the price I won't be back. If this is the pizza/wings you want, just order domino's for 1/2 the price.
author: Rob S.

description: It's really hard to find parking in this area, which is why I can't say much about the service- my food was already there when I arrived (thank you, sis!). She did mention that the waitress double-triple checked to find something without garlic for me, which happened to be a salad and a vegetarian sandwich, which means that they pre-make all their food :(
author: Anna P.

description:
I suspect the client base of this establishment has only fast-food pizza chains to compare this place against. There's no other way to explain the inflated rating and rave reviews.

The pizza crust is interesting, I've had it before at other pizza joints and it's a welcome change from the norm. However, beyond the crust they aren't doing anything special. The toppings are all run of the mill and their cheese/sauce options are standard.

Places such as extreme pizza at the very least give you some weird combinations which are fun to try. Goat hill offers typical choices and fails to improve upon them or make their own interpretation. The ingredients were average, prices were not in line with what you get, and this place is yet another victim of overhype by foodie fanatics.
author: Tony S.

description:
Why are people who hate pizza allowed to run a pizzaria?

Ok, I am assuming they hate pizza, or else they just don't
eat their own cooking, because yeesh, this is ho-hum dreadful.
Like Domino's or Papa John, it tastes like something but doesn't 
quite taste like *food*. I'm going with supremely low-quality 
ingredients as the best theory. I live nearby, have had plenty
of chances to see that this is consistently bad, not a fluke.

Speaking of consistent: the wings here are consistently slimy, 
undercooked unseasoned florescent yellow fatty globs of awfulness. 
I know this is consistent because a friend regularly buys these for takeout
just expecting to put them in the oven for 20 minutes so they become 
edible. Yeah, it's a pizza place, but they did put these on the menu, and 
you gotta wonder is management tasting the food?
author: bobo n.

description:
Their pizza was god but not exceptional
The service was slow but it does have room to accommodate large party
author: Sophia L.

description:
Wasn't impressed after coming in with high expectations due to Yelp; no idea why there's big praise here. 

My girlfriend and I had a dinner salad to start--pretty solid but a little over priced for the size and the ingredients.

Split a medium pie--half porky pie and half Hilda's special. The whole pie had a pool of grease in the middle. The porky pie didn't really have a lot of bacon and, as one other review mentioned, just had an "off" flavor to it that I can't really describe. 

The Hilda's was pretty decent but nothing to write home about. 

If you want great pizza, go to Tony's in North Beach. I've had worse, for sure, but I can't see myself going back to this place.
author: Steve B.

description: First time here and I just LOVEEEEEE the Pizza and the Wings I had there.. Delicious.  Also, everyone there was so friendly and always made sure that our cups weren't empty.  I will definitely be coming back here..
author: SD D.

description:
We got Hilda's favorite, which was a gorgeous pie of goat cheese, tomatoes, and the freshest looking pesto I've ever seen on a pizza. Usually the pesto on pizza is more colorful oil than flavor, but this one really tasted like happy basil times. We added chicken to it, which I was indifferent about.

Our other pie was a Mediterranean, which was clumps of spinach, feta cheese, and onions. I definitely preferred the Hilda's since it stood out more, but this was a solid pizza with the same awesome sourdough crust.

Both pizzas were inhaled after delivery, so I'm sure it'd be even better straight out of the oven, all bubbly and such.

Their all-you-can-eat pizza Monday nights sound amazing!
author: Kevin L.

description: Mmmmm, I met a friend here because we hadn't tried the pizza in San Fran yet.  And, I was pleased.  The salad was yummy and the pizza was too.  I think you could easily split a small pizza.  Toppings were fresh and tasty too.  And, good selection of drinks.
author: Nikki A.

description: Good pizza options. We have usually ended up here because of the long wait at the french bistro next door. The views are nice and the service is quick.
author: Alifiya K.

description: I like goat hill Pizza.  It is ok as pizza goes.  Not terribly imaginative, but tasty.  Unfortunately they are very select about who they deliver too.  I live in a rapidly gentrifying area of the city called Silver Terrace, where the homes are currently selling in the 1 million dollar range.  I am a white man in his early 60's and I have lived here for 16 years in harmony with blacks, hispanics, and asian families from all walks of life.  Last night I just wanted to treat myself to a nice night with pizza and TV so I gave them a call.  Goat Hill on Connecticut is just a 5 minute drive from my house, but they told me that the wouldn't come to MY area as it wasn't in their delivery range, even though they traveled much further in the other direction.  My neighbors on Maddux Avenue are kind, hardworking families with good jobs and lovely homes.  Apparently we are just not good enough for Goat Hill.
author: Clay S.

description:
My brother and I came here wanting a quick bite to eat.  You can either choose take out or dine in.  We opted for dine in since there was a sufficient time before closing.

Pizza comes in either small, medium, large, or x-large sizes.  We ordered the Mediterranean pizza, medium size.  The pizza was dropped off in an acceptable amount of time, and we both proceeded to devour some delicious tasting pizza!  It was quite good!  Another good thing about this place I observed was the service.  The server that helped us was friendly, polite, and efficient. And when she saw we couldn't eat another bite, she kindly offered us a "to go" box.

Bottom Line:  Good service.  Good pizza.
author: Michael C.

description:
Just because a facility has been around forever it does not make them good.   I have NO IDEA what the big deal is about this place.  I live in Potrero hill and have gone there a dozen times and everytime we go there we have the same experience.   For one their wait staff is absolutely terrible and unprofessional.   The last two times our waitress just forgot two simple requests ( i.e for the pizza to be cut into squares and second for some side of ranch).   The place just does not smell clean.  The front room where the entrance is- the very last table is under an air conditioning unit with spider webs, roaches and gross mold on it.    

The ingredients are not Fresh and the wait staff is absolutely terrible.  We could not find our waitress last time to close the tab and get the hell out of there and our waitress was out front smoking a cigarette, then she came back, DID NOT wash her hands and started handling food and finally after another reminder brought our check.  

If I could give this place NO STARS I would,  there are many better Pizza places in town.
author: DocDarien D.

description:
Didn't get the opportunity to try the food since the customer service was so bad! Strike ONE, when you have 3 people behind the counter, two of which looked like they were too busy counting change to look up is not a good sign. Strike TWO occured when one gal finally looked up and asked how many and I replied two please. She quickly blurted out just sit anywhere and went back to counting her pennies. 
Strike THREE, when the server came by to tell that us that the table we chose is reseved for four people. I could understand this If the place was crowded, but aside from two other couples in the joint it was completly empty. 
This was enough to walk out. The only thing that Goat Hill Pizza has going for itself is it's location, certainly not for the food nor customer service!
author: marcus c.

description: Very good, high end pizza with high quality ingredients.  They claim sourdough crust, but it's not very sour..in fact, tastes just like regular crust.  They should offer a super sour sourdough and I'd be hooked for life.  Anyway, very good pizza, lots of toppings.  Parking sucks, and if you do find a spot you will either hike the 45 degree incline coming or going to your car.  For some reason, I really like the lasagna here.  It's not horrible expensive and it's incredible.  It comes still bubbling from the oven, so you will wait a good 10 minutes before it's even close to being cooled off enough to eat.  Service is good.  Pizza, especially for delivery, is very expensive. It's great for special occasions, but on a regular basis, Round Table is just fine at 2/3 the price.
author: Ken P.

description:
FAN-freakin-TASTIC! Came here tonight for the first time and was fortunate to partake in their $12 Monday night/Family Night, all you can eat pizza. DAMN! 

My friends and I got our money's worth for sure! The pizza just kept coming out, everything from tasty classic pepperoni to some great combos... many included garlic (lots of it), pesto, salami, artichoke, mushroom, chicken, sausage, garlic sauces, etc. I did not have one slice that I regretted. Oh, and there was a small salad bar too... but really, save yourself for the pizza. 

The staff were all super friendly and didn't make you feel like a complete fat-ass after eating slice after slice ;) 

We agreed to make Monday Night pizza a once a month event, so we'll for sure be back. And I now have a great go-to pizza place to order from on other nights. 

p.s. we arrived around 6:20 and only had to wait less than 5 minutes for a table, however when we left just before 8 the entrance was pretty crowded and it looked like there was quite the wait.
author: Amanda F.

description:
i've heard about goat hill pizza in the past in regards to their ayce night...but i just can't eat that much pizza anymore!  one or two slices and i'm done...

i got an e-mail from scoutmob offering 50% off and jumped on it the same day.  they're known for their sourdough crust and couldn't wait to give it a try.  

i don't know if it's because of scoutmob or they are always crazy busy...but the service was absolutely horrible!  we waited super long for everything...water, beer, and they even served our food without utensils and napkins!  we had to flag down our server before we could even touch our bruschetta.

btw, the bruschetta was the best i have ever had.  seriously, the bread to bruschetta mix ratio was perfect...super flavorful...and i was really sad when it was all gone.  i was so desperate to try it as it was sitting on our table that i cavemanned it and ate a piece before we got napkins and forks.  

the pizza, on the other hand, was disappointing.  the sourdough crust wasn't anything special...it didn't taste like sourdough.  the sauce wasn't inspiring...and the toppings were just typical.  we ordered the porky pig or something along those lines...the pizza tasted much better the 2nd day!  

i do like how the kitchen and pizza oven are in full view...the restaurant is cute and has so much potential.  they even had someone playing the piano...good ambiance.

i just wish the pizza and service were better!
author: Jen W.

description:
Really good deal for the Monday night pizza buffet. Love how pizzas aren't just sitting around under a heat lamp, but servers actually bring around the pizzas so they're relatively fresh (not so much towards the end of the night as people start getting full & picky, which is unavoidable).

Salad bar = meh. Not too many choices, not super fresh. From what I can remember off the top of my head: lettuce, chickpeas, kidney beans, american cheese, onions, olives, tomato slices, a few dressing choices.

Crust = inconsistent. Some were really hard, some were more dough-y. I really like corn meal crust in general and when we got  a fresh slice done well, it had just the right amount of crunch with a soft almost gooey inside. But many slices were stale (inevitable), and some and a crust that were almost burnt (that IS avoidable).

Toppings = a lot of the same ingredients in different permutations. Many had garlic (so strong! loved it), pesto, cream, mushroom, tomato, artichoke, pineapple, spicy peppers. Anything with pork (ham, salami, pepperoni) were all WAY too salty. The spicy ones were legitimately spicy.

Pizzas we tried (ranked by my taste):

Goat cheese tomato pesto
Sausage pesto tomato goat cheese
Tomato basil garlic
Pesto roasted garlic & tomato
Onion garlic
Cheese
Artichoke feta tomato
Cream & mushroom 
Bacon roasted garlic & basil
Green onion/ red onion pineapple
Mushroom
Tomato & cream sauce
Salami pepper mushroom
Chicken pesto black olive
Green olives, feta, tomato, onion
Spicy Hawaiian
Ham pineapple
Pepperoni
Ham & cream sauce
Grene & black olives, artichoke hearts
(no, I do not have superhuman memory)
