(yes, I was the Yelp nerd taking notes during dinner)
author: Ziyan C.

description: Visited mid afternoon. Loved this place. Mellow and old school. Pizza was excellent and crust was so perfect it held up to next day. Definitely staying in my address book. Planning on trying the All-you-can-eat Monday night to see how it holds up.
author: Alicia Z.

description: Very good pizza.  Service was OK.  The waitress was excellent but the person who served us the food brought it to the wrong table first and then gave us the wrong check.  Maybe she was new.  Overall a great place to stop for good pizza.
author: Natalie P.

description:
The tables were very squished together to the point our server could not even get to us.  We actually couldn't hear him half the time since he couldn't even get up to our table to give us our drinks.

Pizza: not bad, not the best I've had, nothing fantastic though.
author: Omar L.

description:
This place has pretty high ratings! But I thought it was just okay. Seemed overpriced to me. Maybe because they're in the nice Portrero Hill area with good food so they can up their prices?

Salad bowl: waitress actually got our order wrong.... we wanted the caprese salad and asked how big it was and then she started talking about the salad bowl so I guess she wrote that down? When it came though, it looked pretty good so we were like, whatever. It was $8.60 but the salad was huge. Could be a meal for two. Ingredients were pretty fresh but nothing to blow me out of the water? Standard salad.

Pizza: Got HIlda's Favorite. Pesto, goat cheese. $16 for a small sized pizza (about 6 smallish-medium slices)... seemed kinda overpriced since the pizza looked kinda flat and .. standard.. then again, it's only pizza right? I've had better still.
The pesto or goat cheese didn't wow me. But it was what you'd expect. They say they make their own sourdough crust? I guess it was pretty good (the crust) but I wouldn't rave about it?

Overall: decent pizza if you're craving it and in the area but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.
However, service here is great since it's a small place. The people who work here are really nice. Made me feel kinda bad that I didn't like the food more.
author: Emily C.

description: We had the Mediterranean pizza and it was absolutely delicious. I loved the raw onion and whatever chunks of cheese were on it. We chose this place after a random Google search and decided to take a chance. When we walked in there were no other guests so I got a little nervous but decided to go with it and it was worth it. Also great view if you sit in the little spot by the door.
author: Ashley B.

description: Great pizza and atmosphere! We needed a place for a quick bite before a night of dancing at St. Gregory's of Nyssa, and this filled the bill admirably. The salad and pizza were very good.
author: Barbara S.

description: Decent pizza (I had Hilda's with extra jalepenos) with good crust and quality toppings. Service and location was also good. Would love to be able to dine outside to enjoy the beautiful weather on Potrero Hill, but there was no outdoor seating.
author: DV P.

description: One of the better pizza places I've tried in San Francisco. Pies are a little bit pricey, but about standard for good eating in Potrero.
author: Jake S.

description:
The sourdough pizza crust is what makes this place unique.  It does stand out, and it's a different experience.  The sauce and toppings are what you'd expect.

Unfortunately, to me, it just doesn't work.  Pizza is supposed to be classic.  If you go here, don't go expecting normal pizza: it's a spinoff.
author: Kenji M.

description:
Monday night pizza buffet is totally worth coming to Goat Hill Pizza. It's simply the best pizza buffet I've experienced. 

At $12, you get unlimited pizza and a salad bar. You wouldn't expect much from a pizza buffet, but Goat Hill Pizza does it right. They bring around their fresh made pizza and give you slices, instead of leaving them out under a red light. It's kind of like a pizza dim sum, for comparison. Also, they don't seem to make "worse" pizza for the all you can eat night. 

As far as taste goes, their dough is thin and crispy, just the way I like it. The crust is good too, but I chose not to eat too many of mine to save space for the more delicious parts. I was particularly fond of the pepperoni and mushroom pizza. The ones I did not find good was the chicken garlic pizza. I thought it would be a nice white pizza with subtle flavors, but it was actually kind of over the top and too heavy tasting. I was also weirded out that they didn't really have sausages on their pizza, but they had ground beef on them. The ground beef wasn't exactly seasoned any way, so it just tasted like cooked ground beef. 

If you have a large group on monday(over 10), you may need to get split up. It gets pretty packed during the peak time.
author: Julie K.

description: This is a staple for me in this neighborhood gem! Great slices for great prices and the neighborhood night on Mondays is great!
author: Jessica G.

description:
I don't understand why this pizza joint is so spectacular.  I mean it is good pizza, but it's not OMG good.  Just a good corner pizza place.  We ordered a large Pepperoni pizza and it was fine (not too greasy). The buffalo wings were nothing to write home about.  The free cheesy bread you get for checking in were good (heck, they were free).

Service was not responsive, we sat in the back and were basically forgotten (slow water, slow ordering, and slow receipts).  I had to get up and wave down our waitress three times.
author: Madison W.

description: Goat Hill was a great Yelp find! It had some tasty varieties of pizza and yet, the original was still mouthwatering. The free cheesy garlic bread that comes with the check-in isn't bad either! We went on a Saturday night and there were literally all families here, so it was loud. We got to sit at a "date spot" in the corner so that made the experience quite pleasant, but I'd steer away from here if you want something romantic or even somewhere without kids running around and yelling (atmosphere). Maybe order for takeout?
author: Kerry G.

description:
Best Pizza in SF.

The Pepperoni and Sausage was delicious.  We also tried Hilda's Favorite (goat cheese, pesto, tomato) which rocked.  My wife liked this combo better.

We also tried the Soup of the Day...Cream of Asparagus.  Unbelievably good.  It was heavy with the cream...but had great flavor.
author: Zoran L.

description:
I dunno, its alright Iguess,  Its pizza. For me pizza's just one of those kinda things: I don't want it hella nasty (IE Dominoes style) but I don't dig it served up with too much fancery either  (IE I'm not gonna order it at an $$$+ restaurant). 

This place is pretty standard and its really over hyped. Unfortunately I have to agree with the other Yelpers who state ingredient don't seem very fresh - I mean, picture in your head a pizza from say Delfina side by side with one made at Goat Hill and it may even turn your stomach. Pros: Waitstaff is really nice and seem really happy doing what they are doing so that earns the stars in this review. But that's all I have to say really. I won't be returning - there are way too many good pizza joints in SF to bother with this one.
author: Dolores A.

description:
Monday AYCE pizza.  Great idea.

It's not your typical pizza buffet with all the same pizzas sitting under heat lamps...no, they had staff wandering around, pies in hand, dishing out fresh (and hot!) slices to whoever wanted them.  And the variety can't be beat...I don't think I saw the same combo of toppings (and they were good toppings too...spinach, meats, goat cheese, green olives, artichokes, etc) come around, besides maybe the plain cheese.  The slices are small so you can try plenty.

Oh yea, and there's a salad bar in the back.  It's not extensive, but it get the job done.

For the pizza lover, you won't be disappointed!
author: Jennifer A.

description: Came for the first time on Mondays Neighborhood night and left with a very full and happy belly. Sat us next to a window with the view of the city, but it was tucked away in  back corner and sometimes the pizza took awhile to come to us or  the last slice would be taken at the table right before ours. Definitely a place to check out if you enjoy a variety of pizza a friendly atmosphere.
author: Alexis K.

description:
After a day of moving, what better way to end it then with some pizza and beer (wine, in my case). Our friend demanded (as in, commandeered the car and drove us here) that we eat here so we happily [and hungrily] obliged.

For appetizers we munched on the caprese salad and bruschetta. The caprese was really fresh and I loved the basil on it. The bruschetta I guess is made with garlic bread and it was SUPER TASTY. As for our meal, we split a medium -- half Meat Lover's and the other half Hilda's Favorite and everything was delicious and a great blend of flavours.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Don't know why I keep coming back....... Was out have a few drinks in the area and my friends convinced me to give it another shot. But once again.......

The pizza was just off not the goat hill I remember at all don't know if maybe they have changed their dough receipe or what. The other thing that was way different was the blue cheese which I LOVED previously it always nice and thick with nice chunks of good blue cheese it and now it is just a watery a $$ mess.

Step your quality up GH..........  I miss the mom and pop pizza spot you use to be :(
author: Michael W.

description:
Black Friday, coupon booklets, and thrift stores can move aside, because the biggest bargain in town is Monday nights at Goat Hill Pizza.  

Sure, the list to be seated can be so lengthy that while waiting, you are prone to forget if you've accidentally lined up for a Jordan release or the midnight showing of the next Avengers.  Also, the rush hour subway atmosphere limits elbow movement and curtails any reasonable attempts at tai chi, while the necessary salad ingestion to ensure self-preservation the next morning seems like a boring opening act to the main event.

None of these minor inconveniences detract from the glorious satisfaction of having varieties upon variety of pizza paraded around in a neverending stream awaiting a simple nod or passionate finger point to deposit any number of slices on your plate.  Whether the pie is dominated by veggies or speckled with meat, the consistent crispy chewiness in the crust and correctly proportioned sauce provide a model foundation.  Since each pan is brought directly from the oven and distributed immediately, there is no opportunity for hardening cheese or stale crust.

Combined with Nascar-influenced beverage refill times and the eagerness of servers to deliver piping-hot slices to the table, Goat Hill Pizza's smorgasbord of pies rules Potrero Hill.
author: Andrew M.

description:
get the lunch special. good minestrone soup and a large piece of pizza for $8

i came with a group of 8 on a sat afternoon and had easy parking. we were seated immediately.

the service was very nice. the view from the table was nice outside. 

we were told the sandwiches were very good.
author: Jeff K.

description:
After Milano's in Inner Sunset changed management, this place became our favorite pizza joint in the city.

Hilda's favorite (we add sausage) and the Porky Pie. BOOM!
author: Justin J.

description: Great pizzas, we had the cheesy garlic bread to start, the Californian, the Porky Pie and the Pizza of the Day which had a bunch of veggies and pepperoni. Perfect ratio of toppings, cheese and crust (not too thick or thin). I pride myself on being somewhat of a cheesy garlic bread connoisseur and this place did not disappoint (highly recommended!). I'm not a fan of veggies on pizza so I passed on the pizza of the day but the rest of my group really enjoyed it. The Californian and the Porky Pie were delicious! If I didn't live on the other side of town I'd be here WAY too often. There's plenty of space for large groups, good for families or a chill date night and not too loud.
author: Andrea J.

description: Unfortunately I don't see the popularity in Goat Hill Pizza. The pizza dough did not taste like sourdough and was unfortunately closer to frozen pizza quality. I shared a small  1/2 Californian and  1/2 Portuguese ($14.95). Neither was very good. I also had small house salad ($4.75), which was ok and basic, and an order of the hot wings ($4.95), which were the highlight of the meal. Although many claim this to be a neighborhood spot, if it were in my neighborhood, I would rather go to Round Table or Pizza Hut.
author: Rachelle T.

description: Good pizza but don't order the ravioli. Costco has a better one for less. This location is noisy. Sound echoes. The price of a pitcher of beer almost makes up for it but the pitchers are small.
author: Monica M.

description:
Amazing! Must have the Porky Pie....bacon, red onion, and roasted garlic! Does not get any better!
Elena, who I believe is the general manager, made us feel welcome as if it was her own home. Great feel and the best pizza, even gluten free! I'm a new regular
author: David C.

description:
Used to be good...something happened.  Did the owner retire?  The crust looked like it was machine made, thin, hard, tasteless. It isn't as good as it used to be. And yes, though it is "all you can eat pizza" night, I had come to expect better-but the offerings tonight were messy and hap hazard.

One thing I will say is that the staff are still great.
author: Eebee H.

description:
I eat here often mostly because of it's convenient location in my neighborhood. The pizza is good for the price. I always order pepperoni and love how the crust is just thin/thick enough and crunchy and the top broiled to perfection. 

I've ordered delivery from the other location, and the quality has been very inconsistent. Will review that one separately.

I've been once to their Neighborhood Night and because I came late, had a bad experience. The pizza was cold/warm and there was little selection. The wait staff, in general, isn't friendly at all except for select few. 

So basically, order to pick up at this location and you'll be happy. Parking is tough around this area around peak times.
author: Erin C.

description: Super good pizza! Nice quiet spot in Potrero Hill. No wait at all when we stopped in on a Saturday afternoon and great service. If I was a local I would come here often and try more of the menu. It's nice that you can also buy by the slice. Really a family friendly looking place too!
author: Jessica S.

description: The food is fresh, the atmosphere is friendly. Prices are good. Pasta is as good as the pizza is. Even though it is very good, I can't say outstanding just because I wasn't blown away or very surprised by any extremely good sensations while eating there.
author: Rodrigo P.

description:
When I moved to SF, all people ever told me was to try Little Star and Goat Hill for pizza.  I can finally check off Goat Hill.  I regret I hadn't tried it sooner.  One of the best dough recipes I've tried - their crust is extra crusty and crunchy and I love it.  

The ingredients to cheese ratio is generous but not too heavy where it becomes difficult to handle.

This is my new every day pizza joint!
author: Alex T.

description: The sourdough cornmeal crust is delicious and the staff were super attentive. I did, however, feel an unpleasant pang for paying $45 for a medium pizza and two beers. Can't a girl get her pizza on w/out breaking the bank? I suppose we're not in college anymore... Maybe I'll come back on a Monday for "all you can eat" when the college kids are actually abound.
author: Colleen C.

description: I was surprised because if heard great things about this spot. Unfortunately the ingredients were not fresh. And it was a bit on the noisy end. Also about $20 bucks for that kinda pizza isn't something to be excited about. Other places in the city offer a super fresh and delicious palette for as reasonably as $10. Decide for yourself.
author: Nutcrackin C.

description:
This is some GOOOOOOOOOOD pizza.  I've eaten a slice or two in my day and although I still swear by other styles of pizza Goat Hill serves an amazing dish.  The Hilda has to be one of my favorites and every time our office has birthday we buy from Goat Hill.  The deliveries are always prompt, you can order online, and the pizza is always piping hot!

Monday's is an all-you-can-eat night.  Be sure to check it out.
author: Kevin J.

description: Really great spot near the Giants stadium! Parking is tricky due to the hills, go figure, but once you get here the pizza does not disappoint! Occasionally with a yelp check in (or maybe for the first one) they'll do a free cheese bread on sourdough. The pizzas are all made on sourdough also, which means no crust left behind! All this plus decent beer and wine selection, clean bathrooms and an airy atmosphere conspire to make a really good spot that is worth returning to!
author: Tony M.

description:
Came halfway across the country for the best pizza in the land. 
Great neighborhood joint with super pizza, perfect sals, and friendly folks.
author: Kenny K.

description: After never getting our food for 70 minutes across the street at Aperto we came to Goat Hill with two hungry kids and two impatient adults. The order wasn't quite right but they were nice and helpful. Pizza was fresh and yummy and salads delicious. Two thumbs up!
author: Siobhan M.

description: My first time here was over 30 years ago.  Back then they kept a goat in the backyard area.  It hasn't changed a bit and I always stop by when I'm in the area.  Great pizza and great area.  If your nearby I suggest that you try it out.
author: Mike A.

description: I had a problem years ago with the staff at this place, but I've been coming back because the pizza at the end of the day it's pretty good. I also like the neighborhood, a not particularly well known part of the city, but that has fantastic views and plenty of night life.
author: Bartholomew F.

description: Huge portions so great place for groups (family style). Two of us ordered and small pizza and a salad and it was way too much. Next time would share one or the other.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Best pizza in SF!  The sourdough crust is perfection. A wide variety of toppings, something for everyone.  Their meatball sandwich is also great.  
Quick and reliable pickup and, if you eat in, it's a great place for groups, especially with kiddos. For guys with big appetites, all you can eat Mondays are a bargain. 
I hope they stay in Potrero forever!
author: M D.

description: Everything here is chomp-worthy. Unfortunately, it will also take a giant chomp out of your wallet. But do not fret because Monday night is "Neighborhood Night" with an all you can eat pizza and salad theme at 12.95 a person.
author: Michael M.

description: The pizza is really good. Thin crispy crust and fresh toppings. I went on a Monday when it is all you can eat. Everything I tried was delicious. The staff is very friendly and attentive. I will definitely be back again.
author: Olivia K.

description: I loveeeee this place. My best friend took me there on Valentine's Day after we went to the giant pillow fight. The service is a bit slow but the pizza is so good. I always get two slices of cheese pizza and a Shirley temple which they have free refills on. My friend always gets the hot wings and loves them. The ranch is so perfect for pizza. It is very well priced for about three slices and a Shirley temple it was 11$ which is such a great deal when the pizza is so amazing.  I had to give 4 stars because of the slow service.
author: Lauren S.

description: 1st time visit: Wow, surprisingly not really into the Sourdough crust at all.
author: Rharrison79 ..

description: Good pizza that is also a great place for kids. A neighborhood treasure where I took my kids and now hang with my grandkids.
author: Gary F.

description:
Fairly decent place for pizza, but nothing outstanding. Given that it's located in a city that has several amazing pizza places, I can't bring myself to giving it more than three stars.

Their sourdough base is good, but I prefer crusts at Delfina, little star etc. 

We ordered the meat lovers, Portuguese and a DIY pizza. Liked the meat lovers, unimpressed by the Portuguese and disliked the DIY. The DIY had anchovies, kalamata olives and garlic ... I realize that's not everyone's cup of tea, but I generally tend to like these ingredients. Unfortunately, the proportions here weren't balanced and the ingredient quality wasn't great. The anchovies were way too salty, garlic had little flavor and the olives were so-so.

The server however was really nice. Made the experience much better.
author: Ankur V.

description: I love Goat Hill Pizza and my 4 year old and I like to think they love us too.  Beautiful setting, sweet attentive staff and most importantly yummy pizza! Nothing beats this place for a nice son and mommy lunch date. I'm coming back again and again and again.... Love YOU GH!
author: Cindyjo O.

description:
I'm sorry! I'm sorry Goat Hill!

You guys have some very unique pizzas but I've had much better. 

I ordered the porky pie with chicken, but our waiter forgot the chicken =[ The pizza was overall ok/meh. It wasn't amazing or mind blowing. The pizza I've had at other places were just as creative but blasting with flavor. 

Also, the pesto pasta honestly didn't have much flavor to it. The giant meatballs were worse.
author: Maggie C.

description: I wish they delivered to me, but maybe it's better for my health that they don't.  The sourdough crust on the pizzas is great, but I love their salads with chicken.  They are very hearty and fresh tasting.
author: Seong P.

description:
Energy of person at counter gentle, cool and helpful. Gluten-free, vegan (though came out w feta I picked off) pizza a treat. Delicious. Decent wine list selection, about 12 options, give or take. 

Sweet, old church benches. Charming crayon-hand-drawings from kids and old kids of Goat Hill line the walls. 

Medium thick crust , heady hand-tossed. My eating parter likes that he can choose toppings on the singular slices. I wouldn't know because they don't offer gluten-free slices. The gluten free comes in one size small crust- enough for 2 meals or 3 if you eat light. Amazing pizza, he says.

And we're off, pleasantly satisfied. And me, a bit buzzed off a single glass of red.
author: Gaya G.

description:
Their delivery service is ON TOP of it! 
They said they'd deliver by Noon and they were at our offices at 11.55a- much appreciated. 

The pizza itself was good but nothing mind-blowing.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: The absolute hands down best pizza I have ever had! Made a reservation for 730 and we were seated at 7:29. My son drew on a paper and they hung it on the wall. It was an amazing experience and I will be back as soon as humanely possible.
author: Nikki K.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza features many artwork/doodles by patrons, all done on the place mats, plastered around the restaurant.  Whether you are in the bathroom, or staring at the counter waiting for your pizza to come out, it is enormously enjoyable to look at the devotee's interpretation of the establishment. I especially like the "rules of customers" done by some kid.  Awesome.

The pizza is good, with a nice chewy crust. The garlic bread is pretty darn awesome, even for someone like myself who has some reservation around the overuse of garlic.  We also ordered a salad to share and it was simply but tasty.  

I don't know if it's the wall to wall endorsement by the patrons, or simply because it's a homey restaurant that serves good food, but I think I will be back.
author: Candice B.

description:
Pizza was good. Went with Pepperoni and Mushrooms to-go and it was ready and super hot when I got there. Will definitely go back again. Not the best I've ever had, but definitely the best I've had in this area. 

Service was a tiny bit sour, but overall, a very good experience.
author: Matt S.

description: Well I tried to order a Porky Pie online. But it didn't have the option to get that particular pizza. So I tried to "build your own". My wife wanted Garlic sauce. But once again it wasn't offered online menu. Finally had to call in my order after messing around with the website for 15 mins. Oh the place 5 blocks from where I was doesn't deliver. Had to call the Soma location. Placed my order was told up to 1 hour for delivery and its 1.50 extra.. That's fine. Pizza showed up in 50 mins. Not bad. Added an extra 3 bucks tip, 33 dollars plus.. to delivery guy and he look at me and gave me a dirty look and acted cold. Pizza was loaded with garlic cloves. As far as the sourdough crust.. I couldn't even tell it was sourdough. Nothing special here. Basic pizza. Bland and attitude from delivery boy. Try another place if you can.
author: T S.

description: This place is wonderful! It has a very comfy home feel with red and white checkered table clothes and a bright back dining room. The pizza was great-- the ingredients tasted fresh and the crust was so yummy! As a New Yorker, I'm pretty harsh about pizza but I was totally pleased. Will definitely come back!
author: Susannah C.

description:
Good pizza and nice staff.  My husband wanted saltier sauce, but I thought the balance of flavors was tasty.  There was a big delay in our pizza arrival, and the head guy comped us an appetizer.  That's great customer service :-)

Would definitely visit again for some yummy pizza and relaxed atmosphere.
author: Rachel S.

description:
This pizza parlour reminds me of being in Little League again. 

Before Wolfgang Puck came along and arguably transformed the world of pizza for the better, most restaurants slinging pie as their main centerpiece kept it pretty simple; pepperoni, cheese, sausage... and that's about it. These days, you can find almost anything sitting atop artisanal pizza creations like edible flowers, cracked eggs, kobe beef, et al. But with so many boundaries being pushed, it's nice to reminisce about a simpler time when there were only three major networks on TV, and home cordless phones were considered edgy, progressive and cool. 

Granted, there's more to Goat Hill than simple ingredients. They certainly have recipes that rival the creativity of any fanciful parlour in the city... but they still do the basics quite well. Pepperoni pizza, sausage pizza, veggie pizza chock full of every green, red, yellow and black vegetable available... and a handful of gourmet creations like goat cheese with pesto and the Mediterranean special with sliced red onions, feta cheese, rosemary and thyme spices. 

It's not the cheapest skate you'll ever have, as a small pizza rings in at around $13, but once you take a bite it's all water under the bridge. Throw in some classic table settings, friendly faces and a guy playing a piano as you enter the facility... and you've got yourself a pretty quality dinner date with a hearty side of nostalgia. 

If you're a big eater, you'd be remiss not to hit their Monday all-you-can-eat pizza and salad night for $10. I can't say I'd ever be able to take full advantage of a deal like that, but it wouldn't be a bad way to round out a weeklong fast, I suppose.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Monday nights are fabulous for the "buffet" delivered to your table. 

Order the garlic cheese bread!
author: Vicki L.

description:
With friendly service and a relaxed, comfortable vibe, Goat Hill turns out some amazing San Francisco pizza.

Goat Hill is not a participant in the "gourmet pizza" craze that is sweeping The City; it is simply a long-standing Potrero favorite. The crispy sourdough crust is medium-thick:  not paper thin, not Chicago-style. Pizzas have a good balance of cheese and sauce, and the toppings are high quality and fresh. While they have some unique combinations, you can of course create your own. 

The all-you-can-eat special on Monday night is a pizza lovers dream, and there is a pianist who plays on Tuesday and Thursday evenings.

There is a good selection of beers, which are served by the mug or the pitcher.  While there a few wine selections, the quality in limited.  But, no worries:  beer goes better with pizza anyway.

With fresh ingredients, good service, and reasonable prices, Goat Hill is one of the the best pizza places in The City.
author: CJ G.

description: Good heavens, this is an overpriced pizza. 45.57 for two mediums. And frankly, I didn't think they were very good. The crust was tasteless and the whole thing was just lackluster.
author: Karen Z.

description:
As a gluten intolerant person my options with good pizza are limited.
Goat Hill makes a fantastic pizza and they are friendly and nice when you order it.
Really yummy - try their Hilda pizza - quite yummy:)
author: Maya z.

description:
So Goat Hill Pizza is four syllables. All You Can Eat Pizza is six syllables. More syllables and more words, but more to the point. All you can eat pizza! And they can even do it sourdough. If your San Francisco foodie quarter chub or femmeboner isn't in full effect right now, then you my friend are no longer thinking about a pizzeria so delicious you can smell it a block away. That's Goat Hill. 

Potrero Hill is an accurate name for the neighborhood where Goat Hill lives. I don't know how many times I've been out of breath walking up all the hills to get to All You Can Eat Pizza Mondays (I'm capitalizing it because it should be a city-recognized holiday). It's always worth it. When you're disgustingly full or perfectly happy depending on your approach, you'll relish the fact that you get to walk down hill home.

If you were to imagine Pizza Heaven (which why wouldn't you?) then it might feel like pizza and beer here. It's a real pizza joint with a good staff. The experience of all you can eat Monday is made possible by the staff. Without all the obnoxiousness of people in bow-ties waiting on you food, these people regularly handle walking to every table--every server has a different pizza pie--and asking you if you'd like a slice with a solid attitude and even better product. 

I don't know where else I can eat 10 different slices of pizza at once. Do you? If you do, give me a call, but I probably won't pick it up on Mondays. #ColinFarrellGetatMe
author: Danny A.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza's name may not sound appealing, but trust me, I'm all aBAAAAAAHHHHHT it. (Cue mid-1990's image of Goatman from SNL)

I don't get out to the Potrero very often, but this is one place that I would actually go out of my way for. We started out with the meatballs appetizer. I think we got 2, maybe 3 meatballs. Although they were juicy, tender, and really flavorful, the best part about the meatballs was the tomato sauce they were sitting in. I don't even like tomato sauce that much. But I doused every bite of meatball in the tomato sauce. It was sweet, and not at all tart. After we finished the meatballs, I finished up the tomato sauce with my spoon. Don't fAAAAAAAAAAult me for being a beast. (Although if you called me a goat, it'd be pretty appropriate in this instance)

Next, we each had the $5.95 lunch special: a slice of pizza and a bowl of soup.  You may select up to 2 toppings on each slice. My boyfriend ordered chicken/artichoke and I ordered pepperoni/onion. I was worried that this would not fill me up, but it was surprisingly satisfying. The sourdough crust was AHHHHHHHHHmazing and did me proud as a goat, oops, I mean girl, born and raised in SF. Truly one of those pizza crusts where you actually look forward to eating the crust and not merely as an afterthought.  

For the soups, we had split pea with ham and garlic shrimp. Both soups were really, really delicious, fresh, and hearty. 

I came "this close" to giving Goat Hill Pizza 5 stars, but I'll save that for when I come back to try their all-you-can-eat-pizza on Monday nights.
author: Monelle A.

description:
Wandered in after moseying about Potrero Hill in search of a snack to tide us over until dinner.  Not very impressed by the typical pizza parlor decor and menu, we walked back out and consulted Yelp.  Shocked that we might be missing out on something ULTRA TASTY based on the rave reviews, we immediately turned around and marched back in.

We got a small POTD (pizza of the day), which was ham, mushroom and jalapeno.  The small had 6 slices, of which we polished off 3 and packed the leftovers.  The sourdough crust was chewy and slightly crunchy, and we were seriously enthused by the freshness and quality of the sauce, cheese and toppings.  The cheese was stringy and melty beneath the clearly freshly sourced mushrooms and jalapenos.  The combo sounded tasty and was even better than we expected.  I was initially skeptical of the idea of sourdough crust, but the crust had more of the texture than the sour taste of sourdough, which was exactly what the pizza needed.

We're HUGE Little Star Pizza fans ourselves, but that's much more of a gourmet one-of-a-kind don't-even-call-it-pizza experience.  Goat Hill Pizza is classic pizza... just exceptionally well-done.  Can't wait until the next we're looking to get dinner near Potrero Hill... Goat Hill, for sure.  Also, I really enjoyed watching the family-like kooky interactions of the staff.  They were definitely having much more fun working together on a Saturday than I would have had in the same circumstance... babysitting hungry customers on a Saturday afternoon. :P
author: Hannah C.

description:
A very belated review of the awesome pizza here on their manic mondays! I came here with a whole crew of other Yelper Elites! Everyone from Bobby, Cece, Julie, Hana, and Kim all joined in for the fun.

It's all about the Mondays! For Goat Hill Pizza, to offer up all-you-can-eat pizza is probably a god sent! I never had all the pizza I wanted for just a fixed price. Furthermore, piping hot straight from the oven to the server handing out the slices instead of offering up the pizza in a buffet style fashion. In consequent, we all got all the pizza we wanted and none of it are stale since they are all baked. My favorite is any pizza with prosciutto or basil in it!

-----
+ Pro: Delicious thin pizzas.
- Con: None :D
\( ^,^)/ Overall: It's all about their Mondays!
author: James N.

description:
Update: Now they do.

So as of tonight they no longer deliver to the Great Highway. This past weekend they did, now they don't.
author: ian w.

description: Great range of pizza. The sourdough crusts are particularly awesome. My wife, who hates crusts, was eating these instead of leaving them for me. We'll worth a visit.
author: Greg B.

description:
OH MAN

This was some fantastically delicious pizza! Came in here with interns and some of my supervisors for lunch. Got some ice water and there were a plethora of pizza toppings and other item opinions to choose from. Robbie didn't like mushrooms and I didn't like grapefruit so we didn't get any of those toppings (thank god they didn't have grapefruit as a topping). We ended up getting an X-large, half meat lover's, and half "special of the day" which was bacon, artichoke and tomatoes. Wasn't really too long of a wait. The pizza came in smoking hot and SMELLS SO GOOD. GOD it smelled delicious. 

My first slice was of the meat lovers. Sausage, salami, and pepperoni. Mmmmm so meaty and juicy. The salami and pepperoni melded together to from an unearthly fusion of hot fatty meat juices that exploded in your mouth. The sausage was chunked into large pieces too. After a couple salty savory bites of the pizza, you'd bite into a really big piece of yummy sausage. Quite tasty. The special of day was better though. The artichoke and tomato complimented each other well with their slightly sour refreshing juices. The crust held up nicely against the wide array of toppings. And the bacon... oh yes. Usually bacon is cooked limp and chewy on pizza, but this one was nothing like that. The bacon was crispy..CRISPY BACON ON PIZZA. And the fat wasn't even completely rendered! So you'd have an amazing bite of the crispy fatty bacon followed by several refreshing bites of the tomato and artichoke. Fantastic.

But the best part was really none of these toppings. The crust was superb. Crispy sourdough crust that could withstand all the sauce and toppings without drooping down or getting soggy. And at the end, when you finished all the sauced parts, a fabulous crust end awaits which was just as good as the rest of the pizza you had just ate. Yeah that crust was gooodd. They had some cornmeal on the bottom and the crust was a deep brown and slightly charred on the bottom. Good flavors.

5/5 the crust was really really good.
author: Ernest C.

description: Stopped in for the first time looking for a quick bite to eat. I ordered the meatball sandwich with a tomato soup as a side. The soup was the best I've ever had, hands down. I'm usually a big salt a pepper person when eating soup but this was perfect. Then the sandwich came. I had to eat it opened faced cause it was so loaded. When I took a bite it took me by suprise. It tasted exactly like my Sicilian great grandmother's meatballs she used to make for me. There were two cops nearby and I almost called them over for elder abuse because I was sure they had my 90 year old grandma in the back making the meatballs. Being new to the area I will definitely be back!
author: Aaron D.

description:
Monday Nights = $15 (after tax and tip) All you can eat pizza.

Good Pizza and they keep coming with different combos of pizza, good times.

Probably not a good idea to come with groups larger than 4, unless you are willing to wait.
author: Steven F.

description:
Goat Hill is a neighborhood institution. It's also the traditional social spot for One Brick volunteers after volunteering at the food bank. On one volunteering occasion, Goat Hill was closed for renovations. We had to take a moment to process the grief and absence of this jarring break in routine. Fortunately, doors were open again soon and the tradition continues.

Staff are friendly, prices reasonable. There's always lots of interesting artwork on the walls. Crayons and paper place mats available for coloring. Oh, I mean for the kids, yeah, that's right.  Hooray for the goat!
author: Megan K.

description: I loved the sourdough crust! Great tasting pizza and quick delivery too.
author: Mike P.

description:
I had been craving pizza all week so since Mondays are the neighborhood all you can eat pizza and salad night, I figured why not!

I arrived here around 5:30pm with a friend after work. The spot is located in a cute neighborhood on a hill so be prepared to parallel park or park at 90 degrees on a very steep hill.

I had only heard about Goat Hill from 2 friends so it sounded like a good place to try.

When you're seated they give you a paper plate for the pizza and there are actual plates for the salad at the bar. The server come around with different pizzas and as if you'd like a slice. Sounds cool right?

After about 10 minutes of waiting, we finally started to see pizzas coming out the kitchen. I guess when we arrived a new batch had been put in. You never know what you're going to get offered and there is not set menu per say displayed anywhere.

We had the following pizzas today:

pesto and chicken
pesto and cheese
sun-dried tomato and pesto
chicken and mushroom
artichoke and salami
bacon, olive, tomato, and green onion
ham and sausage
pineapple, olive, and green onion

Also going around today was salami and sausage, ground beef and ham, pepperoni, plain cheese, and lots of other combinations.

Personally, a good old Canadian bacon and pineapple would have been great.

The reason for only 3 stars is the following:

The pizza itself doesn't jump out with fireworks sparkling on your taste buds. Moreover, the dining space is very cramped and it gets kind of crazy when there are large parties surrounding you. Since it was just my friend and I, we were smashed up pretty close to another 2 person party and 2, 10+ person parties. In addition, when large groups are being seated they all tend to crowd your eating space. Not the best way to enjoy a meal.

However, the decor is really cute. There are paintings done by local children artists and the bathrooms are full of framed place mats diners have designed.

Another reason for the 3 stars is false advertising on the website. It says $10.95 on the website for the all you can eat, but it's actually $11.95. Attention to detail please!

Thanks for satisfying my pizza craving Goat Hill, but I don't know if I can stomach another visit anytime soon.

Until next time, happy eating!
author: Valerie A.

description:
Simply, some of the best pizza I have ever had.  Hilda's favorite is fantastic, and so is the meat Pizza.

Make sure to go on Monday nights for All you can eat pizza for only $11.  It really doesn't get better than this.
author: Ryan D.

description:
I was coming home late yesterday and didn't have enough time to cook, so I decided to look for pizza joints in SOMA and Yelp brought me to Goat Hill Pizza.

I called in for delivery and the person who assisted me was very helpful and gave good suggestions for what kind of pizza I should get. I ended up getting half special combo and half chicken and pesto.

I arrive at the restaurant and was surprised at how cozy it was. Kinda felt nob hill'ish, small restaurant and was very packed. I'm going to have to come back and dine here.

Now onto the pizza - the sourdough bread was thin, crispy and chewy. There were plenty of toppings for both half's and they were all so flavorful. I can't decide which half I liked more - I loved them both! I got a large pizza ($25 for 2 half's) for 3 people and normally, we'd have plenty left over, but we ended up with just one slice. Even my Grandma who usually doesn't eat much, ate an extra slice because she said it tasted good. It's a tad bit more pricier than other places, but you can taste the difference and that difference is worth the money.
author: Rosie W.

description: Ordered two pizzas for pick up. Arrived at restaurant 20 minutes later and was directed to the pick up counter. Lady was on the phone so I waited until she was finished. When she finished her phone call, she turned and looked at me. Unfazed, I told her My name and that I was here to pick up an order that was telephoned in. She got my order, rang it up, placed the bill on the counter and turned away. After a few minutes, I realized that she wasn't coming back so I signed and left. Pizzas were OK but it was kinda salty and had a little too much garlic. Very expensive. Will not go back.
author: Henry N.

description: Great pizza and pasta.  Large space for groups.  Very casual and neighborhoodie. I highs recommend it.
author: E P.

description:
This review is for AYCE Mondays:

PROS:
- AYCE pizza for about $12. Hooray!
- Try a bunch of different pizzas.
- Leave with a big bellay of pizza.
- Generally nice servers, esp the busboys/men and a few of the pizza servers. 
- Amusing art on the wall, esp the ones done by kids. 
- Potrero Hill neighborhood :)

CONS:
- Wait can be bad. 
- Hostess: Last time, the hostess kept wiping her nose and sneezing INTO the paper plates she was handing out. Gross. Seriously, gross. (But I still stayed for pizza - doh!)
- Depending on where your table is located, sometimes I feel like you get pizza scraps or it runs out before it gets to you. I think the servers try to rotate and hit diff tables in diff orders, but it doesn't always work out. 
- Large groups usually come here and they can get LOUD. Last time we sat near an obnoxious group of ~20 people. Not much you can do about it. When they left, the place got so much more peaceful and pleasant.
author: Veronica H.

description:
What a fantastic lunch deal - $5.95 for a huge slice and a bowl of soup. The crust is excellent, and they pile on the toppings. Service was also great - my glass of ice tea was never empty, even after my third refill.

Portrero is probably the closest thing to a "suburb" that San Francisco has. The children's drawings covering the walls really gives a sense that GHP is a part of the community. Can't wait to come back for their Monday all-you-can-eat Pizza nights and blend in with the crowd.
author: Lael A.

description: The most overrated pizza place in sf.  Overpriced and inconsistent.   The delivery drivers are usually late and are incapable of following instructions.  The salads suck.  The watered down blue cheese is pathetic.  Don't believe the hype.  Try serranos.
author: Zach H.

description: Ordered takeout because they don't deliver to SOMA, ready in 15 min which was nice. Used a Yelp checkin to redeem free cheesy bread! The sausage pizza was pretty good for thin crust, not memorable but decent. The cheesy bread was hot melting and delicious for the first 10min but cut into such large, hard pieces it was hard to eat. And after things cooled, it just looked a large pile of lard on top of hard bread. But the pizza was good to eat days after!
author: Alice L.

description:
So in an act of desperation I gave Goat Hill Pizza another try. Being older, wiser, and decidedly tired of pizza I ordered a hot Italian sandwich. And then I fell in love.

With each bite the horrible experience of my first try of Goat Hill Pizza became a more distant memory. The bread was toasty delicious, the sausage was perfectly flavored, and the toppings were the best companion.

While I was unimpressed with the pizza here, I definitely dig the sandwiches, so if you're finding the pizza underwhelming, don't give up so quickly!
author: Brett P.

description: The pizza was really good. The sauce was awesome - rich and savory and perfect. Delivery was friendly.
author: Andrew K.

description: My friends and I ordered the extra large porky pie pizza with sausage for take out. The pizza was delicious and the pizza was still hot! I will definitely come back again.
author: Karen T.

description:
My boyfriend and I were visiting friends in Potrero Hill and happened to discover all you can eat pizza and salad Monday night.

The place was packed but somehow the two of us were able to be seated almost right away. They walk around with trays of different flavors of pizza and you let them know which ones you want.

There is also a salad bar in the back which isn't very large but it has my favorites like kidney beans, beets and the lettuce was crisp.

We enjoyed sampling the different types of pizza. They have thin crisp crust on their pizzas which was really good. I was grateful that the pieces were really small so that we could enjoy many flavors before becoming too full.
author: Casey S.

description:
This place is great!  I love the sourdough base.  It gives it a very San Francisco feel and taste. 

The best time to go is on Monday night, all you can eat night.  You'll get to sample every pizza they have to offer.  Skip the salad bar in back or you'll miss out on all the different varieties pizza.  Make sure to make a reservation or you'll be waiting there a while.  Your entire party has to be there before you can be seated.

Fact: I saw Albert Einstein eating there! J/k it was just some older man with the same crazy unkempt hair/facial hair.
author: Eleanor L.

description:
We came here on monday night for the All-you-can-eat.  Endless servings of pizza and salad.  Salad options were mediocre, not a whole lot to choose from just lettuce, black olives, beets, pepperoncini, onion and shredded cheese. 

Pizzas are served by servers.  There wasn't a whole lot of pizza with meat toppings.  Their crust is pretty crispyyy so you don't have to worry about getting soggy pizza here. :P  I remembered a lot of pineapple and garlic that night. There was this one really good pizza that came around only once, I will never forget it- it had artichokes, bacon, italian sausage and something else..... They have some pretty interesting combinations, definitely check them out if your in the area.

On a random note they have two unisex bathrooms along the hallway, pretty cramped.
author: Kim R.

description: Very good family restaurant in Potrero. Huge variety of great tasting menu items. Fast and friendly service.
author: Ula K.

description:
Wow, awful pizza and ridiculously overpriced!

Two large pizzas for $46?

Really?

The pizzas arrived and both were very dry (lacking much/any sauce) and the worst part was that I couldn't even "eat around" or come to terms with how badly they were BURNT to a crisp. Sadly, the pizza I ordered with my toppings was the one that was so badly charred I had to eat the alternative. It was that or break off my jaw trying to tear at the charcoal pizza I must have ordered.

So disappointed, even the driver wasn't a pleasant experience. She snapped at us when we came to get the pizzas from her.

Pretty much ruined my Friday night LAN party at the office. What a waste of ~$50!
author: Lauren F.

description:
I love pizza in general and this place is as good as it gets in San Francisco (so far from what I've tasted).  The crust is yum and the sauce is great.  I'm typically a all meat type of pizza person, but I tried the Chicken Pesto pizza and that was pretty darn good.  I also tried their spaghetti with meat balls and the sauce was really good.  It was even better the next day!  

They are also great with their dine in service.  Two summers ago a bunch of my cousins and I dined there after a SF Giants game and they were able to provide us with an "all you can eat" type of dinner where they brought out pizzas as we consumed them (the pizzas were pre-ordered/picked by my wonderful cousin who coordinated our dinner there) and Goat Hill just had them ready to go.  It was a great experience, worth the money and good food.  They are also a kid friendly restaurant, so that's a plus for a mother!
author: Debbie S.

description:
All you can eat pizza night ( Monday)?!?! UH yes please!!  I came here to try out the famous sourdough crust pizza and I have to say. I love it!!  It's a nice little pizzeria. There is a line at this place so eat here as an early dinner or late dinner.

So the way it works is the staff walks around with a pizza pie and pass out slices of pizza at each table.  You can pass on the ones you don't want to try but I say be adventurous and try them all.  The slices are really small.  They're actually half slices.  Plus the crust is thin crust which helps so you try more pizza. 

Don't mess with the salad bar.  Don't waste room with salad.  Just stick to the pizza. It's worth every calorie!

They serve beer and soda. A few tvs are placed in the corners of the restaurant. 

Overall, great experience and differently will be back again!
author: Ying F.

description:
We ordered a stack of pizzas for an office lunch today and Goat Hill delivered to us!

Sourdough pizza of tastiness. Surprisingly, the cheese pizza was one of the better ones I've ever had. I also tried an artichoke/tomato pizza but without tomato sauce, it left a bit to be desired. The other flavours, which I didn't get to try, looked pretty amazing and the feedback of my coworkers was on the positive side. There were very few leftovers by the end of our lunch.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
The place to go on Monday nights. For $11, you can pizza until you die. And it's good pizza at that. You sit down, and they bring the pizza to you. You just say "yes" or "no." 

I really like their veggie pizzas. They make them interesting. Their Greek pizza with tons of feta is one of my faves. 

And they deliver. Not from this location, but they will come to just about anywhere in the city! 

For the price, pizza, atmosphere, Goat Hill is one of my fav pizza places in San Francisco.
author: Mariko F.

description: Very disappointed. A high yelp rating, but horrible food quality and decor. Tasteless pasta sauce, greasy pizza and bad service.
author: Michael P.

description:
I came here this past Saturday afternoon with my child, sister and her two children. I have always loved coming to this pizza joint because I grew up in the City and came 
here a lot growing up. I love the fact that they have markers for the children and adults who want to draw in their place mat. I ordered a combination pizza, wings and bruschetta. The bruschetta was the absolute best that I ever tasted. I can't wait to dine here again! Absolute best pizza in San Francisco period!
author: Kiana D.

description: Delicious and crispy pie, just the way I like it. Got the wings and garlic bread too, both were good as well.
author: Carmen L.

description: Is this a cricket or a cockroach on the wall?! I can't tell so I don't know whether to be relaxed or vomit?? I don't know. I also unfortunately went into the bathroom after an employee that peed on the toilet. But I like the food so I feel conflicted.
author: Jade R.

description:
This place is one of the better pizza place that I've been to so far in San Francisco and it was quite good actually.

Some places can be a bit of a pain to deal with in regards of communication but these guys has been great every time that my roommate and I have managed to find ourselves here.

My roommate and I typically either order the Meat lover or the Hawaiian pizza, and both are quite good, we find that a medium to large is a good size for two people.
author: Anja B.

description:
So we were engaged in Sunday afternoon randomness, when (a) Shorty started gnawing on my arm, which is Shorty's way of subtly signaling that Shorty is hungry, and (b) announced that Shorty wants pizza, which is about as rare as chickens with three wings (except for those mutant chickens The Colonel has unleashed on the world....) as Shorty generally views pizza to be a Food of the Devil. Fortunately the Yelp! iPhone app pointed out that Goat Hill Pizza was in close proximity, and fondly remembering being bribed at work with their pizza, sent us on a beeline there. The choice was confirmed as the Parking Gods smiled upon us, gifting us with a parking space within a quarter block of the place.

Within 20 or so minutes we were well into a pitcher of Anchor Steam which Shorty wanted to know if it was piped directly from the Anchor brewery just down the street, and digging into a Porky Pie, a bacon and roasted garlic masterpiece. The crust was crispy and light (we asked for a thin crust); the toppings a nice scatting of well-fried bacon and whole cloves of expertly roasted garlic all embedded in a good quantity of quality cheese. It was delicious enough that (a) we'll definitely be back, and (b) Shorty is reconsidering whether pizza is a food of the devil (I'm telling Shorty that (a) bad pizza is the food of the devil, and (b) the devil isn't such a bad guy [he did come up with demon rum didn't he?] after all).

By the way, great laid-back staff. Our waiter even pointed out how you could see one of the towers of the Golden Gate Bridge from the window furthest from the door. And you can!

I may have to drench Shorty in Holy Water, but we'll be back!
author: Ed T.

description:
I have been coming to Goat Hill in Potrero for years now.  They make a pretty good pizza, have great service, and is a great place for families.
  Monday night is all you can eat, where they bring around random slices for hours and you eat until full.  Check it out!

   The pizza is a sour dough crust, which I like, and there is the option of gluten free, whuch Dan R will like.  The toppings are fresh, as are the salads, but they tend to go overboard on the fresh garlic on the pizzas, and also the crust is a bit to firm for my liking on something that is not NY style thin.

  The place is solid.  Check it out...  good for groups in the back room btw.
author: Bad Y.

description: The pizza is good. Always very fresh and the sourdough crust is great.
author: Lyndsey C.

description: Great neighborhood place. I was looking for a kid-friendly place for our group of 13 and they were not only extremely accommodating of our reservation, but they gave us great service while we were there. Of course, the pizza was fantastic so it helped make our family get together more fun. Love this place.
author: Steph S.

description:
San Francisco is littered with terrible pizza joints so it's nice to find a good reliable place, and for my money Goat Hill is way better than some fancier places like Delfina or Zero Zero.  When all you want is great pizza with no gimmicks like thin crust or stuffed crust or whatever, Goat Hill is the best option I've found in the city.  Generous with toppings, great textures, not greasy, and the garlic bread is good too.

That said my one and only delivery experience was not great -- it took an hour despite the fact that I'm half a mile from their location (admittedly they were upfront with the time estimate in the beginning), and they left off one of the toppings.  The prices also are higher than you'd expect given the atmosphere, but then the food is also better than you'd expect, so I think it's pretty fair.
author: Alex H.

description:
American-style pizza. Regular ingredients. Reasonable variety and good execution. 

If you're into Italian pizza, this place is not for you.

Great value, and good service.
author: Gatola I.

description: The pizza is pretty good here.  They have a gluten-free option which is growing increasingly important in the past few years.  They had some sort of salad and slice lunch special which i was totally into!
author: Julie B.

description: WTF! Is it me or is their customer service adopting the mandatory rude policy? Especially, this one girl in particular (pale skin/blue eyes) who is just absolutely rude! Someone has a chip on their shoulder! Okay, I got it!. Anyway, It's alright pizza, I like the ambiance when it's right on. I don't know where this "screw it" attitude is coming from, but oh well. I hope it gets better for their sake.
author: Roberto A.

description: The sourdough crust here is amazing! Also there are great options for vegetarians. I ordered for delivery, and the delivery was quick and efficient. They also have great salads which I find to be an exception to the rule when I order pizza.
author: Carissa T.

description:
More like 3.5

Went on monday for all-you-can-eat.  Good experience, staff was great, food was decent. Glad i went and if i'm in that hood, i would go back.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Vegan cheez pleez?

That's not how I asked. This is how someone likely younger than myself asked in a drawing Goat Hill has hanging on a wall.

One of many on display throughout the restaurant. Clearly a cherished part of the neighborhood since 1975.

Not only family friendly. Appetite friendly and healthy friendly too.

Chicken Florentine was a pizza that got better with every bite. Grilled chicken, mushrooms, spinach and vegan cheese on a sourdough crust. Afterwards my stomach and heart were thanking me.

Medium was just a little too big for the two of us. Especially after splitting the kidney and garbanzo bean loaded Salad Bowl to start. Artichoke hearts were bonus.

Glad to be part of the tradition.
author: Jason B.

description:
Shatangi is a pizza snob. Not only do they have 2 great locations and great cali-fusion style pies, their employees really did what they do and are wicked friendly!  Not so much a destination as a staple. Hella heart you Goat Hill!!

Shatangi told you...
author: Njon W.

description: Their Pizza is very good.  thin crust. 2 types of vegetarian..  Mediterranean one is tasty-good flavors.Service is good.  Wish it was closer to us but they have parking in walking distance..  Cute to see all those kids. Looks like a family orientated neighborhood.
author: D.B B.

description: Solid pizza experience.  I'll get straight to the point.  We ordered a medium chef's special which consisted of bacon, artichoke hearts and green onion.  They weren't light on the bacon, which is an automatic extra star.  The toppings were actually very balanced and the cheese was melted to perfection. The crust is medium/thin with a great thin crisp and chewy center through and through.  The service was friendly and the place was actually a lot larger than I expected.  It's not going to be a fancy place to take a date, but definitely a chill experience.  The staff seem to be working their butts off so its expected that service might be a bit slow, but its also a pizza place not by the slice so you should already know you're going to wait.  My gf also got their greek salad, which was fresh and had a good balance of veggies and lentils.  The dressing was also light to, but we did get it on the side.  When I am in the area again, I wouldn't mind dropping by for a pie!
author: Mike L.

description: Sourdough pizza is great. Staff are not so great. I don't want to feel like I'm imposing on someone when they are supposed to be waiting on us. The staff actually made me cringe when my co-worker tried to be friendly.
author: Lydia K.

description:
Pizza is very good.
Weekday lunch specials (slice + salad) are a bargain.
Service and atmosphere are great when it isn't completely mobbed, so I prefer to go here during non-peak hours.
One of the few places in SF you can take a large rowdy party.
Their house-made iced tea is some of the best in town.
author: Eric H.

description:
I "LOVE" Potrero Hill!

I "HEART" Potrero Hill!

I "LOVE" & "HEART" Potrero Hill!

If an Potrero Hill Elementary school-teacher punished me and forces me to write any of those postitive lines a thousand times on the blackboard, I would do it too. 

There are so many great restaurants in the quiet, but lively Potrero Hill neighborhood. And one of them starts with this corner pizzeria. 

I now and again have a craving for a slice of pizza. From my awkward judgment, a slice of pizza is an indication on how the neighborhood really is. There are other ways to sense a unfamiliar neighborhood, but that is how I look at it.

From the counter, I ordered a slice of pizza. Yes, pricey for $4.00 and that single thin slice, which is baked in a "hot" brick oven, comes with choices of two toppings, in which I chose sliced Black Olives and bits of ground beef. The customized pizza was very filling and greasy with the hamburger meat. I enjoyed my slice of pizza on the counter and watching the Bulls and Celtics' playoff game on the in-house Plasma-screen TV.

I didn't get a chance to walk around the entire restaurant. But with the tasty pizza, expect a second trip and an update from me very soon.
author: Matt G.

description:
Monday Night Pizza!
They're awesome. They make maybe the best pizza in SF. SF pizza can not hold a candle to anything from Chicago but at least this places tries my using Sour Dough! The people that work here are great and show you much love.
author: Some D.

description: Fast delivery, tasty pizza that was generous with toppings, and sourdough crust. Need I say more?
author: Shira S.

description:
This review is actually for 4.5 stars.

As soon as I walked by here, I can smell the smell of pizza lurking around the entrance. I came here on monday evening so there was all you can eat pizza. (SCORE!)

Anyways, onto the pizza. Of all the pizzas I tried that night (Hilda's favorite, artichoke + sausage, cheese, combo, vegetarian) I would say that the artichoke and sausage was the best. It stood out the most compared to other pizza places (flavor wise). The crust was nice and soft and the bottom had a nice crisp to it. BEST PIZZA I'VE HAD IN A WHILE!

To sum it all up, yes, I will be back (on Monday's :P) and I suggest that pizza lovers come and try this place out. Come on Monday's so you can try ALL the different types of pizzas! They have waiters/waitresses walking around serving pizza the entire night on Monday's.

***Parking***: may be a bit hard to find. It's street parking only and there are a lot of businesses around here so it tends to be filled up. Park a block or 2 away.

Cash/Credit/Debit are all accepted here.
author: Johnny G.

description:
O stars. If there could be negative stars, a bunch of them.

I'm not sure it's possible, in any human language, to describe how poorly I was treated at Goat Hill this afternoon. Perhaps Klingon would do . I can't say  how I was served, because after over an an hour of sitting and watching tables next to us be served, no one had taken our order. 

I had come early to join a friend for a birthday celebration. I arrived at 5:00, expecting to have something while I waited for the rest of the party, who would not arrive till 6:30 or 7:00. I easily found a seat - it was early, and the place was 2/3 empty - next to a friend who was already there, having some wine while they waited. We talked; the place gradually filled. People sitting at tables next to us began to be served their dinners; but it was over 45 minutes before anyone asked if I was going to order. Then, they told me that they couldn't serve me, I would have to wait till the entire party arrived. They said I could  talk to the manager, and I said I'd like to. Another 20 minutes went by, and finally that personage appeared. They also told me that I could not order anything at all until the entire other party showed. 

If it was Chez Pannise, this much attitude would still be inexcusable. For a pizza joint - who's kidding who? Neither I nor my family will be trying to get served at Goat Hill in the future.
author: Rashid P.

description:
Writing this review, because it is "all you can eat pizza night" at Goat Hill. So since I often think about them on Mondays, I thought I would remind you all of the pizza night too.

This is for me, one of those old school traditions that are simply SF to me. For $10.95, it's worth the wait. 

All you can eat salad bar with all the fixens and dressings that taste homemade and authentic. Yummy Slivers of Pizza, that keep coming your way until you give up and go home satisfied. Different pizzas with unique and delicious toppings that make you crave jalapenos on a pizza when other places just don't do that....
author: Rebekah T.

description:
A slice of authentic two-topping pizza slice and a salad/soup for just $5.95--total steal!

I love Goat Hill Pizza because the quality of their food tastes so... REAL.  I always get just a pepperoni and mushroom slice and a salad with their delicious house Italian dressing if I'm feeling like a good girl but... usually I'm feeling like a bad girl so I end up getting the minestrone soup or clam chowder.  I'm thinking they make the soup in-house because again, there's a real authentic taste to them.

They also serve an awesome Bruschetta every now and then and if they happen to have it--get it!  Super fresh ingredients and really fills you up if you don't think a slice of pizza and hearty soup won't do.

Now, the downside.  It gets pretty darn crowded during lunch time like most places in the area so I suggest taking your food to go.  The place looks small from the outside but it actually has a huge back room.  It always seems like they don't have enough waitresses during the lunch hours so service can be somewhat slow.  If you plan on eating in during peak hours, be prepared to take a 1.5 hour lunch.

Also, parking pretty much sucks.  If you park at the top of the hill, eating a super carb-loaded lunch is not going to make that trek back up any easier!  Just a warning!  I have no other suggestions to help you out with that issue.
author: Ivy Z.

description: Pizza is ok. Just ok. Price is WAY too high for this pizza. I couldn't believe they charge what they do. Next time I'll pay more attention. Actually, there won't be a next time. I can get just as good pizza for a lot less money practically anywhere else.
author: Brad D.

description:
As a Newyorker, Chicagoan, Italy transplant, I wasn't expecting too much from pizza in SF, but living in Potrero Hill, it's my local place, so I had to give it a shot after a few local PH friends talked it up.

First thing that I noticed was the view. Around sunset in the back corner of the restaurant, it really brings out the best in SF. The city is really full of views, but not every restaurant has one when you're sitting down to eat, so it added to the atmosphere.

As for the pizza, I wasn't blown away. That said, I wasn't expecting to be. It wasn't revolutionary, it doesn't define a new genre of pizza, but they did what SF places tend to do - rely on local ingredients and staples. To be honest, I didn't love the sourdough crust and I didn't love the goat cheese, but it wasn't bad. I'd go back with a group and I think people who aren't particularly attached to a certain tradition of pizza would like it.
author: Forza M.

description: Good pizza, I LOVE the sourdough. Much like the hill, the prices are steep and the service can be hit and miss. The place is fairly kid friendly as well...
author: Michael E.

description: YEAHHHH this pizza is soooooo good even two days later, leftover and cold. This pizza is the bomb and you have coloring placemats and it's on a hill, and they have a satanic goat drawing on the restroom, and they have bottles of wine, and it's warm. We got two pizzas and my friend even got a personal pizza..it's so delicious
author: Sonya Z.

description:
We started off with the Hot Wings. While they tasted OK, the skin wasn't crisp. We then had a half-and-half pizza of Hilda's Favorite (goat cheese, pesto, fresh tomatoes) and Porky Pie (bacon, roasted garlic, and red onions). The crust was OK, but there was too much liquid that made the crust soggy and droopy. The toppings were also OK, but the Porky Pie pizza had an off flavor.

If you lived in a small town and this place were the only pizza place, it would be OK; but San Francisco is a big place and there's far better pizza to be had elsewhere -- see my other reviews for where.
author: Paul L.

description:
First time here at Goat Hill Pizza the other night.

My GF and I were just doing our regular Friday night outing in the City. 

After walking around deciding if we should go to Chez Maman again, we agreed to just go to a Pizza Joint.

Although a last resort alternative, we did not mind it after realizing we both never had dinner at a pizza joint. 

As soon as we enter we are greeted by the friendly host who showed us to our seats. We sat in the front dining area. If you are looking for complete privacy, be weary that you may not get it if they are busy. On both sides were other couples. The distance apart is fairly close where you can listen in on awkward first date conversations. It was no big deal for us, but it might be something for others to know.

The menu was not overwhelming so it didn't confuse us when trying to make a choice We went with a small Special Combination, and a half Cheese & Spinach ravioli with pesto sauce.

****YELP TIP**** You can see more details on the menu items, prices, etc on their very website..
http://www.goathill.com/menu.html

The small comes with 6 slices, and the half order of Ravioli comes with 6 pieces and "A" garlic bread. 

The pizza was superb. Everything tasted fresh, and although the combination has so many ingredients on it, I could taste every single one even when covered in the tasty cheese.

The ravioli was good as well, but the pizza was the star. The garlic bread included with the ravioli was sure tasty just to add. 

It was a combination of things that made my first time experience here wonderful. I was with the person I love on our weekly outings. Had a wonderful day gallivanting around the city. Ended the night strolling around Potrero Hill. Then finding a nice cozy pizza joint. 

Perhaps you can have the same experience..
author: Eugene N.

description:
I've been going to Goat Hill for 10+ years, as it's right in the 'hood. The house salad used to be a highlight - fresh greens loaded with beans, feta, and all kinds of goodness. I'm sad to report that the last three times I've been, it's been highly disappointing - iceberg lettuce with a couple of half-assed things thrown on. Even my friend who always wants to go there when passing through town commented on how sad the salad was.

The pizza is solid as it's always been, and the house-made salad dressing is still stellar, but it's sad to witness the slow decline in quality of a place I've been patronizing for years.
author: K L.

description: I did not know about this place until on my bday I received a voucher for one large pizza !!!! The place is really cute and just has that homey vibe in really sweet neighborhood. I ordered cheese pizza that to be honest I was not too crazy about, I felt that the crust was too hard, my son ordered clam chowder that was yummy with a side of meat balls that I ate..haha. Waitress  was beyond nice and just very helpful.
author: Magda G.

description: Great for groups. Went here for birthday dinner and I think we ordered quite a bit of food but the bill was not too bad, dare I say cheap pics in SF exists? Not the best pizza in the world but it'll do the job for large groups or if you need a fixing
author: Dang T.

description:
We came here for the buffet.  

Pizza selections came out fast, but they all pretty much tasted the same because:

-not much variety.  Cheese, cheese with mushrooms, cheese with pineapple, cheese with jalapenos...you get the picture
-skimpy toppings:  a pepperoni slice had 1 piece of pepperoni on it, a chorizo one actually only had half a piece of chorizo.  
-supermodelly waifish-thin slices:  3-4 bites and you're done

On the plus side, the sourdough actually mixes well with the pizza, and the salad selection is pretty good - they had beets!  

But come here for the pizza and prepare to be disappointed.
author: C L.

description: Tasty pizza for as low as $2.50 a slice? (and they're big slices!) Count me in! Totally worth the bus ride to potrero hill :)
author: Eliza D.

description:
Usually I had this pizza via delivery to our company. And it's always been good, doesn't travel as well but not bad. The crust is pretty tasty. 

However the one time I had purchased a groupon I came here with my husband and we ordered an all meat pizza. It tasted very salty and was very oily. Also the waiter was like a sales person or something he kept pushing for us to get dessert and saying that we couldn't leave without trying it, etc... Very pushy, I didn't appreciate that so much especially since we kept telling him we were full. And he kept popping by during our meal to tell us not to fill up and to save room for the dessert. Geez! So that experience wasn't so good. Not sure if I'll come back here on my own to eat here, but of course if my company orders from there then I'll eat it.
author: Grace L.

description: I hate it when I wait a long time after dining somewhere and then finally get around to a Yelp review. Excuse the absence of specifics. What I do remember is having a pitcher of beer, a great soup appetizer, and a delicious pizza. Sort of pricey but there was nothing to complain about. Very tasty. I heard that a celebrity moonlighted here as a delivery driver. I gotta get that story straight to. I'd come here again in a heartbeat.
author: Marty J.

description: Love the crunchy thin crust pizza - one of the best slices in town !
author: Hetal S.

description:
New to the neighborhood and tried Goat Hill Pizza for delivery for the first time last night.  We will definitely try Goat Hill again, possibly seeing what it's like to eat there next time.  

I like that they have multiple vegetarian-friendly choices.  We got a large California, which had a chewy crust, was flavorful, and didn't skimp on the toppings.  The only thing that would have improved the experience for me if if the cheese was more uniformly spread across the pie.  A couple of slices were sorta half-cheesed only.  The side salad was better than expected because it included some garbanzo and kidney beans along with the lettuce.  Cheesy garlic bread was MMm MMm cheezy and garlicky -- definitely worth a try.  

Finally, my favorite thing about GHP is that it's really convenient to order pizza online.  Their time estimate for approximately how long it would take for the delivery to get here was good to know and (despite their disclaimer) spot-on.
author: Elaine S.

description: Best delivery pizza place so far! Ordered half pepperoni, half ck something plus hot wings. Very delicious!!!
author: Kim K.

description:
I had a birthday party here with a group of 13 people + 2 kids. The service was great and the food was excellent. We also ordered the family-style salad that comes with three dressings that each person may choose from. Too bad it wasn't one of the nights when Harold Bradford plays piano (I've been there on one of those nights); he beautifully performs all sorts of pieces from jazz standards to Rachmaninoff, and all by ear.

Everyone enjoyed the pizza and the waitress was really quick with getting us new pitchers of beer whenever we were running low.
author: Tomas P.

description:
Vegetarian pizza selection is outstanding!  The pizza crust is yummers.  Mon "neighborhood" all-you-can-eat nights are great, but one does have to wait a whiiiiiiiile, and the slices are thin enough that you're done as soon as the server turns around. 

The selection of beers on tap is a bit lame, though.
author: Vandana N.

description: Great place for families with kids. Quick service, great cold beer selection on tap and a perfect Hilda pizza with their Caprese salad. What could be better on one of those rare hot days in the city? We even got cool markers and the whole family drew together. Recommend going early with kids. The wait staff was super helpful and nice. We sat in the back room which I think is a little more spacious and better for the little ones......believe it or not this was our first time here and we will definitely be back!
author: Krisztina E.

description:
I want to really give credit to Goat Hill Pizza.  We had reservations for 20 people on Saturday afternoon.  Two days before that, I called and increased our reservation to 25.  That was no problem.  Because our activity before pizza ran long, the entire party showed up an hour late.  Also, no problem!

Service was GREAT! The food was GREAT!  The location was GREAT!  Pizza, salads, appetizers, beer and wine for 25 people came to $495 with tip.  That's $19.76 a person.  UNBELIEVABLE!  They even made extra space for all the toddlers in high chairs that have suddenly wedged their way into my social circle, lately.

I could not be happier with how my husband's birthday dinner went.  Everyone laughed, ate, drank and enjoyed each other.  Goat Hill was a great, laid back choice for a party of this size.
author: Amy A.

description:
This used to be our 'Go to pizza delivery' but something has changed :-(.  The crust is thicker n doughy, the pizza is greasy, and the toppings seem of lower quality (less flavor n greasy). 

We're pretty sad about it but after 3 bad experiences we are ready to move on. :-(
author: Lupe. M.

description: This is a good old fashioned neighborhood pizza parlor. Friendly people. Great pies. Cozy. We've been here several times enjoying the gluten free crust which is excellent. Also the standard crust is sourdough, so be prepared for a treat. Best night to come is Monday. That's all-you-can-eat night. 12 bucks per person, and they have a salad bar, and the servers keep bringing pies around offending slices to each table. It feels like the sushi boats of pizza. They hold the pie in front of you, you look, and if it strikes your fancy they serve you a slice. Really fun and gives you the opportunity to try many combinations.
author: Brian C.
