In fact, we tried to walk by on the way to coffee, but it smelled so irresistible I had to turn around and order some food instead. Being an out-of-towner, I'd recommend sitting in the back of the restaurant so you can admire the city view (if you look really, really hard, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge in the distance.) 

Although there were many, many options to choose from, we stuck with a large vegetarian with pepperoni for good measure. I love the corn meal crust, and the pizza itself is crunchy and not too cheesy. And they don't skimp on the toppings. Yum. Light on the draft been or wine offerings, but they have bottled beer to go (!) which is cool for a Colorado girl like me. I could swear I remember reading something on their printed menu about how they give a certain number of proceeds to a local charity, but I'm not finding that on their website anywhere.

Yay! I'm definitely a fan.
author: Laura L.

description:
Personal preference but im going 5 stars here! 

i work nearby so this is a joint i hit up regularly... maybe once a month for the most part if not more. They have a pretty popular all-you-can-eat event on Mondays, which i have tried on several occasions, but the pizzas they serve really are the stars...

i love going on Tuesdays and Thursdays? when they have an older gentleman who plays a mean piano through the night; great neighborhood feel! Most recent ive had was a bacon mushroom and red 
onion daily special! It was very very tasty!

I love this place enough to encourage fellow Yelpers to message me if they want more info on this place whether its about how the all-you-can-eat works or about other items on the menu!
author: Denny C.

description:
First off, I gotta thank Linda C.  for the great recommendation.  You're awesome!!!

Goat Hill is the kind of pizza parlor you can smell a mile away, but this is a good thing because their pizza is so good.  We had the Hilda's Favorite and Special Combo pizzas along with the salad bowl and garlic bread.  Both of the pizzas were delicious- I especially loved Hilda's because of the goat cheeze/pesto combo.  The salad was ginormous for one person but perfect to share, and the garlic bread was equally as tasty as the pizzas.  Also, Goat Hill has a great view of the city and super-cute pizza parlour table and booths, which are perfect for families and children.  Along with friendly service and numerous cute goat pictures, (I want a cute, little baby goat!!)  Goat Hill has fresh and totally irresistable pizza.
author: Shannon W.

description:
I would say 3.5 for this place. It's big and it's easy to get a table.

I like sourdough and I like pizza so it's A-ok to put 'em together!
author: Nikki M.

description: I've been a frequent patron of Goat Hills for quite some time only to call for delivery tonight and be told that as of a few weeks ago they have "stopped delivering to my area" no explanation or apology. I feel like the owners basically said screw all of our customers on that side of the city. There are plenty of other pizza places in SF,  ones where the owners aren't rich assholes who no longer appreciate their customers
author: Mark K.

description: This pizza is absurdly delicious. The sourdough crust is simply amazing. It really adds a unique flavor to the pizza. I always get a pizza here right before I head over to the Giants game.
author: Ryan N.

description:
The smell of this pizza place reminds me of the funk from Pizza Hut you'd encounter when going to redeem your BOOK IT! free personal pan pizzas as a child. Even the salad bar reminds me of the Pizza Hut experience. 

I went on a Monday for the all you can eat special with a large group of friends. The servers were all friendly and the price was reasonable so I have to cut them some slack at two stars. Overrated for sure.
author: Ian S.

description:
Mixed reviews. 

I like the pizza.  Like more than it probably warrants.  I really like it.  

And on neighborhood night I've only had an awesome time.  The place manages to be simultaneously bustling and cozy.  And they happily make vegetarian pizzas and bring them straight to you if you just tell 'em you're veggie.  

But last week I had dinner with a bunch of rowdy boys, and tho the pizza was spot-on, the service kinda sucked.  And then the server dumped a beer on my lap and handled the whole thing pretty poorly.  Sigh.

My solution?  Block this experience out and give four stars for the pizza and neighborhood night, which is the only night I think I'll be going from now on.
author: Dana S.

description:
It's about 2.45 stars,  so it's a generous 2 stars.  Yeah, there's an all-you-can-eat pizza night on Mondays, i know, i know, but eh, I wasn't impressed.  You get herded to the back like cattle where you and your friend are placed in a very loud, crowded atmosphere and really cannot enjoy a moment  (even with the beer) because you're getting elbowed every 5 minutes if you want anchovy and pineapple flavored pizza.  Plus, you cannot carry a conversation without the feeling that the world is eavesdrooping on everything.

You get these slices that wouldn't be large enough to fit a toddler's hand and then you take two bites and, like indian scalps, you toss them on your plate like a bunch of wartime kills.  The experience was a bit barbaric come to think of it.  Ironically, every fifth or six free pizza was a politically correct veggie pizza. Awe.

The good was that with the all you can eat pizza is a salad bar option.  The beets were very good..the lettuce was rabbit or turtle fodder at best though.

The beer selection on tap was horrible.  Where was the budweiser pitchers for $4.50???  I was forced to order these weird naming home brewed stuff that wasn't very good.  So what.  You call it amber instead of beer.  Where's the budweiser or miller?  I mean, if you're trying to lure in customers by having an all you can eat night..which implies the place is catering to cheap customers like I met then, why the hell are you going to sell overpriced foamy puff-stuff???  It really didn't make sense.

The service was so-so.  The bearded dude dishing out beer was an aquarius like oasis in that he got us our beer right when we needed it.  The friendly, homely hostess was ok too.  The pizza servers were hit or miss...I felt like a seal being fed sardines at a waterworld show or somethun....

In the end, this all-u-can-eat experience cost $10/head.  Which means in the end, you're paying Xtra large pizza prices at a fraudulent discount.  Once you factor in the overpriced beer, you're looking at $35-37 bucks again.  The same as any old pizza joint.

Now if it's $5/head for all you can eat and $1/head for all the beer you can drink, then, and only then, would I give this place 3 or 4 stars.
author: Tony U.

description:
Surprisingly, the thin crust pizza had a slight crunch and the meatballs with the spaghetti, which was cooked al dente, were tender and moist.  However, some of the pizzas, such as the Mediterranean, can be a bit salty.  Try the chicken florentine for a solid pizza even if it's still not made like that in NY.  

Neither the service nor street parking is too bad for its location.  There isn't much of an ambience or ample seating, but it's just enough for a small group to get together in Mission Bay.
author: Jenny L.

description: I have been coming to this Goat Hill locations for over 8yrs and have been a fan ever since. My kids love the pizza so we will will no doubt be coming back for more.
author: Sergio G.

description:
Thought you'd never find unique, fresh ingredients, and truly delicious delivery pizza?

Well, now you have! I just ordered a pizza tonight from them for the first time. I was first drawn in by the sourdough crust. Amazing!! Their cheese and sauces are so fresh - I felt like my pizza had been just taken out of the oven when I took my first bite...

Truly awesome pizza!! And super fast delivery!!!
author: Denise B.

description: Love the all you can eat pizza and salad bar on Mondays!  What a great idea.  The hard part is gambling on whether to take a pizza or wait and save room in your stomach for a better pizza that might possibly come out.  But the service is great and the waiters are really cool about letting you know about what pizzas might be coming up next if they can find out.
author: Maile T.

description: We ordered half a hawaiian and half a californian. Pizza was pretty good. Also ordered a salad for appetizers, most of the toppings were pizza toppings - mushroom, tomato, shredded cheese, etc.
author: Mario M.

description: Goat Hill is a solid 3.5 for me, rounded up cuz it's another solid option for lunch close by work.  Goat Hill uses sourdough for their crust and I like this because it adds a little crunch factor to their pies.  I usually stick to my normal ingredients of pepperoni, sausage, mushroom, salami.  They do have their own custom choices, however, including a Californian, a Mediterranean, a Portuguese, a Hawaiian, and a Greek.  They also offer an all-you-can-eat option on Monday nights.  Sadly I've yet to partake of this, but I fully intend to one of these days.  We used to get Goat Hill catered at work (from the other location) a lot, but not so much anymore.  What I've learned is Goat Hill tastes the best when eaten fresh.  Usually I'm a fan of cold or day-after pizza.  Not so much for Goat Hill, though.  I think it's something about their cheese that gets clunky when it's cold.  But if you do happen to end up with leftovers, my advice is to pop that bad boy in the toaster oven for a cycle to get the crust back to crunchy, then nuke it for a few seconds to get the cheese soft again.  Dig in and enjoy!
author: Joe M.

description:
Dude, they sold my friend a "Pint" of beer.  But it was a 12 ounce glass! 

That is taking advantage of people, purposefully no less, and it is morally wrong. You guys are making pizza which has a high profit margin and you do not need to take advantage of those very people which keep you busy and alive!  

Best damn pizza around though, and I'm from Jersey so I'm picky. 

You guys should get some real Pint glasses and not use those 12 ounce "Pint" glasses again.
author: Estelle Z.

description: I have had this diarrhea inducing "pizza" 4 times in my life.  I wouldn't feed it to my dog and he actually likes to eat poop
author: S M.

description: Great pizza. They really need to put some sound-deadening material in the back room. The dim is deafening at times.
author: sam l.

description: Goat Hill's gluten-free crust kicks Amici's gluten-free crust's behind! So nice to be able to meet friends for a pizza and actually get to eat the pizza!
author: Elli F.

description:
I usually frown whenever my work ordered pizzas for a lunch meeting because the pizzas they get were from crappy places like Round Tables or worst, Dominos. Yuck! After many rounds of complaints, they stepped up and brought in Goat Hill Pizzas. Yeah! Yum! 

I love Goat Hill's creativity used of ingredients. Their pizzas topping combinations aren't like the cookie cutter pizzas that you can find in every pizzeria. Goat Hill has some original pizzas combination that are so yummy. I love their Chicken Florentine, which has grilled chickens and spinach. Tasty and good for you. Their Californian Pizzas come with fresh tomatoes, artichoke hearts, my favorite and garlic. 

My male colleagues always go for the Meat Lover Pizzas that come loaded with 3 kinds of meats including salami, pepperoni and Italian sausage. That pizzas are always the first to go. I guess that's a real guy pizza. 

The crusts, which is a sourdough crust and I hate sourdough bread, but I love it when Goat Hill use it in their crusts. It's crispy, crunchy and moist. So yummy! Of course, their used of 2 kinds of cheeses -- provolone and mozzarella are the perfect melting and flavor combination. I don't always see goat cheese used in pizza, but hey, Goat Hill does it. Their Hilda's Favorite has goat cheese, pesto and fresh tomatoes and let me tell you, the tanginess from the goat cheese is actually very appetizing.

If you are looking for old schools toppings like the Hawaiian (ham and pineapple), or the vegetarian combo. 

Overall, great pizzas, they deliver 20 pizzas to my office and the smell is just so intoxicating. I think ordering Goat Hill pizzas is the best strategy to entice people to attend the monthly 3-hour long meeting because everyone just want to get their hands on some slices.  I know that's why I look forward to that meeting. Honest!
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
The smell that escapes this establishment will automatically force your tummy to grumble.  You will then be convinced that you are craving pizza and beer.  If you are lucky, and happen to be in the area on Mondays, you have hit the jackpot my friend.

Mondays at Goat Hill are fun...might I add...even more fun during football season.  All-u-can-eat pizza for $10.95!  I came here last Monday with a friend in search to do some damage.

***Tip no.1: If you get there before 7:30, you won't have to wait too long for a seat.*** 

We went around 6, and were seated quite promptly. Within a matter of seconds servers came by reciting what type of pizza they had in their hands.  Meat, veggie, pesto, sausage and olives, etc.  The list goes on and on.  

***Tip no.2: if the pizza of your desire is not coming around, you can simply as a server for it (i.e pizza w/chicken), and they will have the kitchen make one up.****

I just kept nodding my head, and the number of pizza slices on my plate multiplied.  Pizza in my face, cold Newcastle in my hand, and my eyes on Monday Night Football.  I was close to euphoria at that moment.  

Overall, Goat Hill Pizza is a great experience-especially on Mondays.  Their pizza is not the best (3 stars), but for the price and the experience they earned 4 stars in my book.
author: Maybelline C.

description:
Contrary to what others have written, it is really quite painless to order a pizza over the phone at Goat HIll.  You just need a little pre-call warm-up.  Practice screaming at a wall for a minute or two.  Now you're ready.  Being blind drunk and fixated on a nice pizza helps endure the misery of placing an order here.

It's actually a fun game to play while drinking on sat. night.  At 8pm call and try to order a pizza.  The longest hold time we got was a couple weeks ago a whopping 30 minutes.  The game really picks up speed when you call and they just slam the phone back down.  Around 10pm they might notice how low the tip jar is and take an order in hopes of a tip.  The game is over when you tell the bitch you already went to Good Life and bought four Viccolo's and cooked and ate them and you'll try calling back next saturday at 8.
author: Alex C.

description:
I order delivery from here regularly.
I like the regular cheese pizza with goat cheese the best, but I have tried almost all their specials, and everyone was delicious.
If you are looking for a good delivery pizza this is it. Not hard and chewy, or over doughy. Its thinner crust and has the perfect amount of cheese.

Delivery is quick, and they are always very nice.

A+++
author: Alyjaa S.

description:
I was never a fan of pizza until I went to NY last September and now I crave it all of the time. I've had some good pizza in LA (best one is probably Village) and when I moved up to the Bay, I was suddenly on a mission.

This place is legit.  I was in the area and decided to stop by.  I got two slices with mushrooms, olives, sausage, and pepperoni.  The ingredients were fresh, the sauce was good, and something about that crust!  It's like a true NY style in that the crust is hard from top to bottom.  Don't you just hate pizza that "flops"? 

My only gripe about this place is they actually messed up my order.  I was going to go back but said it smelled so good that I didn't care at the time.

I would def. go here again
author: Sean Y.

description:
Awesome crust and sauce. Incredibly fast delivery.

The Mediterranean had a bit too much garlic on it, but the salad/garlic bread were excellent.
author: S M.

description:
I live super close to Goat Hill, so this is always my default pizza place. Monday nights are the best - all you can eat pizza for like $11 or something. It's definitely a family vibe on those nights, but after a pint of beer that quickly seems less important. 

I love all of the flavor combinations they offer - from the vegetarian pizzas to pizzas inspired by places like Portugal. Their crust is really delicious as well. If I am not there on a Monday evening, the pizzas seem a little pricey...but hey, it still tastes great.
author: William d.

description:
Dear Goat Hill (Potrero) Phone Order taker,

I'm sorry for bothering you.  I wanted to know what your pizza of the day was -- I'm sorry I didn't hear you say 'phonenumberareacodefirst' you said it so quickly it flew by me.  I hope you can forgive me.  But good think you interrupted me and repeated yourself -- but then I had to give  you my number but without the area code.  Thank you for interrupting me to let  me  know that you wanted the 'phonenumberareacodefirst' and the first 3 digits I gave you was not the area code. I know that by not paying attention to your request that this completely ruined your day -- or at least your train of thought for the morning -- this was just based on your tone of voice.  

I realize that it must be difficult to deal with customers like me who ask so much of you which was to take my pizza order (a 3-item pizza right off your menu) so I could come in and pick it up.  

Again, I am so sorry I have inconvenienced you with my antics today.  I won't ever call and bother you with my pizza order again.

Again, sorry and I hope you have a better day after I completely ruined it.

...

When I came in to pay for my pizza you were glaring at me.   It seems you still have not forgiven me to ruining your day with my slow listening skills and my pizza order.   

...
author: Spicy T.

description:
Amazing place for a large group. I am talking 30+ people came for dinner/fundraiser and we got great service, hot pizza, beer, and wine all with smiles and for a good price.  

Of course we called ahead, which helps, and they had about 3 people serving us on rotation from the kitchen to our tables. Goat Hill has perfect seating for large groups and set us up at two large tables and two smaller tables in the back. It has a great city view and really good pizza. The Combination and Hawaiian were my favorites and everyone raved and fought over the Meat Lovers (with salami, pepperoni and Italian sausages). YUM!
author: Natalie N.

description:
Another pizza adventure for a self-professed pizza snob. We walked from Castro & 18th to work up an appetite for the Monday night special. When we arrived, the crowd around the place was quite large, but our party of two was called pretty quickly. 

The place is simple and cute inside. The salad bar was decent; as others have said, it's a nice companion to the pizza. 

We were probably there for an hour, and the topping choices only started repeating right at the end. As a vegetarian, I had quite a few choices, and it actually helped portion control to pass up the 50% meaty options. My favorites were the tomato/spinach with garlic cream sauce and the pesto pizza. The crust was good and the sauce was pretty tasty. Crispy, crunchy, no floppage. The cheese was unremarkable, but that's not so bad when the toppings take the front seat.  

Overall--it's fun to try out all the topping combinations on Monday night and the total bill is delightfully low. I will definitely be back at some point, and I'll walk again so I don't feel guilty for the carb-fest that will ensue.
author: Robyn M.

description:
My GF and I recently relocated to SF, and decided to venture out to Goat Hill based on all the good Yelp reviews.  We've been here three times now, and I can tell that it's going to be staple in our new-found Norcal lives. 

The sourdough crust pizza is just plain fantastic.  Each time we've come here we've gone directly to bed afterwards because of the intense food coma.  Around dinner time it's packed with a great family vibe, and my GF pointed out the back room is full of little kids artwork.  Cheap pitchers make it a great place to co-eat with friends, and the staff has always been courteous and helpful.
author: daniel v.

description: Goat hill has the most awesome Monday pizza deal. If you stayed long enough you might experience every kind of pizza known to the human race.  Start with a salad then the friendly staff bring the pizza to you.
author: Henry F.

description:
After picking up some concert tickets nearby, (courtesy of 
Craigslist), E-chan and I decided to stop in at Goat Hill for lunch.  We had passed by this pizzeria anytime we were in Potrero Hill and it was always crowded,  but not on this slow rainy Sunday which was lucky for us!

We had the minestrone soup, garlic bread and 2 mini pizzas of our own concoction.

One hour later...

We're in love!  Great atmosphere, great service and great food. We're on a roll this weekend!

5 starshines for being baa-aaad @$$!
author: Keika L.

description:
Went on Monday for the all you can eat deal, which is a pretty awesome deal for some tasty pizza. The wait wasn't bad at all, but we were only a party of two. 

The servers are quick with the pizza, almost too quick, but I get that they are trying to turn the tables. While getting pizza is not a problem, getting a pitcher of beer or your check was a bit more work. Doesn't seem like there was a server to manage the table, just servers running pizza. We asked the pizza people and they were happy to help, although gave the impression that it wasn't really their job. 

Anyway, fun place and good pizza. Will probably go again, even though it's trek.  My favorite pizza in the City is still Little Star.
author: Matthew P.

description:
My new favorite pizza in the city!! That's right, Goat hill- you're my number one! And I like pizza, so that's saying a lot. 

After working in Bayview for 6months (which doesn't have very many dining facilities), I ventured out to the goat. BEST DECISION EVER. The pizza was awesome. We got 1/2 Mediterranean, 1/2 special (sausage, onions and mushrooms- such a good combo)! 

When I picked up my slice, the tip didn't droop, the toppings didn't slide off. Is this b/c there were too few toppings? NO! it's b/c they know how to make a fantastic crust that can withstand the pressure of pizza toppings! The cheese was delicious and the crust was fantastic. (Why do I suddenly want another one??) 

The pizza was delicious! I could have eaten much more than I did, but tried to save my waistline a little bit... we all make sacrifices. 

I can't wait to go back for my next pizza! But the big question will be: should I get the deliciousness from last time or try something new? 

Go and enjoy- you wont be disappointed.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Went in for All You Can Eat Mondays with the Triple D's and had a good time. 

My two favorite pizzas of the night:
- The bacon + red onion pizza was fantastic... the bacon was not too "bacon-y", in other words - just because it was a pizza topped with bacon didn't make it a pizza overloaded by bacon. The bacon had a good meat-fat ratio.

- The chicken + spinach pizza was also fantastic. I'm usually not a fan of chicken on my pizzas as my experience has been that most chicken topped pizzas always have a marinade or glaze that is added to overcompensate for the dryness of the chicken; this was not the case. The chicken was tender but not drowning in other flavors.
author: Ed O.

description:
I love the all you can eat mondays, but I have had better pizza.
Update: 4-3-2007 - Same review.
author: Matt N.

description:
I love Goat Hill Pizza. 

The food is excellent. Their pizzas have all the usual ingredients and they have a couple of creative pizzas as well. This is especially apparent if you go for the $10.99 all-you-can-eat on Monday nights. On those nights you can help yourself to a salad bar in the back of the restaurant, but otherwise you sit at your table and the staff brings around pizzas and will offer a slice. It is kind of the pizza version of dim sum and it works. 

The staff here is very courteous and friendly. One time we had to wait a while for our pizza to come out so our waitress brought us a complimentary serving of garlic bread. 

This place is highly recommended. I eat there all the time. You should too.
author: Stephen G.

description:
Worst delivery experience ever, 2 times in a row couldn't get my pizza, not going to order pizza ever again.

First time, the rude woman on the phone got my phone number wrong and after an hour later, after my call, she sent the delivery person again. I waited half an hour more, still no pizza.. I called to cancel the already cold pizza, then she offered me a free pizza in my next order. Thinking good, wait...

I called today to get my free pizza and the guy on the phone told me, after making me wait for total 15min on the phone, said they have no record of my free offer and he told me to call back tomorrow like it's a clothing shop and I can just eat nothing and order my pizza to work tomorrow! 

So I never got my pizza, two times in a row, with really rude person on the phone.

They lost me. Hope they'll improve their customer service.
author: Ceren S.

description:
This place is clean, family friendly, and the pizza is really good. The crust is a medium-thickness, not paper thin, but not chicago-style either. Good balance of cheese and sauce. The toppings are top-notch quality and fresh. They have some unique topping combinations and the pizzas are reasonably priced. The pizza is no Little Star, but it's solid and the atmosphere makes up for it.

If you get a chance, do the pizza buffet. on Monday night.  I've done the all-you-can-eat pizza buffet on Monday nights a few times and it was amazing. They bring around different creative pizzas dim-sum style and you just pick and choose what you want to eat. Be warned however, that if you show up after 7pm, prepare to wait for an hour outside. Bring snacks. They have good beer selection, which is nice during that wait or with the pizza. They also serve pitchers. On buffet nights, there's also a small salad buffet with basic salad fixins- iceberg lettuce and various vegetables. The salad is nothing special, but then again who goes to a pizza buffet to eat salad anyway.

The atmosphere is nice- it's very family-oriented and I usually go with a group between 4 and 6 in size. The wait is usually reasonable unless it's Monday night. It's usually really warm inside. Sometimes a little too warm. Sit near an open window and be prepared to shed some layers
author: Tyler C.

description:
We would give them 4.5 stars if it was possible. 

Our excursion to Goal Hill Pizza was extremely enjoyable.  On Monday nights they have all you can eat pizza for $10.95. 

And, as one of our dining companions astutely observed, "It's not China Town."

The pizza was great.  The crust was a perfect crispy/chewy combination.  Getting to try all the different types of pizza was great.  The cheese pizza was my favorite.  The bacon and spinach pizza was described as "It's like bacon, not like BACON. Ooh, and there are some of the little fatty bits of the bacon too!"  



They would have gotten all five stars, but the servers seemed a bit stoic and humorless.
author: Triple D D.

description: Low stars as they haven't even responded to two phone calls I have made  this past week for a March 15th reservation for our first wedding anniversary. This restaurant has come highly recommended to us by two regulars so that's a bigger disappointment!
author: Maria D.

description:
Very happy with the folks at Goat Hill Pizza. I was here a few weeks ago, and wasn't ECSTATIC about the visit, but I came here with my hubby and 2 of our close friends. We were seated promptly on a Wednesday night. (There was even a small view of the city!) The servers were attentive and friendly. I drink a TON of water when I eat sodium loaded foods.. and my glass was never empty! (A+!) 

To the important part - THE GRUB! 
Brushetta - OMG.. SO GOOD. I could have  had brushetta all night.. it was seasoned so well. The bread was nice and crunchy, the tomatoes were fresh and .. MMM.. damn.. so good. 

Caprese Salad.. well, we were given olive oil and vinegar (on the side)with the salad, but we ate the salad without it.. because we thought it was already seasoned.. but after we all tried it.. we realized it had to be seasoned ourselves.. lol. So it wasn't a big hit, but that's cuz we didn't know any better hahah. 

I ordered a small vegetarian pizza.. I was trying to stay away from the saturated fat in pepperoni, although I LOVE me some pepperoni :( 
The pizza had the perfect amount of cheese, sauce and toppings. It would've tasted |_____| this much better if there were tomatoes on it! My fault, should have  asked. 

Jo ordered a full order of spaghetti w/ meatballs. The meatballs were yummy.. I tried the meat sauce.. it wasn't thick or meaty as I normally would like. So I personally wouldn't order the spaghetti here. I would stay safe and get the pizza. 

Adam & Mike ordered a XL manly pizza.. manly meaning the toppings were sausage, mushrooms, black olives and pepperoni. I tried a slice of their pizza and DAMN it was SOOO good. I was glancing at my vegetarian pizza a little sad, but happy that I had made a healthier decision.. haha. And then I grabbed another slice of their MANLY pizza. 

Whats even cooler, is they have a "Bakers Dozen" card. If you buy 12 pizzas, you get one free. Whoa.. I mean if you eat pizza as much as I do.. (okay 1x a month) but.. hey every year a free pizza?!! I'm in!
author: Alice E.

description: I live in the hood and have eaten here multiple times.  I would say it's average pizza.  Not thin crust, not thick crust, just average.  The smells coming out of this place are amazing, but the pizza never seems to meet expectations.  There just isn't a lot of flavor with their pizzas, it's pretty bland.  Use as as the Wednesday night pizza fix, but not as a destination restaurant.
author: Brett K.

description:
5 Stars, no ifs ands or buts about it.

Monday night's all you can eat pizza and salad bar (can't remember if drinks i.e. soda and water are included in the price) for $10.95 is nothing to shake a stick at.

The waiters and waitresses come around with all different kinds of crazy pizza concoctions as well as the classics, in pretty small slices so you can make sure that you get to taste everything. The salad bar is small but mighty.  I mean who doesn't enjoy a good salad with pizza? I know I do.

Also the easy to find parking, the atmosphere, the friendly and funny wait staff.  These ease with which you come in, grab a table, and as soon as you sit down you have the waiters with pizza in your face. 

A tribute to show just how busy they get on monday nights: 

THEY USE PAPER PLATES AT THE TABLE FOR YOU TO EAT YOUR PIZZA OFF OF.

The prospect of having to wash HUNDREDS of place is mind boggling, so they make the smart move.

Go eat at Goat Hill pizza, i promise you wont be sad after the meal, i mean unless you have detachment issues and have to wait a week to go back for the all you can eat madness.
author: David M.

description:
My favorite pizza joint in San Francisco, no question. But dig it, this is a traditional family-oriented pizza parlor. If you're a yuppie looking for a trendy foodie-fad hot-spot, Goat Hill ain't for you. Goat Hill's for folks who like a family-friendly place that serves a great pepperoni & roasted red peppers pie. 

Monday night is all you can eat pizza buffet for a reasonable price. A great way to sample a lot of different pizza combinations.
author: Bruce H.

description:
Gosh, maybe we just had a bad pizza or something, but crappy Round Table is better than this!  NO FLAVOR WHATSOEVER! 

Generic meat- not even the ground beef or Italian Sausage had any flavoring... I will give kudos to the crust, though, quite nice and crisp, but again, flavorless.
author: Beatrice K.

description:
This establishment is amazing. I love how down to earth it is. From the kids art on the wall to the extremely approachable wait staff. We had two pizzas and both were fantastic. 

If I lived in the neighborhood I could see this being once a week spot. One of the most amazing things happened while we were dining.  A well dressed man (tie and blazzer) sat down at the piano and started to play a few songs. Because it was Sunday afternoon and there were dozens of kids in the restaurant he was playing fun kids songs. Then after 5 songs. He got up and picked up two pizzas and a salad and headed on his way. I loved it!

Great food and low key ambiance what more could you ask for!
author: Ryan B.

description:
Love their crust - thin and crispy.  Chicken wings hit the spot as an appetizer and although I find their salads a bit boring, they have good dressings; that seem homemade.  I haven't expanded to other choices on their menu because I always just come for the pizza.   

Always good selection of wine and beer.  If you go often enough, you get a free pizza after your first 12 - great bargain and it came in handy the other night.

However, it is a popular spot for groups and families so don't expect a quiet experience - just enjoy it if you get lucky.  I like the atmosphere and staff for a family style restaurant.
author: Jennie M.

description: I know 4 stars seems like a lot. But There are so many things they deserve a star for. I live near by, when friends visit they always want to go here. I love their house made thousand island dressing - it so good I dip my pizza in it. My friends who like Ranch and blue cheese say they are awesome too. The staff is friendly and they really care about what they are doing and the people they are serving. Monday night all you can eat is famous and really good. It is a great place to come for lunch and I get take out a lot and it is always ready on time.
author: Kristian M.

description:
I absolutely love the sourdough crust. This is what you call San Francisco-style pizza AND they have all you can eat on Monday nights which I actually haven't tried yet but will soon. There's always plenty of seating so I enjoy going there to eat and starting with the salad which is filled with all sorts of goodness - beets, pepperoncini peppers, beans, etc...

Unfortunately the last time we came in the server that helped us kind of seemed like she was more annoyed and bothered that we walked in the door. I think she was having a bad day or maybe something happened that put her in a bad mood. I'll give her some slack since by the end of our dinner she warmed up to us.
author: David C.

description: All you can eat pizza Monday nights is awesome!! Servers come around with the pizzas and serve you. They have a wide variety of pizzas to fulfill everybody's taste buds with quality ingredients and thin crust. Full self-serve salad bar included. They also have beer by the pitcher and a decent selection. Great friendly service! Monday nights are busy because of the AYCE so get there early!
author: Linda C.

description:
So it's not your California reinvention of the sparse Roman wood-fired pizza, but with a sourdough crust and a room full of historic photography, it's uniquely San Franciscan in its own right.

It's not quite as good as Arizmendi or Cheese Board in the East Bay, but seems to me related, only with more toppings.  The atmosphere is fun - maybe too fun for a large group of post-college bros in the echo-y back room.  The view of the city from the table by the window made up for their existence.

This is great Monday or Wednesday night pizza.  I went on a Wednesday but have heard about all-you-can-eat Monday, a concept which personally frightens me.  But maybe some day soon I'll bring my pregnant friend.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza is definitely worth a visit anytime, but especially on Mondays. Pricing is very reasonable for unlimited pizza and salad and everything is really yummy.

The staff here is excellent - some of the best I've seen in the city. At first, all the pizzas coming our way had meat on them so we asked one of the servers if there were more veggie pizzas coming our way. He told all the other servers that we were vegetarians, so not only did we get tons of awesome veggie pizzas coming our way in minutes, but we also didn't get offered any more meaty pizzas. 

Our experience was great. It's got a great homey feel and really good pizza.
author: Dana M.

description:
All you can eat pizza every Monday night!!! I have to keep myself from going EVERY monday night because how could you NOT love just sitting there while they bring pizzas by???

You have to get there early though because it's popular and there's usually a long wait, and they will not seat you until your entire party arrives. BUT, it's worth it!

Sitting at your table all you have to do is say yes or no as they come by with fabulous varieties of pizzas to put on your plate. And even though the crust is so good, we've found that not eating the crust gives you more room in your tummy for more slices of pizza! HAHAHA yes we really do that. And no we don't bother with the salad bar although they have one because why waste your time on the salad when you're there for the pizza? 

Goat Hill Pizza, I've spent many Monday nights with you, always leaving happy but so incredibly full that sometimes it hurts to move. But I will keep coming back because I love it that much.
author: Monica P.

description: Hi Philip D, we were about 10' away and that's not how Jason approached the family's table. Also, I think if Jason apologized decently, the family wouldn't have left and I def would not have written what I did. He barely apologized at all, let alone "profusely." It's great you're backing up Jason, but I'm not sure how identifying him by name is helping him at all. In any case, defending him against a customer when it was pretty obvious he was in the wrong is only demonstrating the type of customer service that is condoned there.
author: Mike S.

description:
Great place.  Not a rockstar, but always very dependable.  Old reliable.  If you want some classic thin crust pizza that is much better than Dominoes, Pizza Hut or even Papa John's then try this place out.  

It also helps that this place is literally located 1-minute walking distance from me.  But that doesn't sway my stars at all, I'm just offering full disclosure.  Just saying...
author: Yup S.

description:
They're now on Twitter too:

www.twitter.com/goathillpizza

Mmmm, can't wait to get sourdough crust updates in my timeline.
author: C P.

description:
As if it's not crowded enough on Mondays... 

I will still tell you that Goat Hill's "Neighborhood Night" is the best. For $10 you get all-you-can-eat pizza and salad bar. Such a deal! 

They have at least 6-8 kinds of pizza throughout your meal and each is so tasty. It would be great if they had a few more veggie options, which is why I didn't give them 5 stars. It's such a great deal. 

Show up before 6:30 and you won't wait long.
author: annie s.

description:
Quite decent pizza - more on that in a moment.  

Great location on Potrero Hill, watch your neighbors saunter by along with the comings & goings of many 22 Fillmore buses.

Service - lazy!!! although they realized it, apologized profusely near the end of our visit and stepped it up several notches to prove they could pay attention and treat patrons well.

Now - back to the pizza.  We chose the X-Large Meat Lovers pizza pie.  Crust is sour-dough and had good crispy texture and no soggy parts in the middle.  Meat was heaping quantity of nicely flavored Italian sausage & Pepperoni.  Good ratio of quality cheese to hold and balance all that meat.  A+++ for flavor.

We saw the 'side' of meatballs go by.  it looked great - we'll be back to try that!
author: Lxs S.

description:
OHHH BOY!  Talk about delicious.

My boyfriend and I did a home exchange in Potrero Hill last week from Chicago and this was the first place we went to when we got into the place.  It was like a beacon of light in the dark Tunnel of Hungry.  We ordered a large Greek pizza and we ate all of of it but two slices!!!!!  They also have a veggie cheese option which is fantastic!  This place is PERFECT for vegetarians- they have lots and lots of veggie delight toppings and yummy cheeses.  Also, Mondays are all you can eat pizza and salad for $10.95.  The beer 6-packs were DIRT CHEAP...this place rocks.  Bottom line.  

Best recession-buster.
author: Jillian K.

description: Definitely a fan of Goat Hill Pizza! Came in today for a work lunch after volunteering. Waitress and staff were super attentive and kind. All the salads, pizzas, and pastas we tried were exquisite! Crust and toppings were well done. Bravo Goat Hill Pizza! Thanks for a great lunch and experience.
author: Noora T.

description: Great tasting pizza in my hood. They sell slices too!
author: richard d.

description:
Damn good pizza.

We always order the Mediterranean pizza when we're feeling bad and have zero desire to eat in. It's a cute-friendly neighborhood pizza place in good ol' Potrero Hill.
author: Mary Anne R.

description:
Every so often, Boyfriend and I rent a car. On these special occasions, we go out of our way to get things that our usual lack of transportation prohibits. This is how we found ourselves at Goat Hill pizza last weekend, thanks to the Mini Cooper that was temporarily ours. I was excited to try the pizza that Boyfriend had raved about (his work is within Goat Hill's delivery radius) and I thought I'd leave the ordering to him.

"Medium Chicken Florentine," he told the girl at the counter.

"Wait, are you sure that a medium will be big enough?" I asked, in a mild panic.

"A medium has eight slices," volunteered counter girl "it's perfect for two people."

Now, I would usually use the word "Bitch" numerous times in the following transcript of my internal dialogue. But the counter girl was so sweet and friendly, I cannot bring myself to call her "Bitch," even for dramatic effect. So I am going to say "Nice Girl," but try and imagine that I am saying it with the emphasis and intensity of emotion that using the word "Bitch" would convey:

Nice Girl, you clearly do not know me. You obviously have no familiarity with my appetite or the amount of pizza that I can consume. Do you not tout yourselves as San Francisco's best pizza? Are you telling me that you think I'm only going to want four slices of San Francisco's best pizza? Now I'm either gonna not get the amount of pizza that I want, or I'm gonna have to say in front of Boyfriend "sorry, I'm a big fat pizza pig and I need the largest fucking pie you have to fill my trough!" Congratulations, Nice Girl, you just sold less pizza.

But every slice I ate (six, 'cause I pull more weight in this relationship) was spectacular. Their crust is amazing and the quality of the ingredients was fantastic. Next time we rent a car, I'm gonna go straight to Goat Hill, walk up to Nice Girl, rest my gut on the counter, and order an extra large Meat Lover's with onions.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Got the Veggie pizza to go. I'm more of a thin-crust girl so the crust was a little too thick for my liking.

It smelled amazing in there when i went to pick up so i had very high exceptions for my pizza. I wouldn't say i was disappointed, but just not that impressed.

It's near the crib so i'm sure i'll be back.
author: Rana A.

description: Monday is the day to visit!  All you can eat  salad and pizza for about $14 all-in. They bring out all different topping varieties and you can pick what you like as they come around.  Very yummy!  Recommended.
author: Peter B.

description: Great pizza, great salad and great beer!  Went for the Monday night special all you can eat pizza/salad which was definitely worth the price (although it's $11.95, not what's listed on their website).  Offered a wide variety of options, service was stellar, and left in (remain in) a food coma - we'll be back:)
author: Laura K.

description: Went on a Monday night - all you can eat pizza and salad - It was awesome. The waitstaff were all really nice, the food was great and in general there was a great ambiance.
author: Alex S.

description: I'm not usually a crust eater, but I am here. This is my favorite pizza place in the entire universe. Why? Because they load up each inch of pizza with an admirable portion of toppings.  When I ordered a two-topping slice, the vegetables to cheese ratio was finally correct (something I never thought I'd see in my lifetime).  There weren't speckles of mushrooms and spinach scattered about, but instead there were towers of these flavorful delights.
author: Jaime L.

description:
At last a good delivery place in SF - only 2 years trying lots of rubbish before I discovered Goat Hill Pizza - yeah 

I was drunk and ordered the Special Combination medium pizza and I thought it was fab.  My friends who were sober and who had better judgment than me, thought it was really really good as well and we all agreed that this is now the only place which we will ever order from again.  Hopefully they live up to all my expectations when I order pizza again.

The crust was think, crunchy and delish.  The toppings were super fresh and plenty-full but the pizza didn't feel super overloaded either.

ITS LEGIT.

They do charge an additional $3.50 for delivery which adds to the cost, but I will pay for good pizza and there are far too few places delivering good pizza.
author: ORLA L.

description:
It's no Zachary's... but I'm an East Bay girl through and through... and nothing comes close to Zachary's. 

This place is pretty amazing though! Came here after a very long work day--ordered a small "Hilda's Favorite" (goat cheese, pesto, fresh tomatoes), and Chef's Salad with Garlic Bread. The salad was HUGE for $8--and totally fed three people. The pizza was a little greasy, but really tasty... two of us split it, and even had a few slices left to take back to work!

While it's still no Zachary's, I will definitely be back next time I'm in the city!
author: Jessica J.

description:
It's been a long time since I had a pizza that I actually put down mid-slice and asked myself "can I finish this?" Normally, I will eat 1/2 a of a large pizza in one fell swoop into my mouth. Goat Hill now takes the award as the worst pizza I've had in recent memory.

The crust was decent (and probably was the only edible part of the pizza). The cheese was gloppy, greasy and weird, making me think something had actually gone wrong in the pizza-making process. So, I put the first slice down and didn't have any more.

Lucky for me, I ordered a salad and a side of meatballs. Or not. The meatballs, while just okay, probably were 40% fat. I'd be happy to pay an extra dollar for you to use 80/20 beef next time. And the salad was bland and I was actually a bit scared of eating the sliced chicken breast that came on it. It looked like it had just sat out for a full day.

Sorry. Never again.
author: Jonathan T.

description: This is my favorite pizza place in the city so far. Not only is the pizza good but enjoying the remaining crust dipped in ranch at the end if every slice is delicious. I make this a regular meal on my cheat days.
author: Kevin W.

description: Pizza has always been a staple in my family and it's one of my favorite things. Since becoming self-sufficient and having more options, I've started eating the hoity pizzas - thin crust, deep dish, meats sliced fancily thin, artisan cheeses, pulled pork with guacamole, smoked salmon with crema, and, my personal fave, anything with farm eggs baked on top - combinations that really do call for each slice to be eaten with the pinky up. While the gourmet pizzas have their proper place, nothing quite matches up to the good ol' basic pizza pie, which is what Goat Hill serves up perfectly. I love their homemade sourdough crust, familiar menu options, and the comfortable homey-ness of the place. My personal favorite is the Meat Lover's, inhaling no less than 3 slices, with ranch dressing. =)
author: Queenie C.

description:
We just moved here and received a coupon for a free large pizza with 2 toppings... Not knowing much we order a pizza for delivery. The person taking the order was very pleasant. I told her we had a coupon and she said no problem the pizza is in us.. 
Well it was great.. crispy crust with plenty of toppings and fast delivery.

They now have a new customer!!
author: Robert O.

description: Asian food is the food I crave, period. But then we were on our honeymoon for five weeks in Southeast Asia (food heaven), and I wanted my first meal back home in the Bay to be my usual from Goathill: Vegan cheese pizza with spinach, tomatoes, and chopped garlic. *Love* this pizza- it is perfection! And I can't give enough stars for having vegan cheese- hurrah!! Bless the person whose brain child that was!
author: Emi I.

description:
We used to ALWAYS order pizza from here at my old work. The location is wonderful and it's set in the corner of a big old Victorian house near the Anchor Steam brewery. The inside is very pleasant but I've never actually sat down - just gone in for pick-up. You can get all the standard pizza toppings and combinations but they have a few special items that they're particularly proud of. The pesto, veggie, and Mediterranean are all pretty amazing. They also have vegan options but I'm not really into that. The sourdough crust is good, but my only complaint would be that the crust is too thin and the toppings a little bare...you can eat more slices than you think because there's not much there!

Yummy quirky little Potrero Hill staple.
author: Alexander M.

description:
I may have to qualify myself, as did previous reviewers, as an East Coast pizza snob.  I very much prefer the New York style.  That crust: thin and chewy, maybe just a bit crunchy, is what I like.  
GHP does a good job in that regard.
The sauce is tangy, not too sweet.
The cheese is nice and greasy.  "Put down that soy-milk cheese and back away from the pie."

The atmosphere is great.  Maybe that's the red-and-white checkered tablecloths?  

And yes, I would go out of my way to eat here since there are precious few other pizza parlors I'd care to frequent.
author: Ken B.

description:
Delicious! 
Goat Hill Pizza is absolutely amazing!
Two thumbs up! 
We had a work party lunch and orders 4 pizzas & 2 salads!
We ordered a Hawaiian, a Combination, a Chicken Florentine (my favorite) & Meat Lovers!
We also got a chef's salad with fresh feta cheese & the salad bowl! Both come with some finger licking garlic bread!
I will definitely be returning for more sourdough pizza!
author: Stephanie M.

description: Love Goat Hill! We always place large orders for my office functions and they deliver on-time and the pizza tastes yummy! Friendly service and tasty food, thats what its about. Recommend trying the pizza!!!
author: Desiree T.

description: The pizza wasn't bad, but it wasn't especially memorable either.  You might want to pass on their buffalo wings. They were, by far, the worst wings I've ever had from a pizza joint.  Unless you find the idea of dipping nearly solid chicken fat in ranch appealing, I would make another choice from the menu.
author: Jake G.

description:
Good pizza with a regular pizza place atmosphere. No smiles from the staff when we walked in, but we got a table by the window which was great spot. Too bad it was next to the evil squeeky door of doom! 

The server was sweet and the food she served was "A-OK." We got some delicious minestrone, a medium pizza, wings (which were bad. I'm from Buffalo... I know wings, and these were BAD). We ended up taking a few slices home, too because medium is a lot for two. 

We'd ridden the bike over so she packed them up well and the food didn't drip in my backpack. They were good later when I ate them cold with the rest of their homemade creamy blue cheese. 

I'd go again if it was the the only thing open, but 18th is chocked full of better places.
author: Jan W.

description: Goat Hill Pizza produces wonderful pizza.  The crust is spot on.  The ingredients are fresh.  The only way you can go wrong is to come here if you don't like pizza, even then you may become a convert.
author: Harry B.

description: I loved this place. The sourdough crust was delicious and the caprese salad was fresh and tasty. Service was terrific and fast. I would absolutely recommend it for a fun, delicious, neighborhood pizzeria that is awesome with kids.
author: Adrien L.

description: Delicious chicken wings, but the pizza was a little too salty.  I did discover that pizza crust dipped in ranch dressing is quite yummy!
author: C L.

description:
i know there's a lot of controversy about pizza here in san francisco.  thin crust, chicago-style, east coast... it's a pizza war!

but regardless of your preferred style of pizza, good pizza is good pizza.

and goat hill is good pizza.

i am a huge fan of their style of dough and crust -- the dough seems to cook perfectly so that the bottom gets crispy but it is thick enough that it doesn't feel like you're eating a cracker... and the crust stays doughy and delicious.  the sauce is saucey enough and the toppings taste fresh and are plentiful.

recently i went to goat hill and my friend and i split a large vegetarian and we added pepperoni, pineapple and roasted garlic (this is our signature pizza wherever we go).  we also shared a salad and this was MORE THAN ENOUGH FOOD.  we finished the salad and each took home 4 slices of pizza.

+ ample seating
+ beer!
+ delicious food
+ all you can eat monday's for $11 (never gone but i would imagine it gets packed)

+/- feels a little pricey but the pizza is so good i kind of don't care

- street parking can be tricky
- lots of hills so if you (or someone you're with) is not a stable walker, drop them off and have them put your name in for a table
author: Lauren P.

description: Ordered a medium italian sausage mushroom pizza and chessy garlic bread... both good.  Garlic bread is very garlicky so be warned.  Delivery was fast  - they quoted an hour and it was here in 35 minutes.
author: Traci C.

description: One of the best pizza spots in the city, hands down. Look, this isn't Delfina or Gialina, and it's not  trying to be either. This is sort of an old school family style pizza joint, with the red checkered tables and friendly, unpretentious service. Goat Hill reminds me of family owned joints on the East Coast. You also can't beat the sourdough crust!
author: Nick H.

description: The best neighborhood pizza you can find.  We create our own pizza with pesto.  They keep our recipe in their data base, so when we call to place our order they know exactly what we want.  They are also very consistent, when we order to go and when we eat in, we always get a good pizza.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
love their pizzas! i can't get enough of Hilda's favorite-- with pesto, goat cheese, and tomatoes!

=8)
author: Grace M.

description:
Fine budget pizza place for families.  We went there because we moved to the neighborhood recently and had heard people mention Goat Hill Pizza.  I was so excited to try it.  When we arrived on Friday evening around 6, we got a great table for 2 with a view of the city.

However, within moments, the place filled up with a million children and tweens and I felt like I was at Chuck E. Cheese.  So much for a relaxing dinner.  I figured that the pizza would be out of this world so I soldiered on, mentally.

We had the caprese salad, which was ok but I could have made the same thing at home.  The pizza we had was half cheese, half med.  The med was better but too heavy on garlic.  The cheese side had a slightly overpowering taste of oregano.  The texture of the pizza and crust were good.  I had high hopes for a very sour, chewy sourdough crust but it didn't have much zing.

Overall a fine experience.  I might try take out or dine in on a weeknight.  My thought is to reserve this place as a go to spot when my friends from the suburbs come to visit with their kids.
author: E C.

description: When I lived in Pot Hill this was my neighborhood pizza joint. The sourdough crust was deal closer for me....that and the pesto sauce. All you could eat pizza on Monday nights was an occasional bonus. I would mainly order pizza for takeout and walk down to pick it up. One of the best slices in the City.
author: Anthony V.

description: Not my favorite pizza. It just doesn't taste that great to me. Their all you can eat night is a fun idea though.
author: Olivia P.

description:
How much do I love this city?! Everything I ever wanted...can be delivered!

Monday evening we have a meeting in Potrero and I'm craving pizza.  I suggest going to Goat Hill.  There's a ton of people waiting outside so we go somewhere else (later to find out Monday night is all you can eat pizza night.)

Tuesday my nephew and cousin are coming over. I said I'd order pizza. Look on Yelp - Goat Hill Pizza delivers!  Whoo hoo!  I call...and 45 short minutes later, my extra large half-combination, half-vegetarian pizza is here!  Like I said, I love this city!

The pizza...excellent crust, a ton of toppings, a lot of cheese...and super garlicky ranch.

We also ordered buffalo wings - will probably skip that next time.  But definitely won't skip the ranch.

Me + Goat HIll Pizza = Super Happy Christine
author: Christine O.

description: I just wanted to add that I finally tried the pasta one night when I wasn't in the mood for pizza, and their spinach ravioli is delightful! The house-made meatballs really made the meal. Just wonderful.
author: Cattie P.

description: A fun place to go on a Monday night for the all you can eat special. A SF classic. Nice selection of pizzas though I wish they had more vegetarian options and that they had green leaf or romaine lettuce (or some other real green option) other than ice berg at the salad bar.  The staff is a lot of fun.
author: John C.

description: great pizza and also caters to people allergic to dairy!
author: Ace S.

description: Really good pizza. Very cool decor and neighborhood. Best. Side. Salad. Ever. At. Pizza. Place. Ever. :)
author: Ramin R.

description: I gave this place a bad review a while ago. But I ordered it tonight and it was pretty good. The pizza was great but what I really like about this place is the sides. They have great salads and awesome garlic bread (the sides were even good back when I gave it a bad review.)
author: johan b.

description:
So tonight my friends and I went to "neighborhood" night at Goat Hill. Its eleven dollars per person all you can eat with a full salad bar.
 Aint bad right?!!
 Well, not bad if you seriously enjoy black olives. They come around to your table all night with different trays of pizza. Sadly my conclusion is that they top the pizza with all the shit nobody orders all week long.
 "Anchovies, black olives and pinapple" " Black olives, sausage and green olives" "Black olives, black olives and black olives." 

I was lightweight over it. 

BUT IF YOU ORDER it aint bad. Infact, its pretty good.
author: Liz C.

description:
Very good pizza, and they actually deliver! (As a recent transplant from the Northeast I am finding out that apparently most places in my area don't deliver. Not nice news for my lazy ass.)
In any case, haven't been to the place in person, but the delivery people are quite nice and they arrive in 30 minutes or so, as opposed to the 45 minutes to an hour they normally quote me. 
The pizza is quite good, if not perhaps a little on the chic side. By which I mean very wholesome, fresh, and classy. That's great. But I cannot, for the life of me, find a proper, greasy, will-probably-kill-you-by-40 New York slice. 
That's not Goat Hill's fault; I'm just saying that I have a craving for pizza that has not even a soupcon (dammit, no cedille...) of nutritional value. If someone knows of such a slice that's actually good, PM please -- I might reward you with a picture of a shiny nickel.
author: Graham S.

description: Monday night All You Can Eat Pizza was fantastic! The choices are really creative, delicious, and NOT just cheese or pepperoni (even tho those are available too!) Some of the types of pizza included: basil, goat cheese, and garlic; linguisa sausage, red onion, green onion; beef sausage, olive, and onion; the list goes on! The quality of pizza was truly up to par and nothing was lost with the "all you can eat" quantity needed. The salad bar is fresh and has many toppings. I highly recommend Goat Hill Pizza for the all you can eat Mondays or the usual deliciousness everyday!
author: Jamie O.

description: I grew up down the street from here and I have to say I ate alot of  different pizza but goat hill pizza is the brst ever thats y its only 3 world wide I believe always hot never wait to long for the food to be done also try the hot wings they smack man I wants some now lol.....kind pricey but worth it
author: Aaron J.

description:
Monday night all you can eat pizza at Goat Hill could be a contender in what I will foresee-ingly call the "obsesification of Beah." 

Nice people walk around with pizza pans and offer you delicious slice after slice... Yank Sing, do yourself a favor -- take a line from Goat Hill -- serve us some goddamn PIZZA. Dim sum is so last decade -- the future is pizza. And candy. And Agave sweetened cream soda. Are you confused? It's complicated.
author: Beah B.

description:
Went for lunch with co workers. I ordered the sandwich lunch special. The salad was ok - the lettuce wasn't ass fresh and was browning. However, the sandwich was huge, full of toppings. 

I will be back to try the individual slices next time.
author: Brian W.

description: This is THE San Francisco Sourdough Pizza joint. Sourdough pizza is definitely an acquired taste, but I think it is safe to say that if you don't like Goat Hill Pizza, you probably don't like sourdough pizza. This place is a great place to get a beer and a slice or have a nice family dinner. All of their slices are freshly made and although it may take a few minutes for them to make you a to-go slice, you will be glad you didn't pick up one that was sitting under a heatlamp for who knows how long.
author: Dale S.

description:
Realizing that Little Star and Pauline's Pizza are BOTH closed on Mondays, my pizza connoisseur friend and I go to Goat Hill, NOT a second fiddle choice at ALL - but 'that's life in the big city' as my crazy-ass sophomore year college roommate from Manhattan(that's why she was crazy) used to say - I was more than happy to Goat Hill it.  Was that a run-on? oh fuck it!  it's about the food, right? rrrrrrrrrright.

Tonight, I felt like it was the best idea anyone ever had.  It was my second time there and I wondered if anyone else had thought of that glorious idea of serving people JUST as they sit down.  It's so new millennium. . . waiting for anything is just so 90's.  The pizza is always hot of course, and crispy the way pizza should be served.   They're not afraid of jalapenos and they have a decent side salad bar.  Five Stars.... more to come on my Pizzas Around SF Tour.  Not to be confused with the How to Gain 1000 Pounds in Ten Days tour.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Pizza is not a gourmet food.  It was never meant to be a gourmet food.  It's a peasant food.  That's a good thing.  San Franciscans should get their head out of their behinds and stop lifting their pinkies when they sip from their overpriced lattes.  When I was wee lad, my family would order from the local pizzeria every Friday.  It was called Guy's Pizzeria.  They made one thing there: pizza.  It was owned by Guy DiMaggio and his wife.  Guy would flip the pizza dough into the air.  He was an immigrant and spoke broken English.  My father loved the dude because he was salt of the earth.  If Guy ever came to San Francisco he would be disgusted with about 90% of the pizza here.  How do I know this?  Because I am disgusted by 90% of the pizza here.  

Goat Hill does not disgust me, but Guy would still be disappointed.  The pizza here is thin crust, but not truly Neapolitan.  The toppings are not overwhelming, but there are still too many.  I have never, and I mean never, understood why San Francisco pizzas are so overloaded with toppings.  Goat Hill has too many for a native East Coasters, but not as many as most California pizza places.  

What I did like about Goat Hill is that it is a pizzeria and not a pizza restaurant.  There is a difference.  It also is nestled on a great corner with some great views.  Go to Goat Hill, grab a pie and then go to Bloom's and have a beer.  Wear jeans and t-shirt and leave your lap dog and Yoga mat at home.
author: Chris I.

description:
Have you ever tried to reheat eggs? Rubbery. How about garlic bread? Burnt or chewy.  What about asparagus? Overcooked. Pizza?

Wait, what???Pizza??? That food some people eat cold and like? That food that still tastes relatively good after 30 minutes in a delivery drivers car with one of those sad red bags that they try to pass off as an insulator? That stuff you can pop in the microwave or toaster oven without being the least bit sad you are eating leftovers?

Not this stuff. You have one shot to enjoy your pizza here. One chance and that is it. In the restaurant, straight out of the oven, preferably on a night when you can graze the different kinds (aka all you can eat night). Once this stuff cools down even 10 degrees it just doesn't taste that great anymore. Don't even kid yourself that warming it up will help. All that does is bring out the grease you didn't notice the first time around.

You have been warned but also keep in mind that, like eggs, it is good for about 15 minutes after being cooked.
author: Drue C.

description:
GREEDY PEOPLE UNITE!!!!

All you can eat pizza on Monday night for $11 bucks.  At first I was disappointed with the small slices they were passing out.  Little did I know that this allowed me to try the different pizzas they offer instead of being stuck with a huge slice of pepperoni.     

It's not like Pizza Hut where you go up to the bar and serve yourself.  They will bring the pies around and serve you at the table.  Works better and the pizzas stay hot.

Fun with a group and I enjoyed being able to sample pizzas I probably wouldn't order on my own.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
It was going to be 4 stars for yummy pizza.  But after reading all the reviews and finding out there is all you can eat pizza Mondays...hell yes ill give em an extra star!  

Who's comin with me!
author: Lauren F.

description:
Call it gluttony or call it bargain shopping, but all-you-can-eat Monday nights at Goat Hill Pizza (for under $10!) are a good time.  I think you have to understand the atmosphere to get the most out of it, though.  Here are my observances:

1) It will be crowded.  -- This weekly event is no secret, so you might have to wait a few minutes for a seat.  And the dining environment is cozy and lively (i.e., loud at times), but that's part of the fun.

2) You can't wait for the perfect pie.  -- The wait staff will bring out pizzas in pretty random order.  There are plenty of vegetarian offerings if that's your thing, but aside from that, try not to be too discriminating about toppings, because you'll never get fed.  All of their pizza is good, so just keep trying things as they come around.

3) Plan to spend some time. -- The pizza slices are small, so if you have an appetite like mine, you really need to just make an evening of it.  :-)  You can ask the waiter for two slices at a time and they'll oblige, but that might be considered impolite, so I stopped doing that.   Just order a pitcher of beer, sit back and enjoy the experience.

4) Don't forget the salad!  -- They have a table set up with salad and lots of fresh "fixins" (olives, tomatos, etc.) that should not be missed.  It's a great start to a great meal.

I hope you all enjoy this place as much as I do.
author: Andy G.

description:
I was born in Philly and educated in New York, so it goes without saying that I'm a pizza connoiseur. My friends would say snob. It's gotta be thin crust, and for heaven's sake, no chicken! And Indian pizza? Don't even get me started.

Luckily, the first time someone took me to Goat Hill (before I lived in the neighborhood), I didn't know about the sourdough crust. It was a Monday night - when they do it all you can eat, dim sum style (I'll get back to that) - so I never saw a menu.

I should point out that I have a very sophisticated pizza rating system. Basically, a 1 to 10 system for:

1. the crust
2. the sauce
3. the cheese and other toppings 

So the highest possible score is 30. Goat Hill gets a 10 for the crust. The highest rating. Sourdough crust. The pizza snob in me is completely flummoxed by this.

Anyway, go on a Monday night. Be willing to wait for 20-30 minutes. Monday is dim sum pizza night, where the servers walk through the joint armed with every kind of pie you could want. So sit back and let the slices come to you.
author: Shawn S.

description: I love all types of pizza but there is nothing really exceptional about Goat Hill.  The crust is good but a little too much cornmeal.  The toppings are fine but disappointed in my last order for a meat lovers pizza.  It was mostly covered in beef and very little Italian sausage and pepperoni.  The beef was very greasy so the pizza was oozing grease. I also asked for extra cheese but it was not cheesy at all. In fact their was more sauce than cheese.  That pizza cost me about $25 for a medium pizza.  I think I would do better at Whole Foods or even Costco for what I received.  We also had lasagna with meat sauce. Another disappointment. Very greasy.  It's one thing to have lots of olive oil but this was just poor beef(meat) quality.  I had to settle for making my own lasagna a week later which is made with a bechamel and ricotta with spinach and prosciutto.  I think that was my last visit to Goat Hill.  $55.00 later and we didn't eat in.  Ugh.
author: David C.

description: I thought this was supposed to be one of the best pizza places in SF but what a disappointment!!  The pizza was just mediocre, the dough was not nearly as good as everyone said it would be, the buffalo wings were tasteless, and the salad was disgusting- wilted lettuce with a bunch of beans and green onions does not a salad make!
author: Maxine S.

description:
Recipe for a fat kid:

1 part lonely only child.

1 part living two blocks from Goat Hill during formative years.

1 part sourdough crust.

Shake.
author: Megan W.

description: I came here with my friends because my friend had the groupon deal for it. This was also my last American meal before going to HK for 5 months, and I was not very satisfied. I was quite happy at the beginning of the meal before the food came because I saw drawings on the wall done by students of the elementary school I attended. I haven't visited Potrero Hill since, but it got me nostalgic; however, I was unimpressed when the food finally arrived.  I never would have thought I would eat pizza that I thought was bland (I usually eat things that are pretty light), especially the sausage. It was the pepperoni or salami on the combo pizza that made up for the lack of flavor. The chicken and spinach mushroom was even more bland than the combo pizza and a little soggy :/ I don't think I would come here again, but we passed by a few other restaurants that I want to try such as Chez Papa!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Sourdough? Pizza? WTF!?! It's like I woke up and moved to California! Erm... yeah, where'd the last 8 years of my life go? 

This is not good pizza. It's not absolute trash either, so you won't want to punch yourself in the mouth after you eat here. We had some nice lunchtime adventures away from "real work" here, so nostalgia manages to pull Goat Hill out of the pit of one star reviews.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description:
This review is for the pizza that was delivered to me. I have never stepped into this place  (but it looks really cute from the outside)

I was getting burnt out on Amici's for I went ahead and called GHP. 
I didn't know they charged you a small price for delivery, it kind of fried my ass, but at least they did tell me when they discovered that they never delivered to me before...

It was a good pizza. Although I do agree with an earlier review from Corinna P. about the crust. It is more of a sourdough style and it is mouth full. I usually give my crusts to my dog, I tried to but he didn't like them and left them on the floor.

The actually cheesy goodness portion of the pizza was good. The toppings were good and they tasted very fresh. Will I order from them again, yes.
author: Christine S.

description: I only come in when that hottie waitress with the bangin' bod is working. I think her name is Rachel? Oh, and the pizza is good, too.
author: Megan S.

description:
Great Pizza! Prices are affordable but the service is THE WORST!
What a grouch the lady in the front is makes your meal so not enjoyable, uncomfortable, and awkward.
author: Amy A.

description: Although the idea of pizza dim sum sounds good in theory, it doesn't work so well if the pizza's only mediocre. By pizza dim sum I mean Goat Hill Pizza's legendary Monday nights where they bring around different platters of pizza cut into tiny slices, and you're free to eat as much as you'd like.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Awesome pizza and cerveza in P. Hill.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Goat Dick Pizza

After waiting nearly an hour we received a distress signal from the pizza delivery guy. It turns out, the delivery douche was ringing the doorbell at the wrong house. 

Ten minutes later.....he finally walked to our crib, which was next door (apparently confused by the advanced numbering system of addresses), nearly toppled down the stairs and handed us our cold pizza.

Based on his glazed eyes and awkward body movements we concluded that he was either stoned or retarded. My dreams of having a uber erotic porn scene with the pizza delivery guy are crushed. I got sausage, but it wasn't nearly as erotic as I'd hoped.

Thanks for nothing, Goat Dick Pizza.  Me, my vibrator, and cold pizza will sit this one out.
author: Angie O.

description:
This pizzeria is just OK.  I went here with a coworker of mine for lunch during the week a few months back.  We were greeted with a bad attitude from the only waitress who seemed to want to carry on her conversation with her friend instead of take our orders.

The pizza came and it was overly chewy, there was too much sauce on it, and the cheese was greasy.  I could barely even eat what was in front of me.

2 thumbs down.
author: Kathleen B.

description: This is not New York style pizza.  Not even close.  That being said, for San Francisco it's really quite good.  The sourdough crust is tasty and the toppings are always good quality, whatever you choose.  The soups I've had have all been good and the bruschetta is really outstanding.  I get it every time I come here.  You really need to like garlic though as there is a LOT of garlic on there.  They do dim sum pizza on Mondays.  I've never been there for that as there is always a wait but I like the concept.  It's a good place for kids (I don't have any yet) so that means the atmosphere is a bit lacking but hey, it's a pizza place.  And a good one.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
If you absolutely LOVE pizza, you have to go here especially on a Monday Night!  

Monday night is "Neighborhood Night" from 5-10pm where all-you-can-eat pizza and salad is only $10.95.  You don't pick your pizza at a pizza bar, the food comes to you.... It's like pizza dim sum.  The waiters go around with different kinds of pizza for you to choose from...  What a great idea!
author: Noreen M.

description:
When we walked into Goat Hill pizza, I had a strange feeling there was something a little different about this place, but I couldn't quite put my finger on it.  The hostess also sat us in the bay window, telling us it'd be quieter there and giving us a knowing look, but I still didn't get what she was talking about.  Finally, after about 20 minutes I heard an ear-piercing shriek, and it dawned on me: there are children here!  And not just one or two: it was pretty much families at every table.  I guess for me, children are not to be seen until heard.  Why is Goat Hill the happening family spot?  Beats me.  Maybe P-Hill is the new Noe or something.

Anyway, the pizza itself is delicious, and I especially recommend the linguica, a portuguese variation on pepperoni that's full of spicy, earthy flavor.  The pizzas are deceptively dense and filling, too.  The wife and I split a 12" which looked almost too small but, in fact, we could barely finish it.  I'll definitely have to come back for the Monday night all-you-can-eat that Ed speaks of.
author: Wes M.

description: Been wanting to try this place for awhile now. So wish it was better then it actually turned out to be. The sauce definitely lacks flavor. The crust is slightly better then the sauce. All in all a very lackluster pie. And so the hunt for delicious pizza contines...
author: Ericka A.

description:
What's up with these reviews and the crowds that swarm here. 

Pizza tasted so bland and fake. Chicken tasted like from a package, crust had absolutely no flavor. 

Service was shotty at best, they always seemed rushed to get you in and out and it wasn't even a full service. Waiter set water pitcher on table while he helped another table. Had to constantly ask for water refills.

Do people not know what pizza is supposed to taste like? I'd rather go to Domino's than here, at least there's flavor. With all the good options in the city, don't waste your time. Way over-hyped.
author: Eric M.

description:
3 for the general restaurant experience.  Not sure it is as good as the rep, but the Monday All-You-Can-Eat deal is great for the family.  Staff is charmingly surly at times, but seems to be the Potrero Hill standard.  

1 more for their community involvement and local feel right in line with other 18th Street establishments.
author: Bruce R.

description:
I think I might actually have something to contribute to the ethnography of Goat Hill, in this the trillionth squared review of Goat Hill. First however, I will join the masses: yummy! Crust is the foundation for good pizza and this one of my favorites. Chewy but with a crunch, distinct but not overpowering sourdough flavor.

Now, my 5 cents (you've heard they might be eliminating the penny, will all advice be worth more now?). As a lactard, I order my pizza sans cheese. Which unfortunately is not an option when you order by the slice. Here the cheese is a mozzarella/provolone mixture, provolone being an aged cheese, therefore less lactose (um probably not much of a difference but I will rationalize where I want to ). Also the amount of cheese is fairly light compared to many pizzerias. 

What else can I say? The lunch specials are a great deal. Slice (cheese plus two toppings) and salad is what, 5 bucks? The iced tea is amazing! Now that we've gone enough the waiters just know to bring us a pitcher. The one negative: I might bring a sweater, even on a warm day I feel like I'm sitting in a fridge. Albeit a dream fridge stocked with excellent pizza and iced tea.
author: Hallie R.
