description: What a shame.  Keeps you on hold forever and then won't deliver to my house well within their range but south into Candlestick territory rather than west into Pac Heights land.  Then they hung up on me.  Pizza may be good but customer service SUX.
author: Elizabeth Y.

description: My husband and I got take out from Goat Hill tonight. We've heard about Goat Hill a few times and decided to finally try it out while watching the SAG awards. We ordered a Bruschetta and the Calfornia for pick up.  I usually like more tomato sauce on my pizza so I asked for extra sauce. so two mistakes for my first time eating at Goat Hill: I had my pizza/bruschetta slighty cold and I asked for extra sauce.  The bruschetta was a bit too garlicky and the bread got a bit soggy so it wasn't ideal.  And the pizza had a LOT of sauce (my fault). And it was also super garlicky.  The sauce was actually really flavorful and the crust was a thicker crust  and pretty tasty, but a bit hard. It grew on me.  Not my favorite pizza in the city, but happy we tried it!
author: Eleanor C.

description:
UPDATE: 4/08

I've been here for dine-in a couple times since my original review and I must say, it's getting better and better every time I go. The waiter we had was FANTASTIC. I couldn't ask for better service. I love the pizza, but if you're not a huge fan of insanely fresh and strong and loads of garlic, don't get the garlic topping. I must have had crazy gas for three days after I ate this pizza. Good thing I have Gas-X. Ha ha ha.

Original Review 8/07

As I walk towards Goat Hill Pizza, about a block away I start smelling the dough and pizza sauce. Mm-mm, so good! We checked out a few of the other local places, but just wanted to grab and go to my house a few blocks away.

Ordered a medium Hawaiian to go. I'm probably not even supposed to compare these, but they are much better than any frozen kind or partially fresh. It's a little pricey to me, but they really weren't stingy on the ham or pineapples. SO worth it!

I really want to try a different pizza with Goat Cheese on it. I didn't see anything like that on the menu.

I'm kind of craving it now. Dang it.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
I was house sitting in the neighborhood this weekend and needed to sample the foods of Potrero Hill.

I ordered pizza from here the first night with my sister. She got a meat, meat, meat pizza which was awesome and I got a spinach, feta and chicken pizza and I LOVED IT! The delivery guy was sweet and didnt mind that my dog greeted him at the door. 

The best part of this pizza is the crust! I later found out it was sourdough crust, homemade! YUMMY! Of course I ordered enough for breakfast the next morning, that is a real test of good pizza. I can honestly say it was just as good at 7am as it was the night before!
author: Alicia K.

description: A very "OK" pizza. Not sure if I'd go back having Delfina and Little star also close by. The bruschetta was great though. The caprese salad was good.
author: Diego E.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza has grown on me. Seriously, I actually didn't like the pizza at Goat Hill at all. I was all about North Beach. Of course, I lived a block away from North Beach, so how could I not love it? 

Last weekend, Goat Hill Pizza won over my heart. I often order delivery, but we decided to sit in and eat. We had a very typical order: pepperoni & sausage pizza with cheese garlic bread. 

The pizza was fantastic! The sauce was flavorful, and well balanced. The pizza was perfectly cooked, and the overall taste was excellent. Probably due to the fact that it was fresh from the oven and didn't need to be transported like when we order delivery. 

Garlic bread was OK, a little burnt on the corners, but overall good. 

Will for sure give Goat Hill another visit next time I ain't feelin' like cooking. Not that I do that often =)
author: Michael M.

description: Minus one star because I was told at the restaurant that they deliver to Twin Peaks, and when I called this weekend in the midst of my bronchitis was told they do not.  Very sad day.
author: Nora S.

description:
On Monday night, it's all-you-can-eat-pizza and salad bar for $10.95. It doesn't get much better than that. If you can tolerate the crowds and oodles of kids, you will dig this place. An amazing view to boot! Pizza dim sum is the best way to describe the way the pizza arrives at your table on Monday night. You sit while the staff brings around various styles of pizza for you to feast on. 

Do arrive early to avoid an excessive wait.
author: Kathleen N.

description: GHP is a delightful meal.  Been twice now and it's officially my local pizza.  Nothing spectacular, but if I'm not in the mood for either searching for parking or the huge calorie load that Little Star entails, this totally works.  We request the dough be thinner and cooked extra crispy and this gives it a great crust (I'm a fan of either super thin or ultra deep dish, crusts in between just bug me, but luckily this place will customize for you).  Theirs is actually a sourdough crust, which is sooo San Francisco.  The salads, bruschetta, and eggplant parm were all tasty too.  Medium pizza and a 32 oz Rogue were $32.  Not the cheapest place around, but decent.  The wait staff is really small, so it's not the speediest service, but once beer is in hand I'm not really minding a wait....  Plus is had the great feel of a total local vibe.
author: Monica R.

description:
SERVICE - timely and efficient

FOOD - I wish we can choose the crust thickness but they have 'standard' cornmeal crust.  I enjoy the Mediterranean topping. 

Chicken Wings- Needs to be less soft. 

KIDS/ADULTS all-you-can-eat on Monday nights 530-10pm.  $10.95/per adult.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Three words: Sour Dough Crust.

Maybe not the best pizza I've eaten in San Francisco, but they do it RIGHT. I'd go back to Goat Hill anytime.
author: Pete J.

description: the sourdough crust is a nice touch. Solid pizza
author: Robert C.

description: We recently ordered 3 pizzas to be delivered to our office in downtown SF.  Someone mentioned that we should try the goat cheese pizza and it turned out to be a hit.  Delivery was faster than expected as well.
author: Vivek P.

description:
Pizza in San Francisco is fast becoming an art-form.  Only NYC rivals what we have here.  But the pies they make at Goat Hill lack in every way.

We ordered two different pies and both fell flat; the pizza i get frozen or at COSTCO taste better.

So so many options to good pizza I don't plan to go back here.
author: G R.

description: The pizza was delicious. It was a little soggier than regular pizzas since whenever I would try to bite it, the pizza would all fall apart. But I guess thats why they give us forks and knives for a reason right? Hhahaha (:
author: Claudia M.

description: We have been on the hunt for good pizza out here since we are spoiled back home (if you're looking for a good pizza place in Ventura County go to Toppers)... Unfortunately we have been let down over and over but fret no more! This often overlooked place was just what we were looking for! We had driven past it so many times but never thought to try it. We are so glad we did. Our waitress was really attentive and nice even though it was sort of busy and she was totally accommodating when I unlocked the garlic bread offer. Um by the way, yes it was freakin good too! The prices are fair for SF standards, the pizza is so good and not greasy (yuck!) and the service was tops. We found our new pizza place :)
author: Dalia W.

description:
me and my friend were picking up something from around this neighborhood. he kept talking about pizza the whole car ride.. and wouldnt take his eyes off this restaurant as we were driving by.. he reversed around the corner and then did a u-ey in the intersection after i told him that we should just try it. haha

we ordered the chicken florentine with feta cheese. it took a while to come out but it was oh-so-good!! chicken, mushroom, spinach and feta cheese! what more can you ask for! =) 

i'm sold.
author: JUDY L.

description:
Ha! Like there guys really need *470* reviews...
Well, obviously it's for a reason.

My lady Morgan was visiting from Colorado, and this was to be our last dinner together! So she, my partner and I ended up there last night.
There was a huge line waiting to get in the night before, so we called to reserve a spot... When we arrived, to our relief, it was not at all packed. Yay!
Great view of the Heart of Potrero Hill if you sit up front. We were jazzed by the sounds of the Piano being played directly across form us.
The staff was great. Attentive, but not at all to the annoying point.
They had a decent bottle of chianti on sale for only $17, we went for it.
Really yummy salad with olives and Kidney Beans.
The Chicken wings were decent, but I thought they could have been cooked a bit longer. I will just request that next time.
THE GREEK PIZZA! MmmMmmm... Flawless.

The price was quite nice for the qulity of food as well!
I will go back for sure.
author: Kellie P.

description: NOM NOM NOM! Sooo Good!  Had a small pizza pep and mushrooms and garlic bread with cheese OMG it was amazing!
author: Amy R.

description:
I'm boycotting Goat Hill Pizza.

I used to order from here all the time, and I do like their pizza.  However, after eating with a large group there for a friend's birthday I will never order from Goat Hill Pizza again (and certainly won't go back).  The staff were so unbelievably rude, it almost felt like some kind of a joke.  I thought maybe at some point someone was going to wink at me and say, "Just kidding!"  Every person we dealt with there was rude and condescending.  Hey assholes, you work at a pizza place,  I don't know what you have to be condescending about?  It seems like they are allergic to making money- if they'd treated us with respect we would have ended up spending a lot of money there and tipping generously too.  I hope that the management reads this understands how repellant the attitudes they must condone there are.
author: Sheila B.

description:
'All you can eat' Monday nights!  Not too shabby for not-too-bad pizza.

"Quantity has a quality all it's own." -- Joseph Stalin
author: Bruce L.

description:
Maybe I'm crazy, but this place isn't that great.  The olives on the pizza are low-quality generic canned ones.  The wings (not pizza) are frozen, soggy and not fried.  

Neighborhood night is fun, but it's hard to get a slice with their service.  Last time I was there I actually saw one of the waitstaff eating tacos rather than anything from the GHP menu.  I wish I had had some of his tacos... *they* looked great.
author: Alex D.

description: I am a big fan of the All you can eat pizza on Monday night.  Kids are free too up to the age of 6 or so.  I get to feed the entire family of ravenous monkeys for cheap and enjoy the neighborhood atmostphere.
author: Eric J.

description: Awesome place.  We had our new years eve dinner here. Order two different pasta dishes with meatballs. Really good sauce and meatballs. Garlic bread was excellent. They played great 80s music and the server was very friendly. It was a nice low key way to dine for new years eve in a nice quiet section of the San Francisco.
author: Jon D.

description:
Since I'm on a roll reviewing pizza places...
I think it's great they let you stand outside with a drink while you're waiting forever for a table. And it's cute they offer salad when your sole purpose us to eat as much pizza as possible to start off your work week and vow not to have carbs for 5 days. As I like to describe monday nights, it's like pizza dimsum and they walk about with trays, spouting off the ingredients, you nod or shake your head with mouth full and eat as fast as possible so there's still room on your plate for something you haven't tried.  I usually compete with my opponent about how many we can eat, s/he loses count and then I have an extra plate piled with crusts, declaring that I'm the winner!!!
author: Kim G.

description:
Going to Goat Hill on a Monday night is like going to a pick up bar - rather than trying to pick up on men (or ladies, depending on your sexual orientation), you scope out the pizza that comes around. You see a sexy slice you like? Ask for it and you'll be cheerfully given one. No awkward conversation, no spending countless dollars on drinks, no creepy guys coming on to you. The pizza never talks back. 

This is how dating should be.

You can be as promiscuous as you want - I've had dates with plain, mushroom, veggie delight and pesto slices all in one night and never felt guilty the next day.

I'm not afraid to admit I'm a slut when it comes to pizza, especially on Monday nights...
author: Sean G.

description: Best pizza I've had in SF, hands down. Yay! I'm a fan.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Most importantly: TOTALLY awesome pizza. Crunchy, flavorful, substantial.

But. The hostess tonight? Freakin' CLUELESS. Like, we walk in, she's on the phone and clearly doesn't see us. So we wait. Then she gets off the phone and starts gabbing with the staff in the kitchen, who keep POINTEDLY LOOKING AT US while she's talking, clearly trying to inform her that, like, you know, she had customers and stuff. Then she turns around and starts sorting menus or something, still completely oblivious. Finally one of the kitchen guys comes out and very tactfully informs her we're standing there. HAH.

The lady who waited on us--I think she was the owner? Was a total sweetie. No complaints about anything else, and we'll definitely be back, and frankly, the whole "wow, dude, you really just DON'T GET IT, do you?" experience was actually pretty funny.
author: Lynae Z.

description: This is really good pizza.  Not New York or Chicago style though, its a more vernacular style of pizza.  What's great about it is the crust is light, but still crusty and substantial, and the toppings are good.  Also try one of their salads.  The Chef's salad is hearty and filled with a wide variety of goodies.  I love the homey pizzeria feel of the joint, with their wood slat floors and the upright piano in the corner. Very cool. Cute little old fashioned "to go" boxes.
author: Rick H.

description:
I'm tempted to NOT write a review, because Goat Hill is already crowded enough on Monday nights, when we go for "dim sum pizza"--their all you can eat, try lots o' different things, wonderful pizza experience. Great thin sourdough crust, family-friendly, chaotic and busy, hard to park honest to goodness great pizza.

Ok, now that I've said it, stay away. I want to make sure there's not too long a wait when we go on Monday evenings.

Everything we've tried has been great. Their house red wine ain't bad either. And the price for a family with li'l ones (under 12 yrs) is a-okay.

Had to re-up my review and raise to five stars. I haven't found a better crust anywhere.
---
UPDATE: Weren't you listening? I said Stay Away! Place is even more crowded now, and we've got to get there even earlier on Mondays. Geez, people. Try Tuesdays, why don't you?
author: Doug B.

description: Food is tasty and the vibe makes for a fun meal out. Very kid friendly! I have been a handful of times on weeknights in the past couple months and every time I have gone it's been packed! I have had to wait up to 25 minutes to be seated which is fine, but when I sit down I would like to not have to wait an additional 10 minutes to be waitered on. That's not so cool. Last time I went I saw my waiter a total of 2 times. Once to take my order and once to bring me my bill. The thing that irked me the most is that it took 35 minutes after I finished my meal to get my bill and pay. I should not have to ask staff members more than twice for my bill.
author: Michelle G.

description:
orgasm in pizza form.

So I live in the neighborhood and have been eating here since the time of  high chairs, and never have I found a pizza that was more delicious. Now that I've moved away to college, I spend my days dreaming about the wonders that were Goat Hill Pizza. My favorite was to make my own pizza, and after years I finally perfected the perfect toppings (feta cheese, spinach, mushrooms, and sun dried tomatoes). The crust here is always crunchy, never burnt, and never flavorless. Some people complain about how they use spices, even on just a run of the mill cheese pizza. my response to that, is go call dominoes if you want a tasteless pizza. Goat Hill Pizza will stimulate your taste buds, and leave you hankering for just one more slice, even long after you've become full.

This place is also in a good location (no, not just because I live a few blocks away). It is conveniently located just 3 blocks from The Bottom Of The Hill. So if you go to concerts there, take a short walk up the hill, get a slice to go, eat the slice on the way down, or while standing in line for the show.
author: Allyson S.

description:
All you can eat pizza is always a good thing, but it's 100 x better when you're eating really good pizza.

Monday nights, all you can eat. Do it.
author: Wes F.

description:
Goat Hill is fantastic. Where do I begin...

As has been mentioned many times in these reviews, every Monday they have All-you-can-eat pizza night for $11. So every Monday, my friends and I (it's a growing contingent, this week was 10 people) head over to Goat Hill.

Man, you won't be disappointed. It's a smorgasboard of tomato/bread/topping goodness. The worst part about the place is how good it smells. Standing outside the door, as the scent of sun dried tomatoes and garlic and bread waft by, is pretty tough. But once inside, you're rewarded nearly instantly, as the staff are constantly walking by and offering up slices.

Contrary to some others, I love the staff. They're happy to take special pizza requests (they even accommodated my pineapple and anchovies, mmmm delicious!) and pleasant.

Now, an anecdote. My first time at Goat Hill wasn't on a Monday, so we ordered a pie for the table. About 10 minutes later, they brought out a pie for us. It was close, but it wasn't ours. We told them, and the host instantly offered us a pitcher of beer (umm..sure...would have settled for nothing!) and brought out the correct pie about 40 seconds later. I love the place.
author: Evan G.

description:
Finding new pizza places that are as good as Goat Hill really makes me happy. We went here last Saturday at around 8pm. It wasn't super packed and we got a table immediately. The host and waitress were both super cheery and friendly. It was like going to eat pizza at your uncle's or something. 

THE PIZZA WAS MMMM DELICIOUS. We did a "make your own" style in the small size (for 2 people) and it was perfect. If I had more of a stomach I coulda ate much much more. 

Monday night is neighborhood night there. Pizza and salad galore for everyone at about $11/person.
author: Ash G.

description: My work has ordered this pizza numerous times over the last year.  I have to say that I have always loved pizza with a cornmeal crust.  Like Round  Table used to do.  Well, not anymore.  Thank you Goat Hill pizza for making my pizza California style that not many places do anymore.  Keep it up.
author: Ray A.

description:
My favorite Pizza joint in San Francisco hands down. All-you-can-eat Mondays is one hell of a deal, but the real gem at this place is the supreme which comes loaded with an impressive amount of meat and vegtables and a nice touch of garlic. 

I've also had a few of the Italian dishes from Goat Hill and was very impressed with the quality of the ministrone soup, which a special someone has coined the "Best in San Francisco." 

I was dissapointed to see Michael Bauer diss Goat Hill about a month back in his Pizza Fridays review series. Michael, please go back, check it out . I think people tend to overlook San Francisco for Chicago and New York - but this is really a great pizza town and Goat Hill is one of the best!
author: Dave M.

description:
Save your money.

I bought a three topping small pizza tonight and it cost almost $19. The crust was thicker than the cheese and toppings. The toppings had almost no discernible flavor. When I picked it up and saw what I was getting for my money, I said out loud, This is $19 worth of pizza? The cashier just glared at me and gave me my change. There are many places in SF to get pizza. Try a different place. I know I will.
author: Paul L.

description:
Casual and comfy, down-home pizza joint!  

4.5 stars for their Monday night all you can eat deal!  It's fun- waiters come around carrying all different kinds of pizza, drifting around to each table, and you can ask them to serve you a slice of whatever serves your fancy.  Also, all you can eat salad bar.

3.5 stars for regular dining- the staff are super nice, but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here. Also, I'm an East Coast pizza snob...the pizza is good but not great.
author: Hella M.

description:
Thank you!  It was here when I realized how stupid I have been.  It was here when I got to wonder...

"But Jackie, the last time I slept with her was before I was monogamous with you...you have to believe me.  She didn't know about it until recently."

I mean don't get me wrong, 5 months?!?  Shouldn't you know by then?  COME ON?!?!  Either that or you were creeping around the whole time we were supposed to be monogamous.

What I was thinking as he told me all of this (in order):
1.  I could cut you
2.  Do you think I'm fucking stupid?  I know you're not telling me everything...
3.  What?!  You've known about this for 2 weeks already?!?!
4.  Ugh, I really can't hate the girl.  It's not her fault, it's yours you douche-bag!
5. Once an asshole, always an asshole.  They will never change!  Everyone was right about you this whole time.
6.  ....where's the ranch?  

Also, It was here when I realized that I am officially a fatass because after absorbing all of the information in one sitting, I still managed to finish my delicious jalapeno, garlic,  sun-dried tomato, mushroom pizza.  Where most people would lose their appetite, I took my anger out by inhaling my food like a monster.  

Of course I plan to go back here.  If it wasn't for the delicious food and big portions, I would avoid this place where I am reminded of such bad memories w/ this douchebag that I wasted 5 months of my life with.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: Nice Monday Buffet of endless pizzas, decent salad bar too.  Nothing spectacular, however quite good tasting pizza slices.
author: Jim J.

description:
Goat Hill serves gluten free crusts supplied by Mariposa Bakery and it's one of the best gf pizzas I've had. I was told measures are taken to avoid any cross contamination.

See my full review and more gluten free restaurants in SF here: http://gfinsf.com/2011/07/goat-hill-pizza/
author: lauren v.

description:
Excellent pizza.  Toppings, crust, sauce all work great together.  The sourdough crust is AWESOME.

Screw ny style...  this pizza KICKS ASS.
author: shaun l.

description:
This is my favorite pizza in San Francisco.  I'm a little biased because I grew up on the stuff, but there's something about it.....

I love the neighborhood feel of this place: the dark wood, the red and white checkered tablecloths, the old photos of Portero Hill, etc.  

There's more great things on the menu than the pizza!  I'm a fan of the minestrone soup, the house salad, and the spaghetti (with or without meatballs).  Don't come here and expect find dining.  It's comfort food with a laid-back atmosphere.
author: Kerry D.

description:
The pizza was just ok.

FOOD: ~At the Yelp Elite event, I think I tasted all the pizza samples: olive, mushroom, pesto, cheese, pepperoni. Each piece had only one topping, & some of them were hard, while others were nice & warm. I thought it was simple, pretty average, & if you know people will be yelping about it, why don't you bust out your BEST? The menu offered more sophisticated topping choices, yet I felt like I was at dorm night back in college with the 1-topping pizzas. I've heard good word of mouth, but I'm less incentivized now to check them out at their home base.

~Meatballs were awesome! Menu said 2/$3.50, although for that price I think u should get 4 of those bad boys.

BATHROOM: n/a

OVERALL: Good, decent, but not amazing.
author: miss b.

description:
Not bad. I just hope that waitress(owner?) washed her hands before she carried our drinks with her thumb right in it.

And man-handled our pizza.
author: Ben S.

description:
Oh my god, this pizza is freaking good.

On top of unbeatable prices and damn good food, they have an "all you can eat night" where you pay $9.95 and get all the pizza and salad you can stand.

It's in the hidden section of Potrero Hill quite close to Farley's. A definite must try.
author: Liz L.

description:
Goat Hill is perfectly acceptable - not spectacular, not bad. Tasty pizza!

Went with the kids - they're given washable markers and the placemats are plain white paper. Yay!

We got a small pepperoni and a  medium half mushroom half cheese. A bit greasy but tasty! 

I got a Chef's salad with garlic bread, ranch. Plain, large, just ok. Definitely get pizza :)

Bowl of clam chowder (specials board)
 - rich, tasty. Ate a pepperoncini first so can't assess full flavor just yet. Tasty, nothing super special. Tender clam. Cream a tiny bit curdled. But tasty.  

Attentive service, not overbearing, pleasant on a calm but not slow Sunday night. They got a nice dinner mini-rush while we were there (1730-1845).
author: Eugene A.

description: Service is pretty good. They use WAY too much salt. That's all you can taste. We ordered the beef raviolis in pesto and a medium thin crust supreme. The raviolis came completely drowned in pesto which was so salty that it completely obliterated any other flavor. We had to scrape off all the pesto to make it half way edible. We had asked for the pizza to be well done and extra light cheese. It came soggy with grease and covered with gobs of cheese. And again, all we could taste was the salt. It tasted like they had poured salt all over it. Ugh. Restaurant prices for hole in the wall taste. Not going back. Goat Hill has gone down hill.
author: Edward J.

description:
Goat Hill is very good pizza albeit simple.  Last night we ordered an extra large half Mediterranean and half Pesto Plus.  It was the perfect amount for four adults with a salad (we made our own - their salads are pretty mediocre).  The feta cheese on the Mediterranean was super great and the tomatoes on the Pesto Plus rocked.

One problem: even though I ordered over the phone a half hour ahead and confirmed I had the right number (they have another # for deliveries), when I arrived they had no record of my pizza.  I think they got names mixed up because someone else's pizza with a similar name was sitting there.  They had to remake mine as I sat there - about 15 minutes.
author: John V.

description:
God, I hate their pizza, but ironically, I will only eat it on Mondays for all-you-can-eat.  Everything tastes better when you can eat a ton of it.  Ok, maybe not EVERYTHING.  I bet poop wouldn't taste good in tons.

What definitely would taste good in tons is the dressing from their salad bar on Mondays.  Is that dressing homemade?  I love it!  

Bottomline: Go here for the value on Mondays.  I felt that I was on Check Please! Bay Area for a moment with that last statement.
author: Kim S.

description:
Definitely your "neighborhood joint" - very casual and low key. If you're lucky, you can get a table with a really great view of the city! 

But anyway, onto the food: the Salad Bowl with garlic bread was fairly decent and average. We ordered the Chicken Florentine pizza: a combination of grilled chicken, spinach, and mushrooms. The crust was perfect, not too crunchy and not too chewy either.

Overall, good dining experience.
author: Monica N.

description: Love the pizza!! Their ranch dressing is amazing! I put it on my salad, garlic bread and pizza!
author: David G.

description:
Goat Hill manages to distinguish itself from the other  desirable pizza establishments in the city(Escape from New York, Orgasmica, Little Star all come to mind) by its unique signature sourdough crust, which is quite tasty and balanced in texture and thickness, and its homey and spacious dining area.

Starting with the basics, Goat Hill uses a sourdough crust that is thicker than most NY style crust, but not overly doughy or glutenous, and provides a nice canvas for the rest of the pie.  GHP also offers a wide variety of toppings, and the permutations and configurations of toppings is seemingly endless(I suggest the roast chicken with homemade pesto and sundried tomatoes and fresh chopped garlic, and the ham, mushroom, and sweet red onion).  The choice is yours, and choose wisely.  That said, if you can't choose, ask about the pizza of the day, it's usually a three topping combination offered which is a good default option.  

GHP also offers on their menu some standard Italian cuisine fare, from pastas to italian sausage sandwiches, and some appeasing appetizers, but I recommend you stick to the meat and potatoes of the menu, figuratively speaking.

Also worthy of noting is the Monday all you can eat special, it would be wise to come early and hungry, as the line of eagerly waiting patrons can become substantially long as the night goes on.  But then, as a wise man once said, good food, including pizza, takes time.  Plus, if do you have to wait, just across the street is Delirious, where you can pick a new pair of kicks, which makes the wait seem not all that bad.
author: Michael P.

description: I love Goat Hill Pizza- an awesome ambiance- there is usually a live piano player and everybody seems so happy- delicious pizza- sourdough crust!- and pretty quick take out service. I love to go here before my acupuncture sessions at ACTCM.
author: T W.

description: Incredible pizza joint atop Potrero Hill. Friendly staff, fresh ingredients, and reasonable prices. Personal favorite is "Hilda's Favorite" ... If you want great San Francisco style pizza, Goat hill is the place!
author: Steven C.

description:
I like this place cause it has a nice view from the window tables.  The pizza is good.  Not the best but far from the worst.  Kinda California style pizza with a thin crust that is kinda crunchy but good.  The sauce is good and the meat lovers is good.  

Mondays are all you can eat.  The salad bar is nothing special but at least you can build your own salad.  Really fun to try all the different types of pizza . A very good deal and a lot of fun too.

The place still has a community feel to it and I like that.   I definite place I will return to and have many times.  Also the meatball sandwich is a good deal.

parking is usually fine but you may have to hike up one of those SF hills.  good after the pizza.
author: Bucky W.

description: Pizza was good. Place was nice. Dining experience was ok. Will probably go back but not in the near future. I will recommend it to others but will not really rave about it.
author: Toni T.

description:
They delivered this in record time. However, the flavor was lacking and it was quite expensive after factoring in their delivery charge (which I wasn't aware of pre-order). Seriously, there was almost no flavor to speak of, besides I guess that of salt - which there was far too much of. Asked for extra garlic, but here was none.  

Gotta go with two stars for the cardboard flavor - that even the cheaper pizzarias avoid.
author: Augusto H.

description:
Years from now, when I am on Jerry Springer telling the story of how I made it to 500 lbs, and am asked how it happened, three words will be my reply:  "Goat Hill Pizza."  And when the inevitable follow-up comes, "well, fatty, was it worth it?", I will slap my belly and say "damn right it was!"

My wife and I lived in Potrero for 3 years, and got 4 free pizzas from Goat, so I think that works out to about 52 pizzas.  Never once were we disappointed.  I honestly don't know about some of these negative reviews--when I think about pizza, I think about pepperoni and sausage with a good crust and fresh ingredients.  I can go broaden my horizons on some other cuisine--pizza's a comfort food whether I'm getting a slice in New Haven or New York, or out on the west coast.  I've been to all the supposed "best" places in SF, and Goat was far and away my favorite.
author: Ty D.

description:
Monday night.  All you can eat.  $11.  Food coma.

You sit down, and right away someone is offering you a slice of something delicious.  There is a salad bar too if you're into that, but all that really does is rob your stomach of space for more delicious pizza.  I can't speak for the options when it isn't all-you-can-eat Monday, but if the slices were any indication of the regular menu, then they have got quite a selection.
author: Matt N.

description: I went here with a friend the other night on a Monday, thinking we would split a pizza. I didn't realize that Monday nights are all-you-can-eat pizza and salad nights -- it was amazing! As soon as we sat down, servers started coming around with fresh-from-the oven slices. Artichoke, garlic, Hawaiian, anchovy and green olives, pesto, pepperoni -- one pizza variety after another. They all looked so good I took them all and I soon had a pile of slices on my plate. The salad bar was so-so, but the overall experience still deserves five stars.
author: Melissa M.

description: After reading the great reviews, I admit that I had somewhat of an expectation for the quality of Goat Hill Pizza.  After trying it for the first time, all I can say is "eh."  We ordered delivery on a Tuesday night - it took an hour for one large pizza, and we live fairly close to the Potrero location.  I do like the fact that I could order and pay on the website.  We ordered the Greek Gourmet - it tasted like an average pizza, over-dressed with green olives.  Couldn't even find / taste the feta.  The sourdough crust was good, but not good enough to make me want to order delivery from here again.  Also, pretty pricey for the quality we got.  The only way I will have Goat Hill again is to go in for their all you can eat pizza deal on Monday nights.
author: Jenna C.

description:
First time here was for their Mon. Night all you can eat, LOVED it... for the deal.

However, the pizzas themselves did not impress me, sort of bready...after a couple slices.

I thought since it was the Mon. night special... possibly they didn't go all out, so I tried it a recently on another day. Ordered the large Chicken Florentine. Not impressed by the size. Chicken was nicely charbroiled, however the over all taste was bland.

I'd go back to help others experience the All-you-can-eat night, but otherwise I'll head to one of the other many pizza joints in the city.
author: Angel L.

description:
I've eaten here a handful of times and still haven't made it in on a Monday night for the all-you-can-eat blowout! I love the location, the atmosphere (laid back), the garlic bread and the pies.

Definitely a cool place to hang out with friends and grab some tasty grub.
author: Art D.

description:
Went last night and sat in the back for the first time.  The pizza was better than usual. I love the salad with bread for 6.50. Salad has pepperoncinis, garbanzo beans, kidney beans and they make a wonderful house itialian. Had a slice o pizza for 2.75.

One Peroni beer = 3.25
Salad for two = 6.50
Slice o' pizza = 2.75
Good meal and money for lunch tomorrow = Priceless
author: monika l.

description:
This place is all about the great sourdough crust! Great local ambiance and a really good staff.

I usually eat there twice a month at last...The only reason I gave it only 4 stars is that I have gotten overcooked (burned) pizza there on a couple of occasions but as I am closing in on free pizza, it's obvious that hasn't deterred me from visiting often!

Watch out for all-you-can-eat Mondays...It can be a mad house and it seems that the kitchen shifts over that mode and they look surprised when you don't want the all you can eat.
author: John H.

description: I came here recently with coworkers for a farewell party to our summer college interns. The pizza was fine. Service was good, although the server forgot the iced tea for those who ordered that. Looks like they had decent beer selection including the Speakeasy brand. Too bad I could not order, decided that I better behave because i was on duty.
author: H K.

description: These guys use quality ingredients and put care into their pizza.  I love being able to order online from their site.  Try the Greek pizza with added ground beef.  mmmm.
author: Allan H.

description:
I went here for their all you can eat monday special.  We got a table in the back corner with a view of the city, that was pretty awesome.  For the all you can eat thing, they come around with pizzas and ask if you want a slice.  They have also sorts of different toppings ranging from bbq chicken to artichoke hearts.

The crust is tasty and not all soggy or doughy.  

The all you can eat special for $9-10 is totally worth it for the amount of food that you end up getting.  They also have a small salad bar but there's really no point in visiting it.
author: Shyam P.

description:
While not the most traditional crust the sourdough here is fantastic and provides a nice change to the standard fare.  Each Monday night they have all-you-can-eat pizza for $9 or something cool like that.

If you ask me that is way more impressive than other pizza joints that try and distinguish themselves by putting obscure toppings on the pie.  I like this place and think that it is worth the trip out here. Enjoy.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Worst pizza I've ever had. The center of the pizza was extremely soggy. The cheese was not good. Crust was awful. Absolutely dreadful. I ate one slice and when the waiter asked if I wanted to take it home, I said no. He asked again, are you sure? I said, absolutely sure. 

Dining experience: really awful. The room was filled with little children, one of whom was screaming all the time. If you like kids, this is for you. If not, run away.

Terrible terrible dinner.
author: Esme V.

description:
I hate to dis a local favorite, but I've two sub-par pies at Goat Hill recently. One was the nightly special - linguica and green onions - which came out soupy and not very flavorful. The other was a combo that we ordered up with Italian sausage and some other things... but there was hardly ANY sausage at all. I mentioned this to the server, and he said he'd pass along the feedback. We didn't expect any special treatment, after all, it's just a pizza, but I did mention it again to the head of the house as we were leaving. Her response was, "if you want more sausage, ask for extra when you order." Eh? F**k that, a sausage pizza should COME WITH sausage, enough to taste it, not one little speck per slice. 

Step it up, Goat Hill, or die slowly and shamefully.
author: Bowen D.

description: I love the pizza here and the comfortable environment...I am never disappointed!
author: Tashema M.

description: Order during a late work binge, pizza came hot and great! Not too greasy but still good! While the driver forgot our soda, he (against my direction) drove back within 20 minutes with our 6-pack, what dedication!
author: Eric O.

description:
YUM Great pizza, sourdough crust, and various toppings! Go Monday nights for all you can eat pizza and salad bar only $9.00 per person.  The red and white checkered tableclothes add to cheesy ambiance that makes pizza and beer night so special. 

There is a bit of a wait, but it's so beyond worth it, no one leaves hungry = )

*They won't seat you unless your whole party is there, so keep that in mind.
author: Beth M.

description:
I've been coming to Goat Hill on and off for years now and I can't believe I've never gone to their Monday Neighborhood nights!  Well, now that I live in the neighborhood, I really didn't have an excuse.  I went to my first neighborhood night last night still a little stuffed from lunch but I figured I should just get it over with so I can finally say I've gone to one.  There was a bit of a wait at the door, but nothing outrageous.  We came at 7 pm and for a table of 2, we waited about 15 minutes.  

I loved it!  I forgot about how full I was from earlier that day and I swear, I had like 10 slices.  No need to worry though, the slices are about half the slice of a regular one.  So in all actuality, I had 5 slices.  That's like eating half a pizza!  And a salad bar?  All for $10?  So I have to admit the pizza on Monday nights isn't as good as all the other nights - they don't serve their specials, like my fav - the Californian.  But it's instant gratification and for what you pay, I think it's a steal.    

I have been here on other nights and for lunch during the day.  They have a pretty good lunch special - a mini pizza (which I can never finish) or a pizza and a salad deal all for about $5.  Service here is okay, nothing outstanding.  Come here for their Monday neighborhoods nights, their specialty pizzas on the other nights, and for a chance to sit in the back room to enjoy sweeping views of the city skyline.
author: Jean A.

description:
So disappointing.  My boyfriend has been wanting to try this place for months now mostly I think because he loves to eat.  So after a trip to the Anchor Steam brewery we decided to give the Monday night special a whirl.  Well this place is great for the price.  The pitchers were 9.50 and it was for good beer (speakeasy and anchor to name a couple.  Unfortunately they were out of the Pilsner).  So we waited about an hour for the 5pm special to begin.

All the waiters/waitresses were very nice.  They even let us start the salad bar 15 min before 5 which was great!  Well, the salad bar was the best part of the meal.  The salad bar was fully equipped with bell peppers, kidney beans, garbanzo beans and more! Yum!

But then the pizza came out...  GREASY was the main adjective to describe it.  I also didn't think that the quality of the ingredients was very high.  It just wasn't very good and with all the popularity I was very disappointed.  I will never be back here.  

Great service and lots of food for the price.  But isn't this Goat Hill "PIZZA" .  So I would think the pizza would be better.

PS my boyfriend's stomach was upset for the whole night and this guy has a strong stomach.  That was another con.  We both blamed it on the pizza.
author: Rachel S.

description: went here for the all you can eat pizza on monday night for $11.99. You can eat all that you want and no one will kick you out. I only made it to 15 slices this time around, but I'll prepare better next time. They have all kind of variety available. Meat, yes. Veggie, yes. Exotic, sort of. Pizza seem like they're coming out slowly at first, but that's because you're starving from the long wait that you probably had to endure. Looked there was some opportunity to buy alcohol and sip on that while you wait. Two issues I had was that my mouth was cut up from the sourdough crust and that the pizza was coming out way too hot. Needs to rest a little to get its rigidity established. That said, the pizza was really good. I'd come back. Probably sooner than I think.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Alls I can say is...ALL YOU CAN EAT PIZZA! on Monday nites!
Amazing! I recommend bringing a bunch of friends and making a nite of it. It's unhealthy and fun at the same time. We tend to bring a sharpie and tally who can eat the most slices (crust not included). Get there early to partake in this, as there's always a line and hard to get seating on that particular nite. May be because it's only $10.95 to partake in such goodness? The servers walk around with slices of various pizzas and you can just pick and choose as many as you want. It gets pretty filling by the end of the nite. Perhaps wear some pants with stretch in them as your belly will be full. This nite also includes an all you can eat salad bar. 
(Imagine all you can eat pizza & beer. I wish. That would probably make for a mess, as I'm sure people would be wasted and make the bathroom all icky.)

Anyway... from having tried many a slice from the all you can eat goodness..my favorites are anything with linguica. Remember when Round Table was big? Their linguica was my favorite..this brings me back to that. I like the linguica with pineapple. Their pepperoni here is yummy too. Another bonus: pitchers of Anchor Steam for $10. Amazing. Anchor steam + unlimited pizza= how I like to roll. Don't be afraid of the tall lady who works there, she is actually really nice and super bossy. I love it.
author: Kristy H.

description: The chicken florentine pizza is so good. The only drawback is that it's so loud there it's challenging to have a conversation with the person across the table.
author: Devin V.

description: Simply delicious! Had the salad and slice lunch special. The taste of the pizza reminded me of when my mom used to take me to Woolworths on Market St. Is anyone here even old enough to remember Woolworth's on Market St? Maybe your parents? If they do, they can tell you how good the pizza was there! GHP has won my heart!
author: Andy C.

description:
Mondays at Goat Hill Pizza: All-you-can-eat pizza and salad for $10. 

I told my friend Matt that unless you're a pig who gleefully frequents Las Vegas all-you-can-eat buffets, or some lucky bastard with a mutant overactive thyroid gland, $10 for all the pizza you can shove into your face isn't that amazing of a deal. How much f-ing pizza do you really need? He got mad at me.

That aside, I liked the place a lot. Lucky we got there at 5:30 and were seated immediately; by 5:45 there was a line stretching all the way down the block to the Pets R Us on Potrero.

The pizza? Delicious. Sourdough crust. Pungent sauce. Piping hot. Cute servers come by every 2-3 minutes offering you a slice of the latest pie to pop out of the oven. Artichoke with garlic and tomatoes. Chicken with green olives and feta. Salami. Plain cheese. Pesto. And they had the foresight to make the slices small, so you can chill out at the restaurant for a while, rather than fill up too quick. So it takes you more like 40 minutes before you feel like you're going to puke your stomach out, not 5.

At one point a server came by with "pepperoni" but it sounded to me like he'd said "mac and cheese." Wouldn't that be cool? Pizza with mac and cheese on it? I think so.

Salad bar: great blue cheese dressing. Atmosphere: crowded, loud and very cool. Service: fast and friendly. Pitcher of Anchor Steam we got: only $9. That's rougly $2.25 per pint. Hoorah.

I do recommend this place. Just get there early, and you'd be loving life if you came after getting high. Yeah -- I mean high on life!
author: Dan N.

description:
I love their dinner salad w/feta and their meat lasagne.  There are days when I crave that lasagne with the burnt cheese along the edges of the dish it is served in.   Mmmmmm....

Can't really speak for the pizza since I never eat it there.
author: Pamela S.

description:
Ambiance: Nice relaxing pizza joint with an great view of downtown and has a small neighborhood feel to it. Monday nights its just way to packed, although it's a must you do have to experience it at least once. 

Staff: Super nice, friendly staff. 

Price: $20 for a med pizza - a bit pricey but worth it if you love sour dough!

It's my go-to pizza spot.
author: melissa g.

description: The service staff at Goat Hill Pizza on Potrero Hill is awful and the food is not that great either. How do you give a no stars review???  That's what I'd really like to do. I do not want to go into specifics because it's a waste of my time. Just know that this was my 2nd visit there. On my first visit, I had the same thoughts. However, I decided to visit again and give the place another chance because it is close to my house and conveniently located nearby. However, my initial feelings were confirmed. The wait staff there are very rude and inconsiderate. Furthermore, the pizza is overpriced and not that appetizing.  For the money, I can find better elsewhere. I'm done going to Goat Hill. In my humble opinion, I wouldn't let my worst enemy order food from this place!!!
author: Jason P.

description: All I can say is YUM! I'm not even a fan of sourdough bread, and I thought this pizza was pretty delicious. Also, the cute appearance of a typical pizza shop is an added plus. This is a must try, especially since sourdough bread originated from San Francisco. Can't get more San Franciscan than this!
author: Natalie G.

description: Meh.  Had better pizza.  Pizza was oily and the dough was...interesting, to say the least.  We also had a large table filled with teeny boppers sitting next to us, so I'm sure that didn't help with the meal either.  I'm definitely sticking to Pizza Orgasmica.
author: Linh D.

description:
First all-you-can eat pizza buffet that comes to you!   This place is a stones throw from my place and it's tough to resist the sourdough pizza smell wafting from this place on Monday nights (or every night for that matter).  If clams on on the menu, get them on your pizza. 

Every time my folks come to town, they insist on eating here.  I don't blame them, it is great, unique pizza, but I'd love to show them that SF has a little more to offer...
author: Val U.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza is a great neighborhood pizza place. The pizza crust is what I'm going to call "thin-ish". That is to say, if thin crust pizza was characterized by being thin and crispy and deep dish pizza was characterized by being thick and chewy, Goat Hill Pizza is 90% thin. It's yummy, and dare I say unique.

There aren't any original toppings here (like salmon or apple slices). But the stuff they do have, they do right. My favorite pizza here is the meat lover's. Three kinds of meat, distributed liberally but not overwhelmingly across the pie.

On Monday's, Goat Hill has a special all you can eat night. They bake a bunch of different kinds of pizzas and carry them around table to table. It's a fun night, but the lines outside are a bit much for me.

I once made the mistake of ordering the wine flight here. 2 out of 3 were skunked, but I think I was asking for that.

I would not describe the service here as warm. For pick up orders, they generally seem downright put off. For eating in, the service is a little bit better, but still much closer to Chevys' than Gary Danko's.
author: Keith C.

description: 4.5 stars.  I was pretty tired and hungry and just in need of a good comfort meal... and when I look for comfort in food, I look to pizza... damn do i love pizza.  Came here for the first time and it was nice.... not crowded, easy parking, the tables are covered with that red-white checkered table cloth that every pizzeria should have.... with parmesean and crushed red pepper shakers at every table..... we got some wings... they were good and tasty.. but I was there for pizza so we got a large pizza... half meat-lovers and half greek-gourmet with regular crust.  (They also offer thin crust, deep dish, and gluten free crust options).... but I like regular crust sometimes and this crust was good w/ the cornmeal on the bottom... man it was good eats.  The pizza was slightly salty, but that's b/c we got all salty toppings, but man it was good eats.  Took some home and it was great cold pizza the next day too!
author: Easter E.

description:
I came here with some friends primarily to use up a soon-to-expire Groupon.  We all live in the Sunset, and while it's not exactly a destination restaurant, the trip was totally worth it.

The pizza we got (Hilda's Favorite) was delicious (and they're very generous with the toppings); we also got some pretty tasty bruschetta.  There was a guy playing piano until about nine, which was really cool.  The staff is very friendly, albeit a little tricky to flag down if you're the meek type (as was most of my troupe), but seeing as it's a homey pizza place, most people probably aren't there to rush.

Also they humored us 20-something art majors and let us have the pens to draw on our placemats.

All-in-all I had a great experience and if I'm ever in the area again I'll definitely be back.
author: Hadidjah C.

description:
A lot of people have raved about this place so I decided to go and try it.  I've gone several times now and I have to say that its been a pretty mixed bag.  Sometimes the food & service is great.  Other times, I'm extremely disappointed and dissatisfied with the service.  Here are some examples:

Once, I went there and there was a group of us.  The waitress was very abrupt and it was hard to get service.  We waited and waited and this was during our lunch hour.  When, we finally got the food, we were starving and gobbled up the food.  Later, when we went to go pay the bill, that too seemed to take an eternity.

Another time, I ordered the pesto pizza.  The order was wrong so I sent it back to the kitchen.  The waiter apologized and then not more then 3 minutes later, the slice of pizza returned with a big glob of pesto slathered on top.  Somewhat naive, I thought oh maybe they just picked up the wrong one.  But, when I bit into it, it was clear that it was the same pizza I had sent back with cold pesto paste slapped out on top.  Boo.

Still, despite all my bad experiences, somehow I just keep finding myself back here, mostly because my friends love it.  I do have to say the meatballs are delicious.  If you're ever looking for a cheap snack, get a side of meatballs, very satisfying.  I think the pizza is just okay.  And, well the service, its hit or miss.
author: Candice M.

description: DELICIOUS PIZZA! I just wish they had delivery... oh well! It tastes so good I don't mind going in to pick it up :)
author: Sami Y.

description:
I only come on mondays when they do all you can eat and it's awesome. Sure they're basically getting rid of all their food before they get their new shipment in but the idea is genius.

Once you're at your seat, if someone's passing the pizza around you get your food asap, what restaurant does that? The slices are small the the dough is thin but you want it that way because you want to try everything!  You can get the salad too but meh, I wanted the pizza =) After a while everything starts to taste the same  but I had about 11 slices so yea, I might of over did it. Good place, def check it out esp if you live in sf.
author: Mike B.

description:
Slices for eat in or take out, made fresh to order.

Cheese $2.50
One Topping $3.00
Two Topping $3.50
every topping after +.50cents

You can get a slice to go with up to three toppings. I got two slices with three toppings each and the total bill was $8.75.

The slices were very generously sized and the toppings were extremely nice, very fresh, a lot of them for every bite. The thin crust is, I decided last night, really my favorite. Something about less dough giving more of a spotlight to the other ingredients wins me over. This crust was crunchy and savory.

This reminds me of the quintessential high school date spot or post sports family dining favorite. Plastic red checked table 'cloths', pizza and the standard salads and pastas, nothing too intensely high priced. It is very neighborhoody and the staff is friendly and smiles at you, regularly.

A great option if you find yourself over in Potrero Hill and want to sit down and relax in a no stress atmosphere. Beers too.
author: Miel H.

description: Very good pizza and not too expensive.  I just wish it was closer to my home.  Great place for lunch or dinner.
author: Sarah G.

description:
I'm like a salmon swimming against the tide. Swim little salmon, swim! And the Yelpers are like bears, perched near the water's edge ready to swipe at me as I swim furiously by on my quest to spawning ground. But I will persevere with my 3 stars.

Deep breath. And the plunge:

Sorry for the brag about my boyfriend, or even the fact that I have a boyfriend, but he makes way better pizza than Goat Hill. Seriously, he has a pizza stone and everything and he busts out good pizzas which I devour, leaving him hungry and growing skinnier by the day. (disclaimer: none of this, except the goodness of the pizza, is actually remotely true)

Even with my personal pizza chef, my expectations were  too high for this place. Yeah, it's decent pizza and the Monday night thing sounds awesome but I'd prefer to stay at home and watch my boyfriend slave away making me food. 

If there is no significant other/partner/slave to make you your own pizza, then I would recommend trying some other places around the city before settling at Goat Hill. 

On a side-note: I couldn't seem to find the goats. Are they being hidden in the kitchen somewhere?
author: Ali L.

description:
During finals I let myself eat whatever I want. 
Whatever. I. Want. Because I deserve it.
This Monday I wanted pizza and oh boy, did I get me some pizza. 8 pieces of it to be exact and all for the bargain price of $10.95! On top of the grade A pizza, Goat Hill also offers a yummy Italian style salad bar (included in the all you  can eat Monday night special) and cheap pitchers to help you come down from the weekend. 
I walked away from Goat Hill 5 pounds heavier with a burn on the roof of my mouth from the impatient food shoveling, but it was well worth it.
As this is my last semester and thus last set of finals, maybe I can change my rule to let myself eat whatever I want every Monday. I can't think of a better way to kick start the week, can you?

Be prepared for a wait - apparently I'm not the only one who thinks they deserve a once a week pizza feast.
author: Taylor E.

description:
Imagine, if you will, what it would be like to eat a piece of a volcano.  Oozing lava scorches every surface of your mouth.  It hurts, oh how it hurts, but hey.. maybe it's flavorful.  As if that weren't enough, you then realize you have to chew through razor-sharp volcanic rock, scraping away what little flesh remains in your already-tortured mouth.

Yeah, that's what Goat Hill Pizza is like.  It might be considered sacrilege around these parts to say that, but it had to be done.
author: Adam W.

description:
Just did the Monday night pizza thing here last night. It was great! I'm not known for my love of buffets, or the all you can eat concept, but I loved that they bring the pizza to your table while calling out what kind it is. I also liked that once we told our server we were veg, she refrained from bringing each version of the meatlover's over. There were PLENTY of yummy veggie options and the pizza was straight from the over - hotter than most pizza places that just have to get it to one table deliver. 

Also, mad props for a $9 pitcher of Speakeasy, Sierra Nevada or 2 others. 

Since we're old, we were in by 5:30pm, like the the early birds we are. When we left at about 7, there were quite a few people waiting outside.
author: Shal J.

description:
Goat Hill makes me feel naughty AND satisfied.  

Naughty for the fattening, satisfied for the deliciousness.
author: Maria C.

description:
I love how they always stuff paper plates and extra hot peppers in a brown bag when you order delivery.  

Now, if they can only learn how call from the call box so I can buzz them in verses going downstairs, they'd be a solid 4 stars.
author: Michelle C.

description: Better than most. Nice sunset view. I recommend coming here on a Monday all you can eat night. If you don't like your crusts, then you can stack them up jenga style. See how high you can go!
author: Jon H.

description: LOVE getting delivery from here. Hate paying the bill afterwards. $90 to feed the group of friends in my living room? I guess that's just how much I have to pay to avoid the gluey-cheese disaster that is Pizza Orgasmica, so okay, I'll pay for Goat Hill.
author: Sharon W.

description:
The Californian: fresh tomato, artichoke, garlic.
 
I've eaten 5 slices today.

The most delicious crust ever.

I'm oozing garlic from every pore.  And loving it.
author: diana s.

description:
Good stuff, this pizza. Love the all you can eat, but make sure you get there early enough to get a table. you can wind up waiting outside with everyone else suffering in the aroma of fresh baked pizza.

Enjoy the good stuff, kids. Crust to die for. Great family joint too! Nice view to boot if you get one of the tables by the windows.
author: Charlene L.

description:
Do you have a case of the Monday's? 
Well this makes my Mondays definitely more bearable.

My friend described it like dim sum but with pizza. Tis true. 

All you can eat pizza Monday's for $10.95 and Anchor Steam Pitchers for $10: I am a fan. Sometimes they have mostly veggie, sometimes they have mostly meat. I understand that they have to rotate every week and please the masses so I don't complain. Pretty damn good quality. I am an avid pizza connoisseur.
author: Geneva X.

description: This is a great little neighborhood pizza joint.  The food is delicious and the staff is super friendly.  I had some special combination pizza with my parents and they also loved it (and they're usually very picky).  I'll probably go on a Monday evening next time as I always see a line around the place waiting for their "dim sum of pizza."
author: Karen N.

description:
3.5 Stars - Good, solid, slightly harried but friendly service bumped up to four for longevity and being a great staple of the neighborhood.

TLFC picked up a piece of crust, tapped the bottom of it with his fork and said, "See?  Crispy.  Not as thin as New York, not as thick as Chicago but very good!"  I knew Goat Hill's pizza was good - but I was glad it made TLFC happy.
author: Nancy W.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza is one of the best things about moving to P.Hill.  I love their sour dough crust.  I recommend the vegetarian pizza with sausage.  I'm obviously not a vegetarian but I love veggies.  
My neighbors ordered pizza delivered (the Goat Hill in P.Hill does not delivery) and I was was shocked and appalled since Goat Hill is literally 2 blocks away.... I really lost respect for them.
author: Jessica C.

description: Disclaimer - I'm a local fan. This is a great place to see local Potrero Hill residents wolf down their share of yumminess. Greasy salty pizzas with lots of variety to choose from. Don't wait to eat it, because it could go soggy unless you reheat with a pizza stone. Some of my faves' include their jalapeno pizzas, their combo, the chicken florentine and their home-made ranch dressing is to die for. Come early on all-you-can-eat Mondays, because the place is packed!!!
author: Karin B.

description:
Mediocre.  I wouldn't go here again.  Nor would I recommend it.  I shared a veggie pizza (black olive, green onion, green pepper, mushroom) and added pepperoni to half.  They season it with a ton of fennel, which I hate.  It tasted like warm black licorice.  Outside of the fennel, it was just bland.  I don't think I've ever added straight salt to a pizza, but it was a must to make this palatable.  Not that any of this stopped me from eating half of our large pie.  Bleh.  But since the service was OK, I give them 2 stars.  

And to be fair, I went with my boyfriend who has enjoyed their pizza on previous nights and thought that maybe this was just an off-night  Maybe this is true.  Actually, I've had this happen a lot to me lately -- dining at restaurants my friends enjoy but then the food will suck the time that they bring me, and we think that maybe it was just an "off-night" (see reviews of Club Waziema, My Tofu House, and Delfina).

And maybe on another Monday night when Little Star, Arizmendi, and Patxi's are all closed, I might be convinced to go here again.  Nah.  I think I'd rather heat up a frozen pizza from TJs.
author: S J.

description:
Anybody who says that finding a good pizza in California is next to impossible, needs to come here.  California Pizza has been a little lacking in satisfaction for this Midwestern girl.  Chicago or New York style I can go any which way.  Thats why I think I fell in love when a friend invited me out for pizza.  This has become almost a monthly staple in my diet.

I am not sure about the other nights, but Monday night is the night to go.  For a mere $10 you can have all you can eat Pizza.  These are little slices, so prepare to eat 10 of them.  Ooh yeah and its like dim sum.  The staff walks around holding pizza pies pre sliced with traditional and creative toppings.  Everything is delicious.  The smell lures one in from the street.  It pours outside of the door, so as soon as you put your name down, you are already hungry.  

They have a policy to not seat until all arrive in the party.  Also, prepare to spend some time waiting. (there is a wait, the later you come the easier to get a table.) But it is worth it.  there is also a little salad bar included in the $10 (all you can eat ). Their beer selection is pretty alright with good beers on tap or in bottles.  Their wine selection is a little lagging, but sufficient for a mom and pop pizza parlor.  The view from the outside and the back windows in the back room are spectacular, especially as the sun is setting.  The service is excellent for what it is.  They keep bringing you food after all.  Or at least until you say stop.
author: Stephanie S.

description: I have only been here during the all you can eat pizza on Monday's for 10.99 so this review is only for Monday dine in. If you drop in around dinner time expect to wait at least 30 minutes, even for a party of two. The pizza is good but not good enough for me to come in on a different day or order delivery. There's a salad bar in the back room it's small and limited but it get the job done, you came for the pizza anyways right? My biggest complain is that beer selection is waaaaay too limited. I believe they only have 4 beers on draft and they are all ales. I enjoy a good brew with my pizza so I am always disappointed with their selection. The cheap buffet is what keep me coming back.
author: Laura I.

description:
Pizza: amazing.
Service: amazing.
Slice size: way too small. As in, 3 slices fit into one slice at a normal pizza place. You'd think this was a minor detail, but it gets annoying having to grab another slice after every 3 bites. They should make half as many cuts across the pie, and then it'll be perfect.
author: Ryan L.

description: Had Hilda's Fave and Greek Gourmet.  This is good pizza - but concluded it doesn't merit the rave reviews on here.  The pizza toppings are ample and not overly salty, sauce is balanced, cheese is of good quality.  Crust not too thick or doughy, edges nicely chewy.  I will say the pizza came out wonderfully hot.  To conclude, this is good pizza - nothing hyperbolic here....hence worthy of three stars, which represents "A-OK" on the yelp rating system.  I will return again but I couldn't justify rating it four stars so that I claim "I'm a fan".
author: Liz K.

description: first time eating here and love the pizza, its always pile with meat and sauce but the price tag came out to be about $3.50 a slice and we had 4-5 box pizza at our work, make fast food pizza taste like crap... haha...
author: JessePanda C.

description:
PIzza is decent. Best thing about it is convenient location for those who live near Potrero Hill.

Service is bad, especially on the phone. I got yelled at and hung up on twice before I could order my pizza.
author: epic j.

description:
This pizza place is basically an institution in SF, and as a native, I'm suprised that my first time was tonight!

Mondays are "neighborhood night," aka $10.95 for all you can eat salad and pizza. What a deal!

The servers are constantly circling around the restuarant with different pizzas: green/black olive, meat lovers, linguisa, pesto/peppperoni, etc. The slice are very small too, so that you can sample lots of different kinds. 

The salad bar was decent: mozzarella, black olives, beets, tomatos, pepperocinis, etc. 

The staff is very patient and friendly!
author: Misha F.

description:
Monday night staple, classic and local.

Keep as is and please don't bring A16 to the dogpatch, I think I'll vomit.
author: E C.

description:
I moved to SOMA a few months ago and Goat Hill was kind enough to welcome me to the 'hood  with a coupon for a free large pizza with two toppings, delivered from their SOMA outpost.  Nice of them.  So, I had to try it, since what did I have to lose, right?

I've been to the restaurant on Potrero Hill, so I have some idea of what their pizza is like.  But, (there's always a "but" right?!!?) I'm an east coast native (first 25 yrs of my existence), I am a self-proclaimed pizza snob.  I have lived in SF for 20 years, and mostly have sworn off pizza, cuz most places -- and I do mean *most* -- are downright awful.  Californians simply don't know how to make a great pizza.  I'm talking about pizza from a pizza joint, btw not some froufrou pizza that costs $20 and barely feeds one person.

So, with that as a preface, I give Goat Hill's delivery in SOMA 2 stars.  The service on the phone was excellent...took my order and got it right.

The pizza arrived well ahead of schedule, the delivery guy was professional, and the pizza was piping hot.

So far so good.

The pizza itself was ok.  Not great, not terrible either.  The toppings I chose were chicken and artichoke hearts.  There was a decent amount of chicken, but the 'chokes were all but non-existent.  I also ordered soy cheese on one half and mozzarella on the other.  (They got this right, too!)

But what they heck is it with California pizza places and not putting tomato sauce on pizzas as standard fare?  For the life of me, I do not understand this.  Tomato sauce is not a topping!  It's part of the 3 required components of a great pizza -- dough, cheese and tomato sauce.  Sigh.

In the end, the 'za was ok, as I said already.  The soy cheese was good quality.  The crust was by far the best part.

Would I order from them again for delivery?  Only if I was having company who insisted I serve pizza.  Given that has never happened in the 20 years that I have lived here, it's pretty unlikely.  (But I would go to one of their restaurants if I had a serious craving for pizza.)
author: david s.

description: Two words: burnt pizza.  I love this place when I went to the restaurant some time back, so I was crazy excited that their new to-go location is just around the corner from my apartment.  Sadly, I get home, take a bite and realize the bulk of the pizza crust is full on charred.  What a let down.
author: Aldo K.

description: Great Pizza! I love Hilda's Favorite with goat cheese and pesto.  The service is decent.  I'm looking forward to trying their Monday night "all you can eat" special
author: Dawn R.

description:
I always associated GHP with being purely a pizza delivery chain until my friend took me to the Portero Hill location and I was pretty surprised to find out it was a sit down - new to me.

PROS:
1. Plenty of choices on the menu and the usual choice of toppings
2. You can choose between thick and thin crust which is nice - I'm a thin crust kinda guy
3. Service was very good and all food items were served in a timely manner
4. Good wait staff who come by frequently to check if we need anything else
5. Cheap prices (large pizza + garlic bread + 2 beers = $35.00)
6. Great views from that side of Portrero Hill of downtown SF and nice location for a post meal walk to work those calf muscles!

CONS:
1. It does border on greasy (Mind you, this is after I've been to Pauline's Pizza and am saying it with that perspective)
2. Parking can be tough 

All in all, neat place. Pizza is not a regular part of my menu but I'd be up for hitting this with friends after a long day or on a nice warm summer night to grab a slice on my own.
author: Amit S.

description:
One of the few tasty pizza joints that I've found on the West Coast. Fresh toppings, good dough.

And better yet: Monday nights are ALL YOU CAN EAT DELICIOUSPIZZAPIESCIRCLINGMYHEAD!IEATATLEAST12SLICESBECAUSETHEYARESOSMALLANDTASTY! All for $10.95. Reasonably priced pitchers of beer, too. The only issue is the wait (always long on Monday nights), but who can blame 'em, they can't help that what they do is that good!

Monday nights at Goat Hill make the crosstown trek from the Richmond worthwhile. And that's saying something.
author: Lesley P.

description:
Goat Hill's claim to fame are the incredibly fresh and abundant toppings that come atop your pizza.  My favorites are the vegetarian options like sundried tomato, tomato, artichokes, and mushrooms which are always vibrant and handtossed onto the pizza.

The sourdough crusts aren't notable in texture, though they do taste good.  

I've been for lunch a few times now and am starting to get the feeling that my pizzas dont come with the toppings baked in.  The lunch combos include a slice of pizza with your choice of two toppings and a salad.  With 22 different pizza toppings, we're talking combinations galore--and there is no way that they would be able to get you in and out of the place in under an hour if they had to custom make every pizza.  I'm not exactly sure what their technique is, but it must include building a base cheese pizza and reheating with the toppings before serving.  

A bit generic, though I would bet the Monday night pizza buffet feels more homemade since they can turn out whole pizzas at a time.  

Sometimes my pizza comes out cold..major bummer.
author: Monica T.

description:
Not the friendliest service but they are crazy efficient. That was the fastest service for take out I've ever had and ordering on site versus the phone, which is something we probably should have done. Anyway... 

It was a nice night and I went to get pick up dinner so waiting outside people watching on a Saturday night and it was entertaining. Who knew waiting for dinner would attract a nice somewhat creepy older gentleman man who told corny jokes and shared his rescue dog's history (super cute Besenji mix by the way)! It was an interesting conversation (to say the least), it helped the wait go by incredibly fast. 

We finally got home and everything was fresh tasting and the crust was still crisp from the oven. The salad had to be chopped a bit but it was incredibly fresh with no bugs (muy importante). Good clean food every time!
author: Dorothy S.

description:
Been here once, but really need to go again!  And soon!

1)  All you can eat pizza, all night long
2)  Cozy atmosphere (read: the place is small, so you better not be claustrophobic)
3)  Great, homemade pizza of all kinds of varieties
4)  Did I mention all you can eat?  How about CHEAP?  Even better, huh?
author: Chanel F.

description:
How can I have not reviewed this place yet?  Maybe it's because there are enough reviews here... well, I've only been here on Neighborhood night (aka Monday night all you can eat) and it rocks.

Servers and host team are on and the pizza is excellent.  The salad bar is not top notch, but why the hell are you eating salad anyhow?  Yeah just to  make it feel more healthy - whatever - we only live once right?
author: Gene X.

description:
SPEED DIAL # 6.

Sourdough Crust + Fresh Ingredients - Waiting = F**K YEAH.
author: Ryan G.

description:
We were rolling through SFO on the way to Marin and were taken to this restaurant by a local.....after the wait another local restaurant was too long....to make a long story short, I thought the pizza was good.  I'm between a 3 and 4 stars here.  I've had better pizza, I've had worse.  Ordered a salad, and it was standard for your "Italian pizza" type of salad place.  Pizza wasn't greasy, which is good, but, like I've said, I've had better, I've had worse.   Probably really good with a cold pitcher of beer....

Service was.....so-so.
author: John O.

description: When I want great pizza, I go to Goat Hill.  The people are nice and friendly and the pizza is excellent.  They have an all you can eat Monday special that is very popular.  My favorite pizza is their Pesto-plus.  It isn't on the menue any more, but you can still order it.
author: Robin B.

description: Goat Hill would normally get five stars from me, but this review is dedicated to the heinously mannered waitress working behind the counter this eve. A simple "Sorry, we're closed" works much better than nasty looks, darlin'. She's definitely takes the neighbor out of a neighborhood fave.
author: Elle N M.

description:
Goat Hill is about great Pizza--don't let the name scare you--it is just a name.  The pizza is good but i have never walked away with any cravings of any particular pizza.  it is an institution for Potrero Hill.

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Pizza is a tad dry for me here, but better than 90% of the rest of the city.  

Monday nights are awesome ;)  AYCE pizza owns you.  Their salads are bleh, but at least they have a salad bar.  

Sierra on tap and a small variety of other beers is good.
author: Dong T.

description: It was my first time coming to this pizzeria and I was slightly sad to see that their all you can eat pizza was only on Monday nights. We had the Hilda's special? Which had goat cheese, tomatoes and pesto which was super yummy, a side order of buffalo wings and two glasses of wine which all came up to around 50 dollars. 50 dollars?! 25 for me? I could find a better price for pizza, although good not worth 25 dollars. But I wasn't disappointed, we left full and happy but I was a little sad with the pricing.
author: Lynne E.

description:
Oh, man. great crust, crisp enough but not too thin, SOURDOUGH flavor - yum.
AND they use really good quality pepperoni. Seriously better than most well-known places.  
The space is airy with nice views, the staff is friendly as all get-out.
author: Dana D.

description: Def. not that impressed by the pizza here.  I don't know what it is, but I just didn't get the "damn this is good pizza" when I had my first bite.  I mean I love cheese, so pizza is pizza.  cheese, sauce and meat. and I'm pretty satisfied, but def. missing the wow factor, like when I ate at Tomassos!!!
author: AhLin C.

description:
I want to like this place and give it 4 stars because its my neighborhood pizza place and the Pizza tastes good... but for some odd reason I feel bloated and not good an hour or so after eating the pizza.  I'm not talking once or twice either, its every single time.

Still try it because everyone else seems to love it.
author: Clayton K.

description:
Let's get one thing straight: I don't like waiting for food. Don't like waiting in a huge line at Trader Joe's. Hate standing around for more than 30 min to get into a restaurant. (read my Luna Park review)
So, I end up eating with the old folks and families with kids...oh well. This is one of those places. Love the Monday night special, and the salad bar is a great bonus. Go early. And by early, I mean 5 pm. Ok, maybe 5:30. If you're a guy, you'll love Mondays at Goat Hill--me, I can only eat so much. On the flip, I am just as happy picking up a large pepperoni to go. If you've never been, you can't get lost. You'll smell it a block away. And it's not a bad thing.
author: Dora A.

description:
Yum yum yum yum yum yum yum yum. Need I go on? No? Well, I will anyway. I hadn't been back here in years. And very little has changed...in the best way possible. Their salads are still hearty (and the bleu cheese, my god, the bleu cheese!) the garlic bread is still garlicky, and the pizza still has some of the best crust around.
