It's got that cornmeal stuff baked on. And they do NOT skimp on the toppings. Their beer is on the pricey side (and there is no excuse considering they could roll the Anchor Steam over there themselves) but I forgive and forget just so I will be allowed in on those lovely all-you-can-eat nights.

But I do still miss the goats...
author: Maya S.

description:
A friend convinced me and others to help him move by promising to treat us to Goat Hill Pizza after we unloaded the moving truck. He got about 10 extra sets of hands because of it. It was effective enticement. 

I liked the pizza, the crust was good and the veggie special had a nice kick of garlic to it. The staff was great too, especially since we were such a big group. I'll have to visit my friend and make more trips for pizza.
author: Arun C.

description:
Ya, all what Andy G. said.  I know that's a cop-out, but he really did hit it all on the nose for me.  Monday nights (despite the much remarked crowds) really are the main event here.

Good place for birthday party too -- a large party can be situated comfortably in the rear of the restaurant.
author: Alfonso E.

description:
I'm new to the neighborhood, and after any long day of moving there's only one thing that will make me happy -- and that's a whole bunch of pizza. I called on Goat Hill because they were the closest place I could find..

They were doing quite a business, even on a Sunday. Unfortunately, I found the pizza not to be too amazing... a bit pricey, and I just wasn't digging the sauce. Also, the wait was a little too long for the simple order that I had (one medium pizza). 

All in all, I'll probably end up coming back, just because it's the nearest pizza place, and not the most-delicious.
author: Mike S.

description:
I had put in my ten cents about the Monday All-You-Can-Eat night.  An event always popular for my pizza-loving, cheap-date guy friends.  And one I don't mind tagging along for, since (1) pizza is one of those things you crave once in a while, (2) On Monday nights, you get to sample a bunch of different kinds of pizza, dim sum style.  The slices are small enough that you can sample all of their concoctions, traditional and non-, without stuffing yourself silly. 

I had the same thought as another reviewer...at times it seemed like some of their creations were just an attempt to "get rid of our leftovers!" (Asparagus on pizza?  Sounds weird, but not too bad!)  But generally, they were all winners!  As part of this deal, you also get an all-you-can-eat salad, but I didn't find their salad bar all that impressive - their vinaigrette was a little too oily for me, and it seemed like there was more iceberg than not.  But for $9.95, beggars can't be choosers!

The best time to go is right when they begin at 5:00p.  You wait for a short time for a table, and you'll get to see the first circulation of pizza pies. However, if you want seconds of something, it is a bit of a gamble, since what comes out of the oven is pretty random.  I found the wait staff pretty friendly, and since the place is so neighbor-hoody, the overall energy is good - you'll find people enjoying each other's company.

I would totally recommend this place for: People on a budget, families, hanging out with friends, pizza lovers.

I would not recommend it for people who are about to go to the 7p salsa lesson at Cafe Cocomo.
author: Gail O.

description:
1 star for being in my 'hood
1 star for neighborhood night
1 star for good beer and semi-decent pizza

-1 for leaving huge pieces of plastic in my pizza
-1 for semi-decent pizza and SUPER slow service
author: Inna H.

description:
Somewhere between 3-4 stars. 

The pizza is good--not stellar. It's not NY thin; it's definitely not Chicago deep dish. So I suppose this is CA pizza. The crisp crust is fantastic, which is why this place is between 3-4 stars rather than just 3 stars. 

Service is quick. Pizza is quick. Definitely Monday nights are the best time to go--great deal. Otherwise, I have to agree with some of the other yelpers that this place is a little pricey. 

The bathroom is gross. 

Plenty of street parking--it's Potrero. 

They do have high chairs for kids.
author: Joyce L.

description:
Yum. Yum. Yum. Mantra of Yum.

This is the yummiest, tastiest, flavory-est, pizza on the planet. I grew up about 5 minutes from this place, and we would go in almost every Monday night for the all you can eat special. The servers walk around with a HUGE variety of pies, all sliced really thin, so that you can try as many as your happy tummy can hold.

Now, if you go in on any other night, it looks a touch pricey for pizza, but it's so well worth it. This is such wonderful pie-gasmic pizza. The best. 

(Oh - but don't order delivery unless it's a big party or something. I personally don't think the $3.50 delivery fee + tip is worth it, unless it's a larger order.)

Enjoy!
author: Mindy L.

description: This place is better than I remember!  Pizza was great.  I recommend Monday night.... all you can eat!  But get there early... if not, you'll be waiting a while!
author: Big Daddy C.

description: Casual environment, pretty good food, and solid (but not extraordinary) service. Slightly disappointed by the fabled pizza (I tried pepperoni), but a big fan of the buttery garlic bread, which comes in generous portions. Take some for the road or dip it in their soup of the day-- we tried corn soup as well as clam chowder, and both were piping hot and tasty.
author: Lauren S.

description: I came here for the all you can eat pizza night and was pretty disappointed. The pizza was dry and average at best. $11 isn't a lot to drop, but there's really only so much lackluster pizza one can eat.
author: Bryant T.

description:
I went to Goat Hill last night (a Monday) for the All You Can Eat Pizza & Salad. It was a good time for sure. We were a big group, and surprisingly, we were seated quite fast. Our hostess was a gem and totally helpful and accommodating (so 5 stars for her!). 

However, the pizza was good, but nothing to completely swoon over. I loved that they kept the pizza coming and all the variety to the pizzas, but overall I didn't think there was any magic. I know, I know...it's all you can eat...how much magic can you expect? I guess I'm just picky and think pizza should be magical like when you're a little kid at Chucki Cheese. 

But yah, the food was good though, just not fantastic. The service was okay. But at one point in the night some of my friends had to wait a good 25-30 minutes to get the attention of a server just for a re-fill. I even played one consistent note on my harmonica necklace to get one of the waiters' attention, and all while the entire restaurant seemed to pause and stare at our table trying to figure out where the sound came from...a waiter looked at us for a few seconds and as I asked, "Can we get a re-fill please?" he just looked at us for a few more seconds and walked away. Behold...10 minutes later, finally...a re-fill. Had to pull a star down for the re-fill harmonica fiasco.
author: stefany f.

description: I only came here once and it was GREAT! Monday Night ALL YOU CAN EAT PIZZA for $10.95! You don't even have to get up and go to the buffet line. They BRING THE PIZZA to your table and all you do is say yes or no. They also have a small salad buffet as well. I had a little bit of that cause i felt bad for eating all that pizza and no veggies. I will definitely come again on a monday night. Not sure about the delivery but I only came for the monday night all you can eat pizza. It was packed but we got seated and everything. =)
author: Daniel S.

description: The Californian pizza is great.  It has tomatoes, artichoke hearts, and garlic.  One tiny flaw was that the garlic was sort of lumped together so some slices barely had a hint of garlic while others had a whole lot.  Still very tasty, with lots of cheese too.
author: Rose C.

description: Average pizza, kind of overrated but that Monday night special makes up for all that!
author: Jose M.

description:
what i ordered... special combination pizza and garlic bread

...if it was not about the good service they'd provided and the awesome ambiance at this pizzeria i will definitely rate it at the most a couple of stars.

the pizza dough was THE worst i have ever had, hard and chewy, sourdough bread as they advertised was not quite the right dough for a pizza....also,  where was the cheese in my pie? did it roll down the hill?

garlic bread was so good, only if it had more roasted garlic in it, it'll be enough for me to go back to the place, it was so soft inside with a very thin crunchy crust.

ambiance... great (genuine sf homey feeling, with downtown view if you sit at the back)
service... good (quite lagging though)
cost... $+
author: Gors P.

description:
Definitely lives up to the hype.  The food was served quick, and was reasonably priced. I got a standard pepperoni pizza to split with the guys, my girlfriend got a salad and some sort of vegitarian Italian style toasted sandwich, and another person in our party got ravioli. No complaints from anyone.

Four stars for a damn good product and damn good service. Minus one star for not becoming my new favorite place. Sorry, I've got favorites that just won't be usurped so easily.
author: Alex C.

description:
Going to Goat Hill is such the quintessential pizza parlor experience that it hardly matters how good the pizza is. Red and white checked tablecloths, slightly tired interior, tall plastic glasses for your Coke. It's all there.

Must I even add that the pizza is bloody amazing? One block from 18th and Connecticut in any direction and you will have the irresistable urge to eat it.

Monday all-you-can-eat nights are simply the best.
author: Blake E.

description:
Just a few words about Goat Hill Pizza in the rejuvenated Potrero Hill: All You Can Eat Mondays. 

That's all.
author: Jessica D.

description:
I LOVE GOAT HILL!!!!!
When I lived in the east bay I would drive across the Bay Bridge just for pizza...that's commitment!!!
author: JR H.

description:
The crust on this pizza is just heavenly.  Crisp yet soft and chewy - sounds impossible but it's true.

I also find that the dough is so fresh I can get away with re-heating slices in the microwave for 30sec the following day and it's near-perfect.   My tip is to order medium and take the rest home with you!

The special combination is my favorite, and the refillable soda for a $1.50 is good value.
author: Ben M.

description:
I heard about this place and how good the pizza is.We decided to get take-out from here and the pizza was quite good.Simply delicious overall.If you order the Vegetarian pizza or any type of pizza with salad you will be quite pleased.Fresh and tasty.

Delicious,well throw in a few beers also for movie night with the girls.
author: Dani D.

description:
When I first moved here I enlisted my merry band of friends who had graciously agreed to help me unload my U-Haul truck up two flights of stairs into my lovely new house in the sun-kissed paradise of Potrero Hill.

After the 94th box they staged a revolt and refused to move a finger unless I bought them pizza.  Not knowing the area I called up my landlady who was the previous resident and asked her where to get a good pizza from.  She gave up the name of Goat Hill and I've never looked back!

I confess to being a real pizza purist, or narrow minded, depending on your viewpoint.  You see, I believe that Pizza comes with the three major food groups, cheese, tomato sauce and pepperoni.  Oh hang on, I forgot the all important ranch dressing food group (check the USDA pyramid, its on there, at the top) to dip the crust into.  Goat Hill never disappoints, they use a sourdough crust that is easy on the sour but never short of crunch, beautifully thin but it holds up perfectly under the weight of the toppings.  

We regularly get pizza delivered which comes from a different location but the quality is consistent whether you dine in or take out.  The best thing about Goat Hill is that it doesn't try and emulate the pies found on the East Coast but also resists the temptation to Californicate the ethos of the dish as dictated by the Italians.  The end result is wonderful.

My boyfriend really didn't like Goat Hill at the start as he prefers his pizzas thicker crust but once he moved from the Sunset to Pot Hill, and his beloved North Beach Pizza did not deliver any more we tried many different establishments before he admitted that none of them stood scrutiny against our favourites.

I love you Goat Hill, please never change.
author: Tony S.

description:
No complaints, a good pizza with lovely anisey sausages and a meatball hero with seriously sizable balls only a real hero could manage (mamma mia).

You can't rush a good thing and pizza is no exception, we were starving and it felt like an eternity - however, it was the perfect opportunity to flit across the street to Delirious and pick up a cute pair of K-Swiss (K-Swisses?) for the hungry hubby.
author: GIR ..

description:
The pizza is pretty good, and they have enough interesting varieties to make it worth going back to try them all.   

We really love Monday, all-you-can-eat salad and pizza night ($10). It's a salad bar and then dim sum style pizza service.  There is something quaint about being able to eat dinner for ten bucks.  Sure, people in Omaha do it all the time, but for me it's like a Normal Rockwell painting come to life.  The place gets packed though, so plan to wait for a table.  It's quite the cheapskate scene.
author: Tonie C.

description:
I went with a big group of friends last night to Goat Hill Pizza and assumed we were going to some same ole, run of the mill pizza place. I was pleasantly surprise at how amazing the pizza was! The crust was delicious and they had a variety of vegetarian pizza options (which I'm a fan of). They're salad was also really good too.

Goat Hill Pizza is definitely worth a visit and one of the better (if not the best) pizza I've had in the city so far.
author: Galeet L.

description:
Tasty pizza with a perfect portion!!  It's not the SUPER-AMERICAN-MORE-MERRIER kind of size, but just enjoyable and fit amount of food that I like to have. Although I'd have only 2 slices from a medium pizza, then my friend would eat the rest of it!  

Love their pizza!
author: N. C.

description:
When I was a kid my parents used to throw my birthday parties in the back room at Goat Hill. Now that I am older, I can go there on my own and gorge on all that pizza. I went here recently for the Monday night all you can eat pizza and salad. My friends called me up and we made our way to Goat Hill. Parking is tough around there so after trekking up the hill, we made it into Goat Hill. The wait was not long at all for 3 people. Maybe 5 minutes and the place was pretty crowded at 7:30pm. 

Warning: do not come here drunk and on an empty stomach!! You will end up eating way too much pizza.

The pizza was very good and kept coming all night. I felt bad rejecting some pizza but I ate just way too much. The variation of pizza was very nice. They had some favorites, pepperoni and mushroom and some interesting combinations that included linguicia, garlic and spinach. The service was good especially the pizza coming around, my friends at times had 4 slices on their plates (I never had more than 2). I am coming back to Goat Hill very soon!!
author: D J.

description:
Review for dine-in experience:
Okay so I went here on a lunch date...the pizza and salad were GREAT, but we had to sit a while waiting to have our order taken.  ay ay ay people it's LUNCH TIME!  We got schedules to maintain!!!  Dunno it it's an ongoing problem.
author: Dwayne A.

description:
My friend Mike introduced me to the Monday stuff your face until your gut explode pizza special.  You start off with a simple no frills salad bar. As I cautiously pick through the salad choices, I commented that we don't want to load up on fiber and miss out on the carbfest. Along the way, I managed to pour a handful of unlabeled dressing which strangely resembled pure olive oil and exclaimed "CRAP!" while the guy behind me laughed. 

The layout is dim sum pizza style for a FAT fee of $10.95. Trays and trays of different types of delicious hot slices of pizza were brought by your table and you get to say "yay or nay" to it. To pace myself cause my eyes are always bigger than my small tummy, I kept asking them for a small slice. Of course, after merry-go-round of small slices, the only evidence of the meal were the leftover crusts. Total slices inhaled by me-6. Mike was smart, he left no evidence. 

One of the server lady was sweet as pecan pie and was calling everyone "honey" and "darling" which made the whole place even more quaint. On the walls were multiple pieces of art by a local artist and if you know of anyone interested in showing their pieces, you can call in and put in a request. 

Overall, I definitely recommend this place. It's cute with great service and great choice options for everyone. Totally against any type of diet out there, but life is short and an occasional carbfest never killed anyone....yet.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Ordered a large pizza and raviolis

- I was expecting a greasy pizza, but ended up with something that had no oil on it and very little tomato sauce. Imagine the opposite of pizza hut.I
- Pizza tasted kinda healthy....not what I'm used to
- The raviolis were not very good and the veggie sauce was funny tasting.

I think the problem was that I ordered a pretty healthy pizza as opposed to the meat lover (sauce, pepperoni, chicken, bacon...you get the point) pizza with extra bacon. In that case, I think the pizza would be pretty damn good. 


Bottom Line: 
Pretty good if you're in for a non-greasy pizza with fresh ingredients.
author: Andy C.

description:
on our way to Zachary's in Berkeley but stuck in the ever annoying traffic we decided to cut out at Vermont St and head over to Goat Hill. we happend to stumble upon the monday night extravaganza. $10.95 for all you can eat pizza and salad. and the pizza is brought to you fresh, unlike those CiCi's pizza commercials where you have to walk up to a bar with pizza that's been warming under a lamp. perfect for a glutton who also chooses to be lazy. yes, please do bring pizza my way.

to maximize your eating extravaganza....
-stay away from the salad, it's just food full of water and is a liquid filler.
-don't eat the crust, it's plain and not worth the calories.
-skip the pepperoni and cheese pizzas, there are many better types coming you're way, trust me.
author: Regina C.

description:
Dear Goat Hill Pizza,
Your pizza is overrated and your owner is an a-hole
No, I will not elaborate, he seems the type to take revenge
Take Care
Former Customer
author: Diana K.

description:
you guys are amazing!!! 

we owe you such an immense thank you!!! 
you guys didn't hesitate...for a second!!
 
while we were helping victims from the disaster at sfo today...you guys didn't hesitate to deliver (& donate!!) a ton of your gorgeous pizzas to the nursing, medical and support staff at sfgh emergency department!! 
 
after a 12 hour shift...i lack the words to truly express my gratitude. 

your response was without hesitation, abundant, and desperately needed. (the deliverer even refused to take a tip)

your support is truly and greatly appreciated!!! truly...beyond words or a yelp review. 

http://www.alternet.org/news-amp-politics/airplane-crashes-san-francisco-airport-while-trying-land-2-dead-and-10-critically
author: Sfgh E.

description: Great place to go on Monday nights for "all you can eat."  Otherwise, I feel it is overpriced.  That being said, I think the quality varies a bit depending on when you go and where you are sitting.  I think they use up whatever they have leftover and one Monday night it seemed they had a ton of leftover ground beef!  Gross!  Ground beef pizzas were constantly coming through and I don't eat beef.  If they could be more consistent and offer better prices on non-neighborhood nights, I would consider adding a star or two.
author: GranolaGorilla Z.

description: I'm more of a deep dish pizza person, but Goat Hill Pizza rocks!  The sourdough crust is crispy and chewy, which I really like.  I love their Portuguese pizza, it's the one I always order when I go there!
author: Van P.

description:
I love their crust and always look forward to the end of my pizza when I can get to the bites of pure crust. It's genuinely delicious, unlike most pizzas where it's just a vehicle for the toppings.

My only sorrow is that, for those prices, you should be getting organic food. Now if they could be offering an all-organic pizza (or at least organic cheese!) I would be eating there much more often.
author: Geae D.

description:
Quaint place in the quiet Pot Hill of the city!   I wasn't expecting to see so many people lined up outside the door on a Monday evening, but I soon learned that it was "all you can eat" Monday night at the joint!  It was fun to see everyone in their festive holiday moods, tummy preparing for a good fix of endless pizza.

 We tried their Mediterranean pizza and it was pretty good.  The sourdough crust, topped with spinach, feta, garlic and cheese made for a great combo.    I'd go again if I am ever in the hood again!
author: Megha S.

description:
Alas, I can't eat cheese, so it's been ages since I actually had pizza. But I'd been hearing about the soy cheese pizza at Goat Hill...really?

OMG. It's so good. 

Thank you Goat Hill Pizza!
author: Michelle V.

description: I've only been there once, so I'm not sure if this is the norm, but they had more or less an 'all you can eat' type thing going on for $10 (drinks not included). After we got seated, the waitresses/waiters would randomly bring by different pizzas and one could take some or not at will. They had a lot of very interesting selections I've never even heard of anywhere else. Everything I had was quite good, much better than from any chain I've been too, and I loved the uniqueness of the types of pizza served. I'm usually a pretty picky eater and if I read a review about a 'unique pizza place' I'm not sure I'd go for it. If that's you, take a risk. Low cost and well worth it!
author: Tim B.

description:
Although its a bit of a drive from my place, its certainly worth the trip.

The crust is sourdough and the toppings are tasty...

Definitely check it out.
author: Ken S.

description:
I think this may be the only pizza I've felt comfortable having with a glass of Merlot.

The crust is great and Neighborhood nights (Monday evenings) are amazing.  Neighborhood nights aren't just all you can eat for a decent price but there are so many variations of pizzas coming from ALL directions. It's a bunch of different versions of thin slices of pizzas traveling around the room dim sum style.

They don't take reservations on Monday nights for good reason; but, at the same time, it is worth the wait.

Tip: try not to eat much during the day before you try to go out here. I was full that evening and for the next day and a half.

Why only 4 stars?  It's for the wait time on a Monday evening, other than that... they are doing quite well.
author: Anita J.

description:
Goat Hil Pizza has some of the best pizzas in San Francisco. They give you a good amount of cheese, meat, and other fresh toppings on their pizzas. As usual, pizza joints aren't known for their salads. Their buffalo wings are decent. Almost any of their speciality pizzas on their menu is delicious. 

Too bad, parking is a pain in the a** on this side of Potrero Hill. Likewise, the name of the restaurant Goat Hill is situated on the corner of a street near steep hiils. Great scenery of the city when the weather is good.
author: Joseph N.

description:
The epitome of a friendly neighbor that always has pizza for you. Their pizza crust is just delish. Our dogs love the left over pizza crust too. Compared to other pizza crusts, I think Goat Hill's is their favorite.

I just read some guy's review of their delivery and I don't think real pizza snobs order pizzas with chicken, artichoke hearts, and soy cheese.
author: Clodel G.

description:
For the longest time when I drove by this place I hadn't noticed the "Hill" in the sign.  

Goat Pizza... I'll have to find and try that someday.

This place reminds me of some of the pizzerias I used to go to as a kid.  Casual dining, plastic table "cloths" and the whole joint smelling like a giant pizza.  Luckily the pizza is a lot better than those places I used to go.  It also tends heavily toward that family dining atmosphere, so you might want to avoid coming here if you're really wasted.

It was Friday night.  We were seated quickly and received our pizza in about 12 minutes.  One thing I instantly noticed is the crust.  It's almost, well... perfect.  Yeah, it tastes like regular old pizza crust but the ratios are perfect.  The pizza wasn't thin crust but at the same time, didn't feel like I was eating a bread boat with each slice.  The toppings and cheese were well portioned as well and one bite didn't result in my ripping the cheese off into my lap and me cussing like a sailor.  In the end you feel like you've had some good pizza and not half a loaf of garlic bread.  

I thought their cheapest salad left something to be desired.  I know it was only $4, but I've had more bountiful pre-pizza salads for cheaper, although the kidney and garbanzo beans were a nice touch.  Other than this it was mostly good.  

Except for all the kids.  They started a mini-bowling game using the high chairs as pins and their bodies as balls.  C'mon, parents.
author: Steven R.

description:
The pizza here is pretty great but I haven't been thrilled with any of the pasta dishes we have tried.  It's a fun place to stop in for dinner any night of the week but beware of the children who come in droves with their parents and friends before about 7:0, especially if there is a birthday party going on...For best results come about 2 hours before closing time.

Enjoy!
author: Katie V.

description:
Ask for the THIN crust.  Crispy and delicious sour dough crust that combines the best of New York and the Best of San Francisco into a pie of  deliciousness.  I usually get the California or the Pesto, my wife usually gets the GIGANTIC Salad bowl with garlic bread.

AND THEY DELIVER!!!!

Try the Monday Night All-You -Can-EAT, but get there early and be prepared to wait.
author: Dan W.

description:
Hmm. Nice tasting pizza. I like the sourdough, soy cheese is a nice touch.

But I'm still searching for the perfect thin crust, Italian style. 

if anybody finds one PLEASE let me know!
author: Leah O.

description:
OK, my favorite not deep dish pizza in town.

Fresh ingredients, well prepared, efficient take out , pizza always hot.

Pick: Mediterranean, then add spicy sausage.  WOW.
author: Ken p.

description:
pretty good pizza.

Salad was iceberg lettuce...what is this 1970's New Jersey???  Get some greens in there!  

four stars is appropriate, however more accurately it would be 3.5
author: Matt V.

description:
After experiencing my first Monday Night Pizza Awesomeness, I will be sure to come back, and next time, I might skip all the way there. Although that hill can be kind of a bitch. Nevertheless, this place is great. The sourdough is terrific, the sauce is splendid and all the ingredients (with the exception of the pineapple) were superb.

I would hard-pressed to choose between this place and Unkie Vito's for deliciousness, but the Monday Night Pizza Awesomeness puts GHP well above Vito's (even though Vito's gets the twins occasionally).
author: Josh B.

description:
This is cute little pizza place right on Potrero Hill. It has the simple classic italian restaurant feel. How it got the name Goat Hill I don't really know but I did notice a picture on the wall with goats on what might have been Potrero Hill, a long time ago? 

FOOD: The kewl thing about this place is that they aren't NY or Chicago style, instead its in between and they use a sourdough crust. To really taste the sourdough, save the crust and eat it without the pizza topping, its delicious! Two of us split a small spinach and sausage pizza. You can taste quality, the sausage was slightly spicy and yummy, and extra garlic is free...LOVE GArLIc!

DRINKS: You can get a carafe of the house wine for $7.00, it was decent and was about 2 servings for each of us. Not a bad deal!

Monday nights I hear they have all you can eat special, I'll be there!
author: Venatius P.

description:
Great view of the city, yummy pizza!

The Mediterranean pizza  and the vegetarian pizza is excellent with lots of garlic. Very flavorful. The crust is delicious.

This is a great place for a semi-large crowd. Good pizza and beer.
author: Chili B.

description:
Delicious Portuguese pizza with a side of two huge meatballs. I really wanted to have a beer but it felt wrong to be drinking so early in the afternoon (pre-noon brunch). And I had to drive us back home.

Someone messed up our order - we ordered a small pizza but got what the waiter thought was a medium pizza (the people at the table next to us asked him what size we had).
author: Rob T.

description:
I'm definitely of a split personality on this one - a perfectly acceptable week-night take out option combined with one of the most unpleasant dining-in experiences of my adult life...
The pizza is serviceable to good.  
Now for the warning - NEVER EVER show up later than your friends or family for the Monday nite cheapo deal.  You will be subjected to abusive treatment if you wish to join them.  Or better yet, skip the cheapo nite altogether, as the pizza quality goes down several notches.
We still go for the take out - but then again they're the only game in Potrero.
author: Dan C.

description:
I was in Potereo Hill last week and something smelled amazing.  I went to the source and took the name down.  Luckily, I actually remembered the name when we wanted to order in tonight.

The pizza was solid and we would order from Goat HIll again.  The sauce was good and the crust was thin but a little doey on top.
author: Amy G.

description:
The pizza, lasagne, and sandwiches are all delicious and reasonably priced. Check the all-you-can-eat Mondays! Service varied depending on whether the waiter was identified as an artist or not (just joshin', but that's how I felt about this one foolio who served us). 

Love the feel of the place. There's always art on the walls!

Kick it real @ Goat Hill. Check out their t-shirt. EEEEVIL!
author: André C.

description:
A few friends and I rolled in unknowingly to Goat Hill on a Monday. This is our story.

For those that don't know (I didn't), Monday nights are all-you-can-eat for about $10. And we're not talking 4-hour-cold buffets here. They've got their oven-machines churning in the back, spitting out hot and delicious pizzas. The waiters walk around throwing a slice on any plate that wants one.

You would think a system like that wouldn't work. But it does.

The pizza itself is very good. Some of the best in San Francisco.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I'm not a real fan of pizza but I like good service and cute decor.  Oh, and cheap wine.  Cheap wine is critical.  Goat Hill Pizza has all of these things: pizza, decent service, classic style italian table cloths, and wine for $11 a liter.  If I liked pizza, I'm sure I'd really like this place.  As it is Goat Hill Pizza stands as my favorite place to go out for pizza when I've lost the "what are we going to eat" game - mainly because the cheap wine means I no longer care about what we are eating.

It would make a good casual date restaurant.  It isn't overly expensive and if the other person makes some sort of "ick, pizza" comment there is a ton of other stuff right up the street.  I wouldn't say it is anything special nor will it impress anyone, but it manages to be sufficiently cute without being pretentious.    

But, really, it is all about the $11 a liter wine.
author: Dee B.

description:
Fun atmosphere, great ambience, solid service staff, above average selection of pizzas, pastas, salads, and appetizers. Very kid friendly... just a great neighborhood place for food, drinks, and a good time.

Upgrade your quality of mozzarella and you get 5 stars from me. I realize this is a huge cost cutting measure, but you are better served tacking an extra buck to beer and wines by the glass, and changing your distributor for cheese. When it comes to pizza, cheese speaks volumes.
author: Ivan A.

description: We went here on a Thursday night with 2 couples, each with a toddler in tow, hoping to find a good place for families, and drawn in by the wonderful pizza smell outside. However, we seemed to arrive right at the moment they were slammed, so while the staff was all very nice and friendly, service was extremely slow and not attentive. We waited about 30 minutes for a table, and were seated with no menus and no drinks. We waited about twenty minutes before someone passed and noticed we hadn't been helped. Finally, our waitress took our orders for drinks and dinner. When another waitress returned with drinks, we realized we had forgotten to order an entree for one of the kids (!) and placed our order then. Then we waited, and waited. They initially forgot to bring water for everyone, and only brought out beer and wine; we had to ask for water again. Then our late-ordered pasta entree came out, ahead of all the other food (including our appetizer) that we'd ordered. Fortunately it was for our son who was at the end of his rope waiting for dinner. 15 minutes later we had our appetizer and water, then finally, another 10 minutes or so, we got our pizza....after the people at the table next to us, who were seated after us, got their food. Despite the chaos, all the food was very good. The bruschetta is three *huge* pieces of soft yummy Italian bread topped with generous chunks of tomato. We got the Hilda's Favorite and Portuguese pizzas, which were also very good. My son loved his ravioli and meatballs. However, it would have been a much better experience if the service hadn't been such a mess.
author: Rachel L.

description:
This restaurant is by far one of the best pizza places in SF.  At a glance looking at their restaurant you may not guess it, but it definitely is.  They get 5 Stars for clean dishes, clean tasting ice tea (many restaurants dishes don't look clean, and their Iced Tea tasts like old musty water.)

The real reason they get 5 stars from me is because of their pizza's perfect crust.  It isn't greasy (like Amici's) and it doesn't taste like cardboard (like Extreme Pizza) .  It's light, fresh, and has a little cornmeal on the bottom to give it a perfect crunchyness.  When ordering, they are extremely prompt as well, which is golden.

I would definitely recommend their pizza above anything else I've tried in SF, go for the Goat! :-D
author: Delilah W.

description: The pizza is great with plenty of fresh garlic. The bruchetta is one of the finest especially if you like fresh basi, olive oil, and garlic. You can order half orders of pasta which is perfect if you want a variety of dishes. The staff is nice and the place is clean. The down side is that parking can be difficult during the week but weekends seem to be better.
author: Alexis W.

description: Great place in a part of town that doesn't get as much credit as it deserves. I came for lunch with a couple of colleagues, and we had delicious pizza (half veggie and half "meat lovers"). Service was friendly, vibe was relaxed and comfortable. Nice place - I'll definitely be back.
author: Bret W.

description: Tasty pizzas, beer in pitchers, and you can walk up those killer Potrero Hills to burn it all off afterwards. I wasn't wild about the thick crust on the meat lovers' pie that was dry at times, but the mediterranean veg pie was spot-on. Place was pleasantly crowded, and service was very nice.
author: Lisa P.

description: The pizza was great.  The pizzas tasted like it just came out of the oven because it was to little to hot to bite in it lucky I was careful.  We had a big group to eat here.  Right after we volunteer at the food bank.  I tried the meat lover, presto, vegetarian pizza and combo but  I actually did what the name of of the pizza was.
author: John F.

description:
When I went in to pick up my three pizzas, the woman at the counter was on the phone with another customer explaining she had given him MY pizzas and asked him to come back and pick up his pizzas.  When she hung up the phone, I was not given any apologies, just a cold hard glare.  She did throw a paper bag at me and told me I could get my own paper plates and napkins while waiting.

So I stood at the counter awkwardly for about 5 minutes and finally took my pizzas from another random customer who returned.  

I wasn't asking for a refund, a credit or any sort of discount.  I was just looking for a little customer service by way of an apology or even acknowledgment that releasing your food to another customer and then taking it back from them is a little weird.

Horrible customer service.  Mediocre pizza.
author: Juliana C.

description: Not a bad pizza shack.  I was walking home to my new apartment when I saw a sign: "Fresh Pizza Slices, Walk-up Window."   This was perfect, I thought, as I was terribly hungry from a long day and long commute.  I thought I'd give it a shot.  Turns out this place is one of the only sour dough pizza shacks in the city.  Although it had a walk-up friendly business, down a discreet alley, it still was not very quick.  I think I waited about 20 minutes or more standing outside for a fresh slice that was made to order.  It seemed that they were cleaning up for the day and finishing several big deliveries as I saw about 3 take out orders pass thru as I waited for one slice.  I don't know if your experience was different, or if this is a place that stays open late after bars close to feed hungry patrons on their walk home, but it didn't seem very good on convenience or price.  The quality was pretty exceptional, but I think it was advertised a little improperly.   I think they are going for more quality for delivery services rather than walk-up's and quick bites.  Overall, decent experience.
author: Adam N.

description: Ordered 2 pizzas for delivery to my job, very good, a little pricey and their large is more like a medium, xlarge is more like a large.... oh well, I know what I like.
author: Rpm R.

description:
This is as good as it gets if you are looking for :
**A San Francisco tradition: 30 years and counting, how many restaurants can say that?
***Unpretentious, unique, delicious pizza (mmm sourdough crust) made fresh with quality ingredients 
** a GREAT view of the city from the back dining room 
** Owners who honnor and treat both their employees and customers with respect and genuine care, all in a fun, comfortable environment.
author: D S.

description:
I love this place!!! The sourdough crust may not sound intuitive, but after you try it you'll wonder what kind of crap you sustained yourself on through college and how it is that you're still alive.
It's a true neighborhood, casual restaurant - you can go there in your jammies if you wanted to and enjoy some super-fine pizza.  Their pre-made salads aren't anything special, but that wouldn't stop me from going there on a weekly basis if I could.  Then again, I can!
author: Andrea S.

description:
This is a great pizzaria, perfect for when you're looking for a simple yummy pizza.  You've absolutely got to stop by on all-you-can-eat-pizza night.

I always ask them to make the crust a little less crispy - as it can be a little too crunchy for my taste.
author: Nick T.

description:
I went to what is called neighborhood night which is all you can eat pizza. 

I sat down kinda nervous because apparently it's like dim sum and I was kinda nervous for that too. I just didn't know what to expect. What I got was pretty awesome. Like 6 or 8 slices of pizza and they had an all you can eat salad bar for 9 bucks. The pizza is really yummy too. A lil greasy but the crust is crunchy and tastes best with ranch. This place is pretty awesome although its been like four hours since i've eaten there and i'm still full.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
A while back I got a Yelp email listing a few good pizza places in SF.  Goat Hill was one I hadn't tried.  Basically, it's OK.

The pizza ain't bad, it is not really that great either.  The crust is the unique part.  They make a not-thin, not-thick crust from sourdough.  What you get is something that (with the crust) resembles a dessert pizza.  I prefer really thin crust.  The cheese is good and the sauce is bland.  They do have green olives as a topping which I very much like.

The other cool thing about this place is that it's lively.  The servers and owner have a great rapport with some of the customers, who I assume live nearby or are regular visitors.  Good for them.  As for me, I will look elsewhere for my favorite pizza.
author: Michael S.

description:
Meh at best.

Everybody loves this place.  But, not me.

Alas, the cheese stands alone.
author: Jeff P.

description:
So working for a VERY busy pizzeria in Seattle years ago, I understand the crazy busy nights Friday's would bring. Yet through it all, we still managed to be friendly and courteous to those calling in. 

I went onto Yelp to find a pizza place near where I live; I found Goat Hill. On their Yelp page, they offer one number to call so I called it. The person that answered was very rude when she put me on hold. When she finally returned I asked her how long the delivery time was, she even more rudely replied, "I don't know, call the delivery line!" Seriously? That's how you talk to customers that want to give you business? If management reads these, you need to offer a class in customer service. The saving grace is that the pizza here is actually pretty good.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
this review is for the pizza itself, not the restaurant, or the experience. 

not sure what all the fuzz about this place is about.  we ordered a veggie pizza for delivery.  quite simply, it was completely unremarkable.  the toppings were overcooked, the sauce lacked flavor, and the consistency was, well not right.  the corn meal crust is good, but not great, and IMHO i think the crust at little star has a clear leg up.

the pie wasn't much to look at, and at $25 delivered, was overpriced.

to me, this is maybe a place i'd try again if i was catching a show at the bottom of the hill, but only because of the generally positive reviews here.  otherwise, with much better pizza options not far away, i'd go elsewhere.
author: Matt G.

description: A very low key staple of the city.  Dependable great food and a good time.  I am a bit of a snob when it comes to pizza, and it took me some time to find a place in the area I liked when I moved here 4 years ago.  Thankful, Goat hill has my back!
author: Jean P.

description: Not impressed with anything on their menu.  It's such a generic pizza place with no sense of what real Italian food is.  I don't think they've heard of fresh anything.   The prices were a little too high for the quality of food they have.  Should've hit up a Taco Truck.
author: Edward P.

description: Goat Hill is a damn good pie.  I wish I was digging into a slice instead of typing this right now.  If you want the perfect day, go do an Anchor tour and follow it up with a pie after.   Heavenly!
author: chuck p.

description: I love this SF place! My husband who said he is not much of a pizza fan, loves this place too! He said this is DIFFERENT. It's in a different category, like gourmet or couture. The price is like RTP(round table), but an upscale pizza joint. It would be nice to pair it with wine as well, but I haven't.  The crust was perfectly crunchy, not hard or burnt, like other places. Fresh, generous amount of italian sausage makes it tasty, but a little oily. I also requested for a side of pepperchinis, which are to die for, esp. for those adventurous pizza lovers.
author: Louise T.

description: Best crust and decent salad bar.  And love love love Monday night all you can eat!  I used to go there 15 years ago with my Step-Mom, it's her fav too... gotta give props that they're still around.
author: Bin M.

description: There are two things I can't live without.  One is my significant other and the other is pizza!  I love pizza-especially pizza by the slice.  But of course, finding pizza by the slice isn't hard in SF, but finding a place that uses super fresh produce and ingredients is.  The pizza is delicious, not super greasy, and I really appreciate the quality of the ingredients.
author: Natasha K.

description: PS: all you can eat Mondays!!!! BIG fan :)
author: May D.

description:
Ugh.  I am so full.  You know that feeling when you're extremely tired, but you know that lying down will just induce....something quite unpleasant because your tummy is jam packed?  Well, that's me right about now.  Waking up for work tomorrow is going to be a nightmare.  Ugh.  BUT, this is not to say that I won't be returning to Goat Hill Pizza.....

Came here tonight for the first time with some friends per DC and his wifey's recommendation (great pick, D & W!).  Monday nights are the way to go with this place, as it's all you can eat pizza and salad for around $10 (the bf asked why I had even bothered gymming prior to all you can eat pizza, and I replied, "Duh!  So I can eat all you can eat pizza!!")!  Show up early, as the wait can be hit or miss (thanks, T, for arriving early and ensuring the rest of us scavengers a seat!).

So here's how it works: this place is like a dim sum joint except instead of serving dim sum, you get pizza (duh)!  Waitstaff, each with a pizza tray in hand, float around the restaurant, visiting table to table, offering hot, slim, thin crust sourdough (I normally am anti-sourdough, but this place was yum!  I couldn't even detect any sour-ness in the crust!) slices of deliciousness.  And what's great about this pizza buffet is the various toppings that make their way onto numerous pizza combinations.  There's cheese, feta, pesto, garlic, tomatoes, onions, red onions, bell peppers, black olives, green olives, artichoke, spinach, mushroom, pineapple, jalapeno, hamburger, ham, salami, pepperoni, linguica, and sausage (did I get them all?).  Out of the twelve slices I ate (remember, the slices are cut small, so you can try all the variations..and I didn't eat my crusts), my favorite was the pesto tomato black olive.  Then again, by the sixth or seventh slice, I had already begun to lose track of what I had eaten.

Service was very friendly.  The employees were unfazed as ravenous patrons thrust plate after plate into their faces.  After we left the restaurant, a couple employees were outside on their breaks, but still thanked us and said bye.  They even cautioned against getting cramps as we trekked up the slight incline on Connecticut, heavy stomached, back to our cars. 

The only con I noticed was that when we first sat down, it was as if the employees were tag-teaming each other, approaching us every couple of minutes with new pizza offerings; the pizza seemed limitless.  However, after these first few rounds of pizza slices, there was a huge lull.  We sat around for what had to have been at least 15 minutes before the next pizza began circulating the restaurant, and even then, it was another 5 - 10 minutes before the pizza after that arrived.  As I sat there waiting for more pizza, my hunger slowly disappeared (in hindsight, maybe this was a good thing, since I am still so stuffed right now).

Oh, yeah, the all you can eat salad bar?  I didn't even bother taking a peek at it.  It was a very tiny bar, with, I'm assuming the regular fixings...but who wants salad?  Bring on the pizza!!
author: Mel T.

description: Goat Hill Pizza is my favorite, and I'm so lucky it's right down the street!  Their crust is the best--tangy, chewy, crackling crisp.  And how can you "top" all-you-can-eat Mondays??  With anything and everything, that's how!  Mmmm, roasted garlic... The line is out the door on Monday nights, but it's worth the wait.
author: Davina C.

description:
Monday night- it's pizza Dim Sum!  Seriously, you sit at a table while the wait staff bring around many many different kinds of pizza cut into thin little slices.  If you like that kind, then you get a slice or two.  It's all you can eat pizza at a great price!  There is a salad bar included (ranch dressing + beets = heaven!).  

I also get pizza to go here regularly- I recommend the californian or pesto.  I really like the crust.  I also like how the person taking my order on the phone asks the pizza cooker how long my order will take.
author: Becky P.

description:
I've heard about this place before and finally decided to take the plunge.  " All You Can Eat Monday Nights " for 10.95 its not bad, but the only downside would be the place is small.. With that in mind I figured the line would be long so the GF and I arrived shortly after 5:45.  We ordered a pint and were seated within 5 minutes.  NO special attention here. The servers come out with a variety of pizza for you to choose from and then its either a YES or a NO.  Oh FYI they have a mini salad bar for that vegetarian in your party

The Pizza was pretty good and I would come back on a non Monday night. The crust is the star which has a nice crunch, and the slices are a just enough to experience all the different pies.  All the pizza's are tasty and unique including  original pepperoni & cheese, to Hawaiian Style.  If your looking for something new to try go check out there Monday night
author: Robert M.

description:
I've never gone inside of a Goat Hill Pizza. I've always had it delivered.

Their pizza is delicious and everyone I've had try it with me agrees.

The delivery guys are always quick (usually quicker than they say) and friendly.
author: Ty L.

description: Best pizza I've had so far in San Francisco; the sauce, cheese, and crust were awesome.  The Chef Salad is also very good, the peppercini's make the salad!  Only four stars because my ranch was actually bleu cheese (but good bleu cheese at that) and it was kind of pricey for just a small one-topping pizza and a salad.
author: Rachelle P.

description: I don't understand the high avg rating for this place?  I was excited to try this place. I heard about it a couple of times by a couple of friends. I was meeting a friend out for dinner and said let's give it a whirl.  The neighborhood is nice, easy parking. The place looks kinda cool on the outside. You walk in and it starts looking more like a run down pizza parlor chain.  I read many reviews on here about how the wait staff was wonderful. Well, our waiter was far from good, and even seemed to have trouble taking our order, and I think I"m being nice in leaving it at that.  We got a half and half pizza, plus garlic cheese bread. The bread came out and was abundant but nothing fantastic.  The pizza came out and looked pretty good but after biting in it just seemed average at best.  The crust was nice and crunchy, i like that, yet it seemed so manufactured and almost too perfectly even all over. The view from our table was nice. I'd say the view was the only great thing in the place.  It appears that this place is well thought of for their Monday night all you can eat. Well, I have never seen real high quality all you can eat anything except maybe an 80 dollar buffet in Vegas and even that wasn't true high quality if you ask me. So, if you want to stuff you face with avg pizza and feel like you're kind of in a brightly lit fluorescent cafeteria that hopes to fill it's seats with screaming kids and cheap parents,, then this is your place.  Otherwise, go to Pazzia, or 00 for an adult higher quality experience.
author: Rodney P.

description:
The food and prices here are amazing, terrific, wonderous!! But the service left more to be desired. 
If you eat in it takes a whole lunch break to get your food, and: hate to say it... but the waitress is a biotch.
author: Danielle G.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza Haiku:

I am so hungry
I would like goat hill pizza
garlic yum garlic
author: sunshine c.

description:
On a cold rainy night a grumbling began from the depth of hell.  OK I am being a little dramatic, but seriously I was hungry.  The 1.5 hour wait time for the delivery of the pizza was terrible.  Everything hinged on the pizza being there.  We couldn't start the movie and no one was talking to each other because they were so hungry.  I thought I was going to have an situation similar to the move 'Alive'.

Then the phone rang and everyone perked up with wide eyes.  It was my mom.  Ha, I am such a trickster.  It was the pizza and just in the nick of time as I was going to have a mutiny.  Two larges were completely demolished in 10 minutes.  I have to give the pizza a 3.5 star as it hasn't been consistent with the last pizza.
author: Po L.

description:
So, I went here with Sean and Tim for Monday night, all you can eat pizza. Even before we entered (we had to wait outside for about 20 minutes for a table) I knew we were going to have fun. This place is really laid back but with a fun and exciting atmosphere. The pizza was very tasty and the very friendly and personable servers kept coming by with lots and lots of unique pizzas to pick and choose from. Even the salad bar, which comes with the meal, was fresh and stocked up. 
In conclusion, if you're hankering for some good pizza and you're with some homies, head to Goat Hill. Their 'monday night all you can eat pizza night' is like having Dim Sum pizza- and how cool is that??
author: Robert L.

description:
cute chicks coming around, forcing steaming slices of pizza on you during their all-you-can eat Mondays....totally hawt.

salad bar is underwhelming, but what do you expect?  i'm not of an all-you-can eat afficionado, but the pizzas were decent.  not the best in the world (i'm more into a cracker thin crust), but in the context of the price, i'd give this place 3.5 stars.

i was a bit dissapointed they didn't actually have Goat Pizza...which is dangerously close to falling under the auspices of false advertisement, but i decided to let it slide, since i don't even know what goat tastes like.
author: Miss P.

description: I originally called Goat Hill Pizza on Potrero Hill, and was given a different number to call (a new delivery location south of Market). I called that number and ordered my Pizza, for delivery to Bernal Heights. The next day I noticed I had been charged an outrageous $4.50(!) for the delivery service. No employee at either location explained this NEW FEE or procedure. Besides that, I was disappointed in the quality of the Pizza, the crust was too thick & doughy & the cheese was weird... I want my delivery charge refunded, so I can go to Arinell's Pizza for a great slice of Pizza!
author: Chris Ellen M.

description: neighborhood day is buffet-style and you can eat tens of slices of pizzas in minutes. yum! many different toppings today.
author: Sahil L.

description: We went here for a quick lunch and ordered a Hilda's Favorite (pesto, goat cheese and tomatoes).  Overall the pizza was good and filling.  The cornmeal crust was nice, but fell apart too easily in the center.  I would have liked the goat cheese and pesto to be more flavorful and there to be less olive oil dripping from the pesto.  Also, the price is pretty high compared to other pizza places in the city.
author: Alexander N.

description: A 4-star joint that gets bumped up to 5 because of the soy cheese pizza and ridiculously cheap ($9.50) pitchers of beer.  And the meatballs (mix of beef + sausage = genius) are off the chain.
author: Doctor L.

description: Ate there several times, foods ok - staff could be better.  Ordered the "everything"  asked for no whole garlic.  Got it home and it was covered - was ok I guess i like garlic more than I thought but I asked for none.  Went again for the famous "all you can eat" getting a slice was difficult and there was nothing but non-typical fancy types  no peperoni or sausage and mushroom. Tried a third time to order and pick up.  Called in and spoke with Brian.  Asked if they could do half spagetti half ravioli.  He said I could half orders of each for three dollars more than a regular full order.  I asked in his opinion which was his favorite.  He said Lasagna.  I said great I'll order that and I asked if I could do the salad up-charge (listed on their website for $2.50) and he said that I must have wrong info and that it was $2.95.  I said its not a big deal but you should honor what he has on his own site.  He replied why are you making it a big deal and I replied I'll order from somewhere else.  He did me a favor because I found Little Joe's and they do a 50/50 with salad - it was better food.  If you like arrogant service people go to Goal Hill - if not try Little Joe's - they also deliver to Potrero Hill and are nice.
author: Joey L.

description: I went this past Monday for the Neighborhood all you can eat night.   I wasn't too impressed.  The pizza seemed low on cheese and a little extra hard.  I was really expecting better.  The salad bar was small but I enjoyed it.  That was one positive out of the whole night.
author: Ahmed B.

description:
I LOVE their pizza and used to order a pie for take out every couple of weeks when i lived in Potrero Hill.   I give a five-star review for take-out, but a one-star review for Monday Night All-You-Can-Eat.

2/12/07 - We went with a large group and knew that we would have trouble getting one table together, which we were okay with.  However, we got nothing but attitude from the host and waitresses from the moment we walked in and said there would be 10-20 of us.  If the hosts eyes rolled any harder, they would have rolled out of his head.  He made NO attempt to work with us, but was more than happy to remind of us their many rules regarding Monday nights.

When he sat 8 of us at a table for 10 (at 5:30pm in a half-empty restaurant), the waitress almost refused to serve us because they only seat complete parties.  Anyway, the service and attitude got so bad that as other friends tried to join us we were given new "rules" and they decided to go across the street to eat at Lingba.  Honestly, I thought I was in some sort of dress rehearsal for a Saturday Night Live skit on really bad service.

Advice: Stay away from Monday nights if there are more than 4 of you.
author: Dave M.

description:
We visited Goat Hill Pizza for a friend's celebratory dinner on a Friday night.  They accommodated our reservation of 15, however some of the seating was a little tight.  I sampled the Greek and the Mediterranean pizzas which were pretty tasty; the large salad was simple and hit the spot.  Another bright spot was the wine list . . . although it was short it had some pretty cheap by the bottle prices (quite low mark-up).  We had a couple of Chiantis and a syrah and they were all $20 or less!

I don't get to that part of town often and there are lots of pizza places to try, so I don't expect I'll get back.
author: Justin S.

description:
Eh.

The service was decent.  My waitress seemed to be more interested in chatting with her friends who were sitting at another table.  But we didn't have to wait too long for anything.

We had the vegetarian.  The crust was yummy and I was starving.  But the chopped garlic put over the top of the pizza was off putting.  Seriously.  I reeked of garlic for the next two days.

There is a limit to garlicky goodness.  And I do like it, but this was over the line.

I'd try it again and ask for no chopped garlic over the top.  We'll see how that goes.
author: Samantha F.

description:
I heard about this pizza place before I even moved to San Francisco.

Finally tried it, and it was incredible! I've never had a pizza so delicious for so cheap. Came out of the oven really, really hot... it was just great all around. Don't really know what else to say about it. 

Oh, and the refillable drinks are $1. AMAZING.This contrasts to my previous dining experience two days before at Belden Place where I paid $3 for a NONrefillable soda. Praise the Lord for Goat Hill's cheap goodness. 

I mean, obviously, you aren't getting like, gourmet flavors you've never experienced or anything. But this pizza certainly satisfies.
author: Angie B.

description: Reliable pizza joint. Check. All you can eat pizza on Monday nights. Check. $5 pizza lunch specials. Check. How can you go wrong with Goat Hill? The place is not pretentious. It is what it is. Pizza, sodas, and dinner salads on red and white checkerboard tablecloths. The food may not blow your mind, but Goat Hill Pizza has that neighborhoody feel that keeps people coming back to it.
author: Alex H.

description: An oldie but a goodie!  I'm usually not in this neighborhood very often, but what a great idea when we decided to go on a Sunday afternoon.  I can't remember the the name of the pizza we had, but it was the chicken one!  The crust was excellent and ingredients fresh!  San Francisco has a ton of pizza places, but Goat Hill is definitely consistently very good.  One large salad, one large pizza, ice cold beer, and we were completely content.  Great casual atmosphere, great service.
author: louis a.

description: Great for a relaxed Friday night out. Superb piano play, very friendly and attentive service and they seem to really like toddlers, which is a relief, when you bring along your 1.5 year old kid. Oh yeah, and good pizza too  ;-)
author: Lars N.

description: Was there last night. Even better than the last time. We always get the same thing: dinner salad with blue cheese dressing and a pizza with pepperoni and red onion. The salad dressing is amazing -- fresh and homemade. The joint was hopping at 6 PM. It was really comfortable for myself and family. The pizza was terrific. It's all about the crust -- really.
author: Lee M.

description:
solid neighborhood pizza joint. 

this isn't milano's perfect cheese pie in the inner sunset  nor is it gourmet cheeseboard perfection from berkeley.

just a solid neighborhood pizza joint, with better than average neighborhood pizza.  sourdough with cornmeal crust, and a far superior version than little star.  also quick no frills service. simple beers and cheap wine.
author: Nikki F.

description: I've been going here (very infrequently) since 1990.  The sauce has a unique dreamy taste that sucks you in.  Great neighborhood place but with very good food.
author: Ric S.

description:
I love this place.  Fresh ingredients, and consistent quality keep me coming back.  

Sour dough crust?  Delicious.  Actually, everything about their pizzas are delicious.

Check this place out if you are in the neighborhood.
author: J. B.

description:
Goat Hill Pizza on Connecticut SUX!!!

I just had the worst experience there and I didn't even get to EAT.  *breathing woo saaahhh*

Ok,

So I go for a late lunch (around 3pm).  Drive over to Potrero Hill, and voila - there's a parking space right in front!  Great!!! The Gods are shining on me.  NOT!  So I go in and there are 4 people in the entire restaurant.  One guy was finished eating and just sitting savoring that delicious sourdough crust Goat Hill is know for.  A couple are waiting for their food, and one guy was placing his order as I walked in.  The sign said "Please wait to be seated".  So I wait. And wait some more. And wait a little bit more.  Then I read the sign again...u know, just to be sure I read it right the first time.  So I wait.  Then I make eye contact with the server (big woman with big nasty attitude). She looks at me and go behind the counter and gets a pitcher of water for the people who were already seated.  She gives them the water and walks back behind the counter.  Then the telephone rings.  She takes the call, and gets plates for those already sitting.  Then she gives them their plates and continues to ignore me.  So when we make eye contact again, I say shall I seat myself?  WRONG MOVE.  She snarled ever so loudly "NO DON'T SEAT YOURSELF.  YOU DON'T WANT IT TO GO?"  I just politely said never mind and left.

Never again!  For real!
author: blak k.

description:
worst pizza I have ever eaten.  crust is way too thin, greasy, and soggy.  I would not be suprised if they used processed cheese food, rather than actual cheese.

*puke*
author: Peter H.

description: Goat Hill's a good sit down pizza establishment for when you want to savor the food, as opposed to the hole-in-the walls where you're forced to do the dine and dash.  But the pizza itself was average tasting.  The staff wasn't the most welcoming, but I've come to expect that from pizza joints.  From the back dining area, the view from the top out to downtown and the Civic Center is great at night.
author: Marsha Z.

description: One of my favorite pizza delivery places ever. I love their sourdough crust and when I ask them to make it really crispy, they always come through. My favorite toppings are pepperoni, mushrooms, and green olives and I order the Chef's salad so I can dip the crust into the ranch dressing. Delivery service is good, too. They do a good job of giving you a somewhat long time estimate and then coming through quicker. Ordered last night and they said an hour. It arrived in 40 minutes. Score!
author: J.J. P.

description: Goats eat everything, and in my recent lunch party of four, we behaved like total Goats--we wolfed down everything but some bread that came with a salad.  I love the cornmeal-dusted, crunchy crust on our pizza--very flavorful and just the right texture.  The rest of the pie was good too but believe it or not the toppings were a little too heavy.  This is a good choice for lunch on a sunny day.
author: Kevin S.

description: To the owner and staff:  If you don't like having an all-u-can-eat night then don't have one! It's your business and your decision to make. It was made perfectly clear by the attitudes of the host and my server that Goat Hill did not want my business on Monday 2/12/07. I did not enjoy the surly attitudes, frowning faces or the loud sighs of discontent. If it's such a horrible thing for the staff to endure then nix it or learn to deal with it without making your customers miserable in turn. Hands down the most unfriendly staff I've ever met. I won't be coming back.
author: Richard F.

description: It's my neighborhood place.  I want to like it.  I don't.  I feel bad, not for any good reason other than it would be freaking awesome to have a great pizza place within spitting distance of my home.  Tried it umpteen times, never felt it, so now I buy half-baked pizzas from Cheeseboard and Arizmendi on my East Bay forays, and cut them up into quarters and freeze them.  That + a few Sierra Nevadas in the fridge = I can have pizza whenever I want.  So I have neighborhood pizza after all.
author: Laurel B.

description: I really want to give 1 star due to the rude behavior of the woman working there but the pizza is better than that.  The older woman working there tonight (July 28) is simply rude. I ordered over the phone and didn't hear what the price she quoted was. When I showed up to pick it up, I wasn't sure the price and this woman (wearing a shirt saying "in pink" on it) snapped at me saying "I told you the price" over the phone.  Ok, sorry I didn't hear that, what difference does it make, unnecessary.  Why are you snapping for no reason at a polite customer.  I own restaurants and would send her walking if I ever heard such pointlessly rude behavior at mine.  Whoever the manager or owner is, should be aware that terribly rude staff members do your business harm.  No one wants to be treated poorly... especially as a paying customer.  Very unfortunate.  Decent pizza, but this portly older woman isn't helping.
author: matteo C.

description: Love love love this place.  Anyone who will do a kick ass soy cheese pizza is alright in my book.  Their marinara is just right - not too oily, not too salty, just enough garlic.  Their offerings of toppings make me squeal like a happy little girl on her first horse back ride.  I love their salads - with a mix of romaine and iceburg lettuce, beans, cumcumbers, red onions, tomatos... and their Italian dressing is nummy!!!  They have a nice offering of wines and beers, and their atmosphere is chill.
author: Lea R.

description:
Fantastic!

Great pizza & good service.  Could be less expensive, but worth it.

Our waitress was hot, in a dirty-girl sort of way.
author: The P.

description: I would give 2.5 if I could, but not 3 so I am going w/ 2 stars.  Basically it was just okay, not okay enough to order from again however.  The crust was kinda puffy, not doughy or chewy just puffy.  I ordered the pie well done or crispy and it wasn't.  I have a feeling if I hadn't taken that precaution it would've arrived a bit soggy.  There was plenty of cheese, but it was pretty flavourless.  So there you go in a nutshell.  Maybe it's my east coast roots and my years living off NYC slices, but this place is only so-so.
author: Heather S.

description: We get delivery from here and it's always a great meal. Quality ingredients and greayt service
author: Meagan B.

description: Awesome all you can eat deal on Monday nights! The pizza is fresh and delicious and there are so many kinds to choose from! The servers walk around and deliver right to you, which is great and makes it all the easier to stuff your face all night. The slices are small so you get to try all kinds, and there is a great variety of both veggie and meat options. The salad bar is ok too - definitely a nice balance to the all the pizza intake. Cheap pitchers of good draft beer really make this a fun night out with a group!
author: Stephanie H.

description: This place is great.  The view looking out is great.  And the service we had  was great.  Unfortunately, our pizza wasn't perfect.  They ran out of artichokes for our Californian Pizza order so we got the veggie pizza.  The veggie slice wasn't fantabulous.  I don't think I am a fan of the crust. It is sourdough and wasn't crispy enough for my taste. So: 4 stars.  But it still is one of my favorite portrero hill joints.
author: Lauren S.

description: Fantastic pizza. We went here with a huge group and they were somehow able to accomodate 15+ people. The servers were really nice as well. Definitely going back!
author: Ben E.

description: I'll admit it: Goat Hill might be the real reason why I occasionally volunteer for One Brick Food Bank nights - it's a really good excuse to drive across town for pizza!  Anyway, at the latest outing, this girl and I bonded over the fact that we both wanted cheese pizza, as opposed to the multi-topping pizzas that everyone else was wanting.  And she made a good point: a plain cheese pizza is the test of whether a pizza is truly good or not, because there's no hiding the quality of the dough, the cheese, and the sauce under lots of toppings.   Goat Hill's pizza stands up to that test perfectly - all three are delicious.
author: DD B.

description: Lovin' the sourdough crust! You can't go wrong with any choice in toppings as long as it comes on that crust. My brother and his girlfriend couldn't stop raving about Goat Hill and kept asking to go back. Maybe next time, lil bro!
author: Nathalie L.

description: Gimme a GHP on PH! One star for the pizza- always fresh, always scrumptious. Crispy sourdough crust- need I say more? One star for the service- I can usually get in and out in a reasonable amount of time, and the waiters are friendly. One star for the view- I love looking at the city at night. One star for Monday night madness, even if I never get to make it. Minus one star for serving pizza that makes me fat...
author: Stephen H.

description: I'm from New York so I'm totally biased but I will admit that Goat Hill serves up a pretty tasty pizza.  The restaurant has a nice family-friendly environment.  You get a real sense of the history of Potrero Hill inside (there's old photos covering the walls), which is fun for a resident like myself.  Nice crispy crust, good toppings.  If you're in the mood for pizza, it will definitely hit the spot.
author: Kristin P.

description: My hubby and I came here to try the pizza about a year ago, although I couldn't really give it an honest review considering I had a cold and my sense of taste was..well you know..not existent. So anyway, I came back for a slice a few times in the past few weeks, since this pizza place is near where I work. I had actually missed my T-train and another one would cause me to miss my Ferry back to Vallejo, so anyway had to call the hubby and have him pick me up. Meanwhile, I was ravenous and decided to take the 22 up to 18Th street and scope out some grub. I didn't want to spend a lot so I went with Goat Hill pizza, and got myself 2 slices while I waited for him to arrive. I had a mushroom and pineapple and a garlic and olive slice. Boy where those good and BOY do they ever pile on that garlic. I have to say the wait was long and I felt kind of ignored even though I was sitting there ready to order. So so much for quick service. I also didn't;t enjoy having to sit there by myself since I felt like all the rich "yuppies" were staring me down along with the ditsy blonde's who apparently have no other worries in their life, besides trying to decide on what to order. But overall, not a bad pizza place at all, in fact it's my 3rd favorite in the city, and love how crispy and thin the crust is. My only recommendation is, don't eat in unless there's someone with you, or you'll feel rather ignored and stared at.
author: Petra S.

description: I used to live right down the street from this spot. Goooood Pizza! All you can eat pizza??? My buddy Yoshi went to work. Definitely my favorite pizza spot in SF.
author: Ken K.

description: Bucking the trend of terrible left coast pizza, Goat Hill Pizza's sourdough crust stands out among the Californian style pizzerias in SF. The best night to come here is Monday night - for their special version of all you can eat pizza served dim sum style. For $9.95, you get the pizza (including gourmet toppings) and access to the salad bar. Folks, this is some of the best pizza you'll find out here.
author: Neil K.

description: A postcard romantic view of downtown San Francisco with a nice slice of pizza and a heavily dressed salad.  I love it.  Holds a special place in my heart as the restaurant in which some pretty incredible friendships were born after several lonely months following my arrival in SF.
author: L W.

description: Their pizza is below average.  I don't think the all you can eat night is worth all the hype, when you don't even like the pizza that much.  But the staff is very nice.  Too pricey for me.  If the pizza's mediocre, I want it to be cheap, too.
author: Honey L.

description: After I finished unloading the Uhaul at my new apartment in Po' Hill, my friend and I swung by this neighborhood pizza parlor. It happened to be Monday. Dude, all-you-can-eat pizza? All sorts of toppings? Swaayt! The crust crunch quotient just right, and some toppings atypical enough. That said, I went back on a non-Monday with my brother and we got a pizza. It just wasn't the same eating the same pie slices over and over, even if it included some of my favorite traditional toppings (olives, shrooms, pepperoni). After all, I had already had the all-you-can-eat Monday experience. I could be munching on artichokes or pesto or chicken or spinach, I found myself thinking. Goat Hill rates an enthusiastic thumbs up on Mondays. Just above average rating other days.
author: dave y.

description: We just had a nice lunch with the family. Service is good and the food is great. Had the Mediterranean pizza with gaot cheese, onion and spinach. The kids shared a meatball spaghetti and did not leave much! Great neighborhood place for families.
author: Reza M.

description: Who doesn't love pizza and beer? What makes Goat Hill special is the Monday night all-you-can-eat pizza, and the fact that I can drunkenly waddle home after the revelry. I'm not usually a thin crust person, but goat hill's thin crust really compliments the rich flavors in their sauces, cheeses and toppings. So delicious!
author: Alanna B.

description: I'm not the biggest fan of pizza but I have to give up to Goat Hill Pizza.   Something about their pizza makes my mouth water.  Not to oily, not to salty, and the crust is baked to perfection.  If you haven't been here yet you must make a trip out to this area.  The perks about this location is that I've always been able to find parking easily!
author: Jenny H.

description: Tasty crust and some interesting pizzas at this Potrero Hill pizza joint. There is plenty of seating so it's good for a casual Sunday dinner.
author: Nish N.

description: I've walked past Goat Hill Pizza a few times when visiting a friend who lives close by. Today, due to the fact that I didn't have food all day I was starving and decided to grab a slice of sausage pizza on my way. I got my slice to-go so I could eat it at my friend's house. I was super excited to eat my presumably delicious slice of pizza. There was plenty of sausage, which tasted pretty good, but the pizza itself was kind of whatever.  I have a feeling my slice might have been sitting around for awhile before they reheated it again for my order. There was barely any sauce and the crust was lacking flavor. Overall the pizza wasn't awful, but it certainly wasn't great either. Considering that my stomach was on the verge of eating itself I can't complain too much cause the slice did fill me up, however it was nothing memorable. I doubt I'll have Goat Hill Pizza again.
author: Paige C.

description: Sourdough crust, fresh toppings...OMG!  My favorite pizza in SF.  I might check out the all you can eat night on Mondays.  $10.95 for all you can eat pizza and salad.
author: Kattya B.

description:
went for the monday night all-you-can-eat
the hostess was terse and not efficient
the pizza was okay, but definitely not the best.
honestly, i think round table is better
they have a lot of vegetarian options which is fine if you are a vegetarian.
where's the meat?!
not worth the 30-minute wait
author: Deka M.

description:
definitely a place to try again.  let's explore why...


- good selection of toppings, and the garlic comes with all ur pizzas.  oh, have i told u i LOVE garlic.  if you're a vampire, this might not be the place for u.

- service was good, the gal was friendly, its a pizza joint, what else can u ask for.  water was on the table and i got my diet coke.  good enough for me.

- the pizza was piping hot, tons of toppings, perfectly cooked

- great crispy crust

- $20 for two, not bad since we were carrying our bellies out the door.

- great location, we explored the hills and made a decision to hit up the local restaurants our next trip back

-  still burping up the italian sausage, the pizza that keeps on giving. yum!
author: Ames K.

description: Goat Hill Pizza is only 2 blocks away from my flat, and it always looked like Free Pizza night every Monday evening. Well, they may not be giving it away, but for just $9 in your pocket (plus tip & drinks)  you can partake an unlimited array of Dim Sum Pizza and salad. It is kind of exciting to see which pizzas will be staring you in the face.  I ate way too much but that's my own damn fault.  For $9 this is quite the deal and it makes for an exciting Monday.
author: Suzanne A.
